content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												The Witcher comes off as a game that firmly has its hauberk and claymore equipped on one screen, and a naughty wink and nudge on another. Its medieval fantasy setting brings you a world in its own Dark Ages with modern problems, but the way that it works those problems into a detailed, twisting story makes The Witcher stand out as the best RPG to have arrived on the PC in 2008.It earns its maturity rating because of the subjects it tackles rather than to the occasional F-bomb that the NPCs drop. Non-humans such as elves and dwarves are victims of open racism and must live in a medieval ghetto that humans tend to avoid. Cutthroat intrigue lies hidden behind every story, often revealing unexpected twists that force you to think twice about navigating through the many shades of gray that taint every decision. There's no alignment here, only the choices that you make. Consequences often reveal themselves much later in the game, thus shaping the epic story in subtle ways. The Witcher manages to make the amnesiac angle work without feeling stale since the character whose role you step into, Geralt, actually has a personality of his own. You may not be able to choose a face, gender or hairstyle to build from, but every action, decision or person you help or treat to the end of his sword will shape his story through new adventures. You aren't required to know anything more than what the manual has to say, creating a clean break from the Polish novels upon which the game is based.Witchers are mutants, changed through alchemy and granted exceptional abilities that hone their work as medieval monster hunters. Not every candidate who attempts to become a witcher survives the experience, but those who do become something more than human. By the time the game begins, witchers are few and far between, and Geralt is one of the handful remaining who continue their work despite the superstitious disdain that both peasants and polite society have for their ilk. Fortunately, he is also one of the best, and while his memory may be lost, what he remembers is enough to skewer his foes with steel and spell. This is a good thing because Geralt travels alone, although he sometimes fights alongside temporary allies.Geralt wants to know what happened to him, but more importantly, who tried to kill him and the other witchers. There are at least 40 to 60 hours of adventure here, with each chapter packed with plenty of things to do and kill. The simple interface helps keep track of your quests with a glossary of people, monsters and terms, and it's also where you can view Geralt's vitals, what he's equipped with — all of the usual information. It's not a bad system, but it would have been nice to be able to automatically organize his inventory as opposed to manually moving everything around yourself.As a witcher, Geralt uses a two-handed steel sword for his human foes and a silver blade for the monsters he hunts; both weapons can be swapped out during real-time combat, as can his combat stances, such as a strong style that's best suited against well-armored foes or a group style that gives everyone a taste of death. As Geralt levels up, he'll also earn "tokens" that can be used to improve his personal statistics or skills, especially those for combat, such as his swordsmanship abilities.Fighting is all in real time, including dodges and spinning jumps, but just as in Knights of the Old Republic or Baldur's Gate, you can pause the action with the spacebar to give you a breather and decide what to do next. Potions are just as important to a witcher as their blades, allowing them to heal faster in battle or see in the dark, although utilizing too many potions will eventually poison their blood. Resting by a fire or at an inn will clear out the poison before it becomes a problem, which you'll need to keep in mind when red spots start filling the screen.It wouldn't be much of a game without a compelling setting, and CD Projekt's passion for the material succeeds in building a living world, although as Geralt, you can't simply skewer the occasional shopkeeper ... unless it's a monster. As you go from chapter to chapter, you'll also find that you can't revisit certain areas, although there is still plenty to do in the current town. NPCs bearing medieval flutes and drums complement a fantasy-oriented soundtrack that Peter Jackson might have used, aside from the occasional electric guitar. Well acted, in-game cinematics add to the modern-flavored fantasy, thanks to the remarkable voice acting and animation work.As fun as The Witcher can be, it does have issues. Combat can feel a little clunky, and not everyone may like reflex-based click chains, especially when Geralt provides little feedback as to whether or not your clicked attack worked. The difficulty level of one or two of the boss battles can also surprise the player; it may have been a cakewalk to reach them, but it's shocking when Geralt's opponent suddenly starts wiping the floor with him.Despite its faults, The Witcher is a diamond in the rough as a mature, gritty and atmospheric RPG that heads into territory not often explored. The modern, tongue-in-cheek additions to the fantasy tale of Geralt's journey and the choices that shape it build a unique experience that might keep you awake for hours simply to find out what happens next. Games have grown up along with their players, and The Witcher is the kind of title that the genre deserves to have.

graphics.The witcher has a great story.The story starts really slow and dull until you reach the third chapter.By reaching the third chapter,things get really interesting.The problem is,you get dragged through 3 long boring chapters,with unnecessary main missions and some little odd ones.But in the end,the story stands out with its unique choices.The gamplay is the game's weakness.I say this with full confident due to alot of flows in the combat system,AI,boss   fights,difficulty, glitches and so more.The combat system is good idea the was executed badly due to random stunning you get even if you were away from enemies or they had no chance of hitting you,random bleeding,randomly beating an enemy with one hit even it is impossible,or even being forced to use a normal sword to what is clearly not a human enemy.The AI is bad,you may say it is justifiable for a game that came out in 2007 but i think they could have done better or at least updated it.The friends who company you die easily and completely useless.The enemy AI is odd and sometimes standing far away stops them from attacking you or simply running around them in circles.What really annoy me in some of the bosses is how scripted the fighting is.You could check The spider queen fight.It is unbelievable how scripted it was.The difficulty spike from easy to normal is ridiculous.I highly recommend playing it easy if you cant take dying from an OP enemy or a boss.Finally,the gliches.Three are alot of them.Sometimes you cant use any sign,even if you reloaded the game.Sometimes,by walking around a cretin area,you can avoid a main story fight!!some keys refuses to respond like your mouses right click or the saving button.Using a sigh has no effect on enemies who are close to you and this glitch can cause you troubles.I could take along times mentioning these glitches.The Witcher has a good graphics.The game obviously aged well.Even playing it without mods didn't make it old .Though you cant play it with SlI enabled without problems for some reason. In conclousion,The witcher is great game with alot of problems.I recommend it only in easy difficulty and for a really really patient gamer.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												An amazing RPG that has just the right balance of old and new RPG mechanics. The only true flaw with the game is its numerous difficulty spikes, but in the grand scheme of things, this is forgiveable, as the rest of the game makes up for it. The combat blends together a tactical and action-focused approach, giving you a rush while retaining a D&D feel. The story is, in my opinion, highly original, with a monster slayer trying to cope with a changing world in which man can be a greater danger than beast. With this changing world, he too must change, learning to fight humans as well as monsters. In this ever-changing world, nothing is ever black and white.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												The first installment of the Witcher series surprised me quite a bit, to say the least. I've heard good things about the games multiple times before, mostly how good Witcher 2 was. So i decided to check the series for myself.If you are a fan of cool fantasy based story with a lot of choices - this game is definitely for you. Basically any of your responses to the dialogues will affect the story in some way. The results will not be as massive as something from the Mass Effect series, but they are still deep and impactful nonetheless.As always, there's something good, something bad, and something ugly. The good here is obviously the story. But the story can not be the only reason to play a game like this. Since 95% of the game is combat, this aspect of the game should have been one of the main focuses of the developers. What we receieved as a finished product though, is some point-and-click strategy with abysmal combat but amazing story, instead of something that should fit in a proper 3D RPG. Witcher 2 is what 1 should have been, and I'm glad they switched from the engine Witcher 1 is running on.In any case, the game is very good. If you can handle the terrible combat and a bit outdated graphics, this game will definitely be wirth the 8$ it is right now (1.20$ on sale). Giving it a very solid 7.5/10

												This is a good narrative rpg, but a god awful video game. The combat is terrible, the character progression is terrible, the inventory management is terrible, the game's auto save system is completely sentient and makes its own damn rules, Act III comes with a hearty helping of cpu usage issues with a nice side of micro-stutter, oh and bad voice acting combined with robotic facial animations makes Geralt being hit on and getting laid constantly extremely awkward and uncomfortable. BUT, even with all that, play this game. The stories are well written and have numerous outcomes based entirely on the way you do things. Choices are rarely laid out in front of you and always have a significant impact later in the game.Recommendation: this game is everything that Bioware RPGs wishes they were, but the low budget and (probable)inexperience of CDProjektRed in 2007 hides the good behind multiple layers of clunk and awkward.Side Note: Assassin of Kings succeeds in virtually every area that this game fails, so it's an obvious choice over this game, but they allow you to import a save with all your choices, so I'd say The Witcher is worth suffering through to get the best experience out of the sequel, even if you hate its guts.

content:
Posted: April 21
												For fans of older/classic action RPGs, The Witcher (EE) is a must-play.  I would rank it up  there with KOTOR personally and (not coincidentally, I'm sure) the actual alignment paths you can follow as Geralt are pretty similar: good/Hero, neutral/Witcher, and evil/Wild Hunt  Champion.  It's an old game though so don't expect to be blown away by NPC/enemy  variety.  In fact, I would say that is really the only downside to The Witcher: the limitations  of an old engine which basically builds in a lot of repetitive gameplay.  But the engine is so great for what it is though; a build of Bioware's Aurora engine (Neverwinter Nights' engine) which would act as the foundation for Knights of the Old Republic (I and II).  The story and the character of Geralt, the world you inhabit--a dirty world (uncensored!) that almost benefits from less color depth, kept me so engrossed that I hardly noticed and definitely didn't begrudge The Witcher it's quirks and old age.  It is especially worth playing if you plan to continue the series since you can import your save game and give yourself some cool continuity game-to-game (RIP Bioware trend).  The game is fully voiced and it is full of  dialogue and conversation trees and every interaction has some kind of impact on the overall  game and story.  Read as: this game is chock-full of content.  Take the "risk".  If you need some more assurance, continue reading as I try to address the common detractors.	The "scariest" thing about The Witcher is the combat system but really, it's very streamlined in my opinion and once you understand that it's all about timing and selecting the correct fighting forms (and thus, levelling up the corresponding forms and attributes/talents) it becomes very easy to navigate.  I'll try to break down  the system so you have a slight primer going in: Geralt has two swords; one steel and one silver.  Steel for humans/normal animals and silver for monsters/magical creatures.  PC Master Race so movement is WASD with Q for pulling steel and E for pulling silver, M1 for attack.  Each sword has three forms: strong, fast and group.  Each form has a different animation set and a different effect on enemies.  If you notice you're hitting the crap out of something and it's barely taking damage, change forms (one button press cycles the forms, Q for steel, E for silver) until you start landing blows and doing damage.  Time your M1 clicks with the "firey" sword pointer. STR, DEX, END all correspond to the different forms so when you level up, look at the different talents and you'll see how to buff the strong form, for instance (HINT: it's in the STR tree).  INT is all about your magic abilities (and certain crafting abilities; Bombs and Oils) so levelling up INT will benefit your Signs arsenal, which are offensive/defensive magic "spells" you cast during combat with M2.   Geralt starts with one sign, gets another fairly quickly and then eventually you get five signs that all loosely represent some elemental aspect (air, water, fire, etc).  You cycle through signs by hitting 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  THEN there's Alchemy which isn't really tied to any attribute and depends more on whether you have the recipe--alchemy is all about collecting materials and strong alcohol to use in mixes for cool potions which you can put into quickslots (which you can drink on the fly during combat, very useful).  Potions are all toxic to some degree though so you can't abuse them.   (I didn't even use bombs or sword oil on my playthrough.)	The other thing, the dreaded fetch-quests.  The Witcher's fetch-quests are obviously labelled as "Monster X Contract" with the note of "Must have Monster X  bestiary entry to complete".  They all boil down to: kill X number of monster Y to collect mat Z.  Some are collected as "proof" but most are for alchemy mats.  Early game they are useful because you'll be killing monsters anyway, late game they are entirely skippable although the rewards get better and better as you progress through the game (typically, sometimes it's just gold).  	The game has tons of onscreen information and tips too if I've been too presumptuous... I mean, not everyone grew up playing Dungeons and Dragons I guess.  Roll for initiative!  (Oh yeah, Dice Poker in-game!)

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
The Witcher, worth buyingOverall impressionIt is an older game, but the graphics are okay. I really enjoyed the atmosphere in this game and the story is entertaining and intersting. I haven't read the books, but the game makes me consider to give those a try because everything appears to be well-thought-out. With all the different options and styles it might take a while before you feel comfortable with the controls, but soon as you remember the hotkeys it becomes a second nature. Geralt's sarcasm and sense of humor really made me enjoy the various dialogues. I also love the fact that this is a mature game with mature content because that fits the medieval setting and makes it feel more immersive. And yes, I had fun to collect all those cards! Player advice:Save early, save often. Learn to play the dice poker game, it is the best way to earn money and remember that everything you do in this game has consequences that can alter the story and make things easier or harder for you.   Bugs: In the first few chapters I encountered no problems. But after chapter 3 the game crashed every few hours. By the time I started chapter 4 it happened every few minutes. The screen often turned black (even though the game itself continued) and/or crashes to desktop often ignoring my last save. It really killed the fun (and my mood) but thanks to various websites I found a way to prevent that from happening; disable the autosave and do not use more than 15 savegame slots to prevent crashes. If you play the game in windowed mode it is less likely to crash and you can download a tool that allows you to play the game windowed whilst appearing to be full screen. After that, the game worked fine again and I've experienced no more crashes.Could be better: I really hope the sequels are less likely to crash, if it wasn't for all the good information of how to prevent it I would have likely stopped playing the game because of that. That said, I'm glad I didn't stop because the game itself was really enjoyable and I want to buy the sequel games as well. Frustrating is Geralt's tiny inventory combined with the item-overkill in the game. You often end up selling or discarding items that you could use a few moments later, or you carry something with you that you have no use of at all. More NPC-models would also be an improvement because you always look at the same old hag because there is only one model for elderly women. Which would not be so frustrating if they were able to age gracefully... Final thingy; I would have never thought I would say this, but please lower the number of redheads in game. I know we are sexy as hell but we do not make up for 85% of the female population... ;-)

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
The Witcher: Enhanced Edition - ReviewThe Witcher is a story driver, character focused Role-Playing Game that follows the exploits of professional monster hunter and witcher, Geralt of Rivia.------------I don't like scores, but it's a good way for people to get an idea of where a game stands in different categories, so I use them for those of you who don't like reading too much. According to my system, a 5 is completely in the middle, not like IGN and Gamespot's stupidity, where a 5 is a disaster.------------Visuals 7.5/10 [Graphics - 6 | Artstyle - 9]Running on a heavily modified version of BioWare's Aurora engine, it's natural for The Witcher to look dated in the 2010's, but due to CDProjektRED's attention to detail and loving recreation of Andrzej Sapkowski's fictional world it still manages to look pleasing. The world and characters show a genuine degree of wear and tear and it seems like everything has been designed intentionally, to give you a good idea of what a person is and does before you even speak to them. There is very good consistency of detail without anything standing out as drastically better or worse.The texture work hold up surprisingly well, although some of the models are a tad on the lower quality side, not to mention re-used on several occasions. There exists a mod (Rise of the White Wolf[www.nexusmods.com]) which fixes some of these concerns, while bringing the character designs more in-line with the rest of the franchise. The UI is functional and easy to navigate, despite it being a bit gaudy, visually speaking, the aforementioned mod helps with that too.Gameplay 7/10The Witcher's gameplay, although very well balanced, might put a lot of people off, mostly due to the clunky nature of it's combat. In the lore, Witchers enter a calmed state of mind while fighting, following a specific rhythm. What that means, is that you need to time your clicks, so that they coincide with the end of an attack animation, instead of freely clicking whenever you choose, which ends up stopping your combo. A lot of people feel put off by this, I personally don't mind it at all, but what I do mind is the lack of player feedback when you've broken a combo or when you've continued it. There is feedback, but it's not very noticeable. A lot of the animations aren't particularly responsive as well, a holdover from the way the Aurora engine handles animations, but they do their job fairly well. The game features robust character development mechanics that also follow the philosophy of "though choices" that the series is known for, meaning you'll not be able to become a master at everything. Everything else is by the book and completely functional, there are several minigames you can engage in, the quest system is robust and it's just generally a functional if slightly unpolished game. The challenge is high but fair and the unique spin, namely a Witcher's prepwork, does play well with it's other system. For those seeking a greater challenge, along with a more faithful adaptation of the source material, I will recommend the Full Combat Rebalance mod, who's developer actually got hired by the CDPR as a result.Sound 9/10 [Music - 10 | Voice Acting - 8]This game's music is beautiful, the soundtrack is certainly worth owning, not to mention it comes with a separate disc of music that was inspired by the game, performed by different musical acts, such as the widely known death metal band Vader. Calm Slavic and Celtic folk meet to solidify the atmosphere of The Witcher's world and provide a truly unique experience. There is great internal consistency within the soundtrack and the combat music manages to both by fitting to action, without dropping those folkish motifs.The voice acting is generally decent but there are several hits and misses. Most notable is the incorrect intonation of several characters, my guess is that the actors didn't exactly understand the context of the lines. Nothing too jarring though.Story 9.5/10 [Story - 10 | Writing - 9 | World Building - 10]It's difficult to write about a game's story without spoiling it, so I won't. I'll instead focus on an aspect of video game storytelling that The Witcher does exceptionally well.Choices and consequences, they aren't immediate sometimes, they are always difficult to make and they might come back to haunt you. This game layers on the morally gray overtones that we associate with adult fiction, and boy are those layers heavy. The world is filled with racism and all manner of bad people being bad to similarly bad people, which you get to be a bad person towards, or not, your choice.The Writing is certainly praiseworthy with no standout flaws. A few lines miss their intended goals here and there, but on the whole the writing is superb and memorable, certainly helping to bring the world and characters that inhabit it to life.Segueing into the worldbuilding, there is tons of ingame lore to read, but more importantly, key aspects of The Witcher's universe are presented to you through ingame events, helping you both learn and grow a bond to this fictitious place. All of the game's narrative elements combine to form this expertly designed and extremely immersive experience, which you won't soon forget. Element  Score  Visuals  7.5/10   Gameplay  7/10  Sound  9/10  Story  9.5/10  Overall  8.5/10 My personal recommendation is to play this game, it is one of my favorite games of all time. The unique story and characters, fleshed out world, choices that matter and unforgettable journey makes The Witcher: Enhanced Edition a truly special game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Not the prettiest game, not the greatest combat system (igni), terrible lip syncing and some pretty poor character models, very weird story telling system (at first), and lots and lots of walking simulator. But somehow, it's one of the most compelling and overall best games I've ever played. If you're having a hard time getting into it, just play through the first act and see how you feel. It took me a while to get invested, but at one point in class I was just like, "Dang, I really wish I was playing the Witcher right now," went home, and played for 50 hours over the course of a week or so.I'm honestly not sure what makes this game so great. None of the individual aspects really stand out, with the exception of maybe the story. However, the story telling method just thrusts you into the game, characters discuss events that you haven't experienced like you're supposed to know what's going on, and there are a lot of unanswered questions by the end.But somehow, it all ties together to make one inredible game. Probably the best RPG I've ever played.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												The Witcher comes off as a game that firmly has its hauberk and claymore equipped on one screen, and a naughty wink and nudge on another. Its medieval fantasy setting brings you a world in its own Dark Ages with modern problems, but the way that it works those problems into a detailed, twisting story makes The Witcher stand out as the best RPG to have arrived on the PC in 2008.It earns its maturity rating because of the subjects it tackles rather than to the occasional F-bomb that the NPCs drop. Non-humans such as elves and dwarves are victims of open racism and must live in a medieval ghetto that humans tend to avoid. Cutthroat intrigue lies hidden behind every story, often revealing unexpected twists that force you to think twice about navigating through the many shades of gray that taint every decision. There's no alignment here, only the choices that you make. Consequences often reveal themselves much later in the game, thus shaping the epic story in subtle ways. The Witcher manages to make the amnesiac angle work without feeling stale since the character whose role you step into, Geralt, actually has a personality of his own. You may not be able to choose a face, gender or hairstyle to build from, but every action, decision or person you help or treat to the end of his sword will shape his story through new adventures. You aren't required to know anything more than what the manual has to say, creating a clean break from the Polish novels upon which the game is based.Witchers are mutants, changed through alchemy and granted exceptional abilities that hone their work as medieval monster hunters. Not every candidate who attempts to become a witcher survives the experience, but those who do become something more than human. By the time the game begins, witchers are few and far between, and Geralt is one of the handful remaining who continue their work despite the superstitious disdain that both peasants and polite society have for their ilk. Fortunately, he is also one of the best, and while his memory may be lost, what he remembers is enough to skewer his foes with steel and spell. This is a good thing because Geralt travels alone, although he sometimes fights alongside temporary allies.Geralt wants to know what happened to him, but more importantly, who tried to kill him and the other witchers. There are at least 40 to 60 hours of adventure here, with each chapter packed with plenty of things to do and kill. The simple interface helps keep track of your quests with a glossary of people, monsters and terms, and it's also where you can view Geralt's vitals, what he's equipped with — all of the usual information. It's not a bad system, but it would have been nice to be able to automatically organize his inventory as opposed to manually moving everything around yourself.As a witcher, Geralt uses a two-handed steel sword for his human foes and a silver blade for the monsters he hunts; both weapons can be swapped out during real-time combat, as can his combat stances, such as a strong style that's best suited against well-armored foes or a group style that gives everyone a taste of death. As Geralt levels up, he'll also earn "tokens" that can be used to improve his personal statistics or skills, especially those for combat, such as his swordsmanship abilities.Fighting is all in real time, including dodges and spinning jumps, but just as in Knights of the Old Republic or Baldur's Gate, you can pause the action with the spacebar to give you a breather and decide what to do next. Potions are just as important to a witcher as their blades, allowing them to heal faster in battle or see in the dark, although utilizing too many potions will eventually poison their blood. Resting by a fire or at an inn will clear out the poison before it becomes a problem, which you'll need to keep in mind when red spots start filling the screen.It wouldn't be much of a game without a compelling setting, and CD Projekt's passion for the material succeeds in building a living world, although as Geralt, you can't simply skewer the occasional shopkeeper ... unless it's a monster. As you go from chapter to chapter, you'll also find that you can't revisit certain areas, although there is still plenty to do in the current town. NPCs bearing medieval flutes and drums complement a fantasy-oriented soundtrack that Peter Jackson might have used, aside from the occasional electric guitar. Well acted, in-game cinematics add to the modern-flavored fantasy, thanks to the remarkable voice acting and animation work.As fun as The Witcher can be, it does have issues. Combat can feel a little clunky, and not everyone may like reflex-based click chains, especially when Geralt provides little feedback as to whether or not your clicked attack worked. The difficulty level of one or two of the boss battles can also surprise the player; it may have been a cakewalk to reach them, but it's shocking when Geralt's opponent suddenly starts wiping the floor with him.Despite its faults, The Witcher is a diamond in the rough as a mature, gritty and atmospheric RPG that heads into territory not often explored. The modern, tongue-in-cheek additions to the fantasy tale of Geralt's journey and the choices that shape it build a unique experience that might keep you awake for hours simply to find out what happens next. Games have grown up along with their players, and The Witcher is the kind of title that the genre deserves to have.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												The Witcher is an amazing Role-Playing game and the first entry to the popular franchise involving Geralt of Rivia, a monster slayer, more specifically, a witcher.In The Witcher, the main gameplay focuses on combat and dialogue. Talking with the characters is a huge part in completing the numerous main and side quests. What you say matters, as each possible line might cause something different, it can mean a mass slaughtering or a problem solved in a peaceful way. Certain characters will help you or not depending on what desicions you made in the past.It is known that combat is a weak part of the game, but it is not as bad as people make it out to be. Sure, it is not the same as the later Witchers' but it isn't that awful. When you put the cursor over an enemy, it will turn into a sword, that's when you can attack. Clicking mid-action stops the attack. Clicking when the sword is flaming starts a chain of attacks. Depending on what type of enemy you are fighting, you will use a different sword. The steel sword is used against humans, elves, dwarfs, dogs, while the silver one is used against monsters. Three fighting styles are available, depending on if the enemy is a strong or light type, or you are fighting a group of enemies.Witchers have the ability to use signs - they provide specials powers such as telecinetic blasts, shields, making enemies your allies and more. As the game progresses you will find them all. Geralt can brew potions - large part of the game, especially if you are playing on a higher difficulity, make oil - to enhance his swords and deal more damage, and craft bombs.Story is also amazing, but considering the game is made after a book, it's not surprising. People say that the second and third game's stories are more important, though, so what do I know.Along with the game, you get adventures, I guess they could be called free DLC. They are small main quests, not tied to the story. An adventure editor also comes with them.Overall, this is a must play for RPG fans out there and considering it goes as low as an euro during sales, it's a great deal as the game can provide over 30 hours of fun.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I am editing this review because my last review was simply to warn people not to buy this if you intend to play on a Mac.  Having now owned a pc a few years and beaten the game, it's time for a new, complete review.Chances are, if you are reading reviews for Witcher 1, you are wondering if it is worth playing before you play the sequels.  That, my friend, depends entirely on you.  This game is hard to love. But I love it. There are MAYBE a dozen different character models, and possibly half that number of voice actors.  It's clunky, in a bioware-KOTOR-Trying to kill a butterfly with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sword kind of clunky. **[Steam insists on censoring that word, but it's actually the more common way to refer to a Hand-and-a-Half sword, and not a derrogatory term for a child born out of wedlock.]**   The graphics are dated, the combat style is very odd, so why am I recommending it?It made me uncomfortable.  Art is designed to give you a certain emotion, and the witcher is designed to make you uncomfortable.  You won't sit back with a cold beer and enjoy this game with your feet up, you will sit on the edge of your seat taking quick shots of strong vodka to numb the fear of entering that pitch black cave filled with too many creepy crawlies to count, and also because THAT'S WHAT GERALT WOULD DO.  This game introduces the player to the creepy, grim, unsettling world of the witcher.  There are no silver linings; there are no "good choices" or "evil choices", only tough decisions with no clear predictable outcome. Geralt is a mutant, and can wield some very minor magic, but he is no invincible hero.  Depending on difficulty level, and stat progression, this game can be rather challenging.  The sounds work well with the graphics, even though dated, to paint a believable world full of death, decay, lies, sex, love, and at times, some hope.   This game is showing it's age, as mentioned. You will be teleported around against your will.   Some questlines won't make sense or even seem continuous and some just seem to end. And you WILL get sick of seeing the same character models (besides the main important chars) and hearing the same voices.  But if you can get past all of that, and perhaps other problems I am not remembering at this time, you will find a deep, compelling game that throws you into a story much bigger than one character.It is atmospheric, dark, gruesome, but at times silly, and campy.  Overall, I simply love the world of the Witcher, with all it's realistic racial and political conflict, realistic cause and effect type events, and a world that believably exists regardless of your character's existence.  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>TL,DR: Its a highly atmospheric intruduction to the world of the witcher, with different gameplay than the sequels, but is worth struggling through for certain people, despite it's showing age.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												This is a good narrative rpg, but a god awful video game. The combat is terrible, the character progression is terrible, the inventory management is terrible, the game's auto save system is completely sentient and makes its own damn rules, Act III comes with a hearty helping of cpu usage issues with a nice side of micro-stutter, oh and bad voice acting combined with robotic facial animations makes Geralt being hit on and getting laid constantly extremely awkward and uncomfortable. BUT, even with all that, play this game. The stories are well written and have numerous outcomes based entirely on the way you do things. Choices are rarely laid out in front of you and always have a significant impact later in the game.Recommendation: this game is everything that Bioware RPGs wishes they were, but the low budget and (probable)inexperience of CDProjektRed in 2007 hides the good behind multiple layers of clunk and awkward.Side Note: Assassin of Kings succeeds in virtually every area that this game fails, so it's an obvious choice over this game, but they allow you to import a save with all your choices, so I'd say The Witcher is worth suffering through to get the best experience out of the sequel, even if you hate its guts.

content:

												The first installment of the Witcher series surprised me quite a bit, to say the least. I've heard good things about the games multiple times before, mostly how good Witcher 2 was. So i decided to check the series for myself.If you are a fan of cool fantasy based story with a lot of choices - this game is definitely for you. Basically any of your responses to the dialogues will affect the story in some way. The results will not be as massive as something from the Mass Effect series, but they are still deep and impactful nonetheless.As always, there's something good, something bad, and something ugly. The good here is obviously the story. But the story can not be the only reason to play a game like this. Since 95% of the game is combat, this aspect of the game should have been one of the main focuses of the developers. What we receieved as a finished product though, is some point-and-click strategy with abysmal combat but amazing story, instead of something that should fit in a proper 3D RPG. Witcher 2 is what 1 should have been, and I'm glad they switched from the engine Witcher 1 is running on.In any case, the game is very good. If you can handle the terrible combat and a bit outdated graphics, this game will definitely be wirth the 8$ it is right now (1.20$ on sale). Giving it a very solid 7.5/10

												Even though a game that doesn't manage to get away with the "Amnesia Story" without a few critics noticing that, The Witcher manages to uphold the bar for a decent story where morality actually maters. No, there's no big morality bar telling you whether what you do leads you to being Mother Theresse or Satan. There's actually an inticant way of making it work in the long run, a concequence for your action that was done way long ago(hopefully you didn't forget about it). There's no boring conversations, the combat is solid enough(hard to belive it's the Aurora engine from Neverwinter Nights 2). The whole theme features a nice slavic mythology on a pretty big level with a lot of lore and such. Definetely worth buying if one is looking for a more mature experience.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I loved this game back in 2007, before a lot of patches made it better, I love it today, when some of its parts are very outdated. It's still an amazing adventure in a truly unique world with great story, witty dialogue and slavic mythology. Though, if you play it in English, it will lose some of its charm (note, I recommend playing it with Polish voice acting even if you leave text in a language you do understand).Even without some amazing mods (Full Combat Rebalance is almost a must for more fun play), which can make the rather annoying fighting much more fun, this game still holds up. The animation might be stiff, some events look visually silly, but there's enough amazing stuff happening for your imagination to fill the blanks and see what the game wanted to show, instead of what it actually shown at times.The main draw of the game is a story, so if you find gameplay lacking, fighting frustrating due to silly bugs that plagued Aurora engine (and a lot of BioWare games based on it), just don't feel bad, switch to easier mode, install the FCR mod (the fights will actually end faster with it) and enjoy the witchering adventure at it's best.And no, you don't need to know the lore or read the books before starting the game, in fact, some of it is more interesting to experience before reading the books, as books will undoubtedly colour your choices in the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												A unique role-playing game that is a rarity these days. Developed by a Polish company and is based on the book with the same title written by a Polish author called Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a mutant hunter who is specialised in fighting and slaying monsters. At the beginning of Geralt's story he does not remember much - he's found unconscious and is taken to the witchers' hideout. The establishment, then, is attacked by a group of bandits known as the Salamander - although defending the castle is a success, the witchers are unable to stop the bandits from stealing their precious mutagens. Geralt and his fellow witchers, therefore, set out to find where the gang is hiding and of course to take back what is rightfully theirs.Some notable elements that characterises Witcher and makes it different from other RPGs:--- Controlling Geralt is very easy. The game offers you several camera perspectives, in fact, even the input device can be changed: focus can be on the mouse solely or you can use the combination of the keyboard and mouse - whichever is your preference.--- During combat timing is very important. The game being hack-and-slash requires you to hit enemies several times. This, Geralt does automatically, but following the hit of his blade you can have a follow-up click with your mouse - if your timing is perfect Geralt does make a follow-up cut which is stronger and deadlier. In addition to this the game employs 3 combat styles. Larger enemies require the strong style: Geralt carefully times each hit and while they are slower they result in a heavier slash. Faster enemies simply avoid your attacks but changing to the fast style enables you to hit them. And if your are surrounded you need to use the group style.--- Beside the styles and the timing you should be careful with the material your weapon is made of. While steel-made swords are perfect against human beings and some of the monsters you encounter there are many supernatural beings in the Witcher's world you can only wound with a silver-made sword. And here come those that made me like the game a lot:--- Choices: Yes, yes, this is common. You decide to help or you simply let people die. Right? No! Witcher does not indicate what will happen once a decision is made. Unlike Mass Effect, here there are no indicators and nobody tells you whether it is good or bad what you'll attempt to do. In certain cases both decisions you can make will result in the death of someone - you need to decide which is "better" or you simply need to pick A) so that in your next playthrough you can go with option B. --- Alchemy: A very important part of the game! There are severals types of plants / herbs out there you need to collect. You can then use these at fireplaces to create potions that either make you stronger or grant you an extra ability (e.g. seeing in dark places). Interestingly, all of these poison Geralt to a certain degree - your toxicity level increases and eventually you need to rest or drink another potion that neutralises the adverse effect of these drinks. The more scrolls you find the more potions are available - you can also experiment if you have the time. It should be noted that Geralt is mainly a warrior. You have some spells called signs but they are nothing special. So, in your next playthrough you cannot have a significantly different build - you can experiment, for sure, but the value lies in Witcher's world. And this world is huge. I like how the game starts filling up your Glossary - a menu similar to the codex in the Dragon Ages series containing all kinds of entries explaining the world to the gamer. Also, while fistfighting is rather easy and boring the drinking and dice-poker mini games are excellent and make the game quite funny!I finished the game in 50+ hours and pretty much completed everything I could. I read the game's wikia pages parallelly and found that I'd missed some missions and if I remember correctly the game has at least 2 endings. So there you go: over 100 hours and this is only for 8 bucks! In addition to this, it comes in the form of a so-called Enhanced Edition that offers a lot of extras such as making-of videos and other campaigns. Plus, the game looks quite good for being released in 2007!Overall, Witcher is a unique RPG. If you are fan of the genre and finished multiple playthroughs in Dragon Age then do head for the store page as this game must be in your basket!

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Let me start by saying: Please do not buy the game expecting gameplay or graphics too similar to Witcher 2 or 3! This game is quite a bit older than the two others, and has a different style. HOWEVER! What this game has going for it is another strong story and a lot of atmosphere. This is what the company got right even in this first game. It is obvious that the team truly loves the source (the books and stories) and the world and story in this game, IMO, is VERY immersive.The playstyle is quite different, just like the graphics. It reminds me a bit more of Diablo, as it's click-to-move. You have different stances which you switch with keys, according to what you are fighting. Of course, alchemy and signs are in this game as well, as they are just of a trademark of the character as the two swords are. The game is showing it's age, as the graphics are of course not comparable to the later games, and it's quite interesting to compare the mechanics of the games, and see how the series developed. But even though this game has weaknesses and will feel VERY different compared to the later ones (total readjustment especially regarding combat), it still has tons of atmosphere and, as I said, a fascinating story. It's actually quite impressive how much the (back then) small company put into this game. If you don't mind the fact that the game is a bit older and therefore is very different regarding graphics and playstyle, if you care about the characters (of course, many of the beloved characters from the stories and the other games appear here, for example Triss and Vesemir) and the story, you might find yourself quite immersed, and if you are willing to adjust to the very different movement and combat, you might enjoy it a lot. I sure did!

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												This game was probably good for it's time, and I was actually very impressed with how well the game felt at first.  But after a while, it's age became more and more apparent.  The flaws in the game mechanics became more obvious and frustrating the longer I played, which eventually eliminated my motivation to keep playing. The biggest problem of note is that the quests show where you are supposed to go with a red dot on the map.  But many times this dot was either in too general an area to understand where I was supposed to go resulting an a trial and error exploration of that area, or it was just plain wrong.  Once it told me to go see someone at an Inn.  He was nowhere to be found.  I later found the guy walking the streets a few blocks away, and turned in the quest to him there.  Issues like this kept popping up more and more.  I have to talk to someone, and he isnt where the map says he is.  It felt too broken to be worth dealing with anymore.Also, much of the gameplay felt more like chores than fun.  People sending you back and forth across the entire town consecutively for a 30 second piece of dialogue.  It seemed unnecessary and boring.  Other than that, the story was interesting, dice and fighting was fun, and the combat was unique and skillful.  But these factors weren't able to redeem the negatives for me.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												One question, one answer.Should you play this game before the other two or just skip it?Yes, play it, or well, it’s up to you. It will set basis for you knowledge in the universe of The Witcher, and even though it’s a long game (for me 77 hours my first play trough), I felt it was totally worth it, and very rewarding. The game plays different than in The Witcher 2, instead on focusing on skill play, it focuses on tactics like alchemy and oil coating, etc. It may not sound good, but it is pretty fun. Plus the tactical knowledge carries over to the following games, letting you play I higher difficulties than before.The length of the game was in my opinion perfect, it didn’t felt repetitive, or like being obligated to do chores. Heck, I got bored of Alien Isolation halfway through the entire game which only lasted about 15 hours. I just don’t play games for long, still, this is my second most played game of all time, I would never had tough!!!For the price you get all this content, it is just a crime not to get, less than $2 for in sale sure.The only thing you have to get pass to is the gameplay, if you come from The Witcher 2 like me, don’t quit in the introduction because of the combat. Stick with it for a little and you’ll get used to is very soon, as I already say, the gameplay is a little different, but it’s still fun.Thank you CD Projekt for this Masterpiece, I’m a fan of the series now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												One of the best PC RPGs in recent memory, with a storyline and depth very few games in this genre bother having. It pulls no punches and makes no compromises. It takes SOME liberties with the source material, but nothing at all that is far-fetched or uncharecteristic of Geralt and company. This is a game that requires preparation and tactics for combat, with a world so rich and alive that its immersion is second to none. It looks beautiful for its age and its outdated Aurora engine, it plays well and has some of the best medieval-themed music out of any franchise in any media. To fans of the original books that had to suffer that absolutely heart-destroying ending, it was something of a blessing that offered a take on Geralt in videogame form supervised by the man, Sapkowski himself. CDPR did a stellar job all around. Just a heads up though - If you're the impatient type that tries to rush through games, you're gonna have a bad time. One of my playthroughs that was a sort of completionist run took me roughly 130 hours, and that included reading every book, interacting with every NPC and doing every single side quest plus some grinding at the end to reach the maximum level just for the hell of it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												The Witcher - is one of the few modern (well, almost modern) 3rd person RPGs that really do their job properly. This game is not about levelling your character or killing tons of creatures with one swing of your sword. It's about playing o role - a ROLE playing game. You play as a witcher, a mutant that kills beasts. It's based on famous books series by Andrzej Sapkowski. Since you are a mutant, not every person likes you. More of that, you always have to chose how to behave, whos side to take. It's a first game by polish studio CD Project RED, so it's not brilliant, but you immediately forget about all it's cons when you start playing because a rare game can get you suck a real roleplay experience, such dark fantasy world, where everything is corruted, dark and still people survive and see bright things.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I'm a recent Witcher fan. After watching Angry Joe's video over the Witcher 2, I've been curious over this entire franchise for a while. Last Christmas, my parents got me several of the Witcher novels and my then girlfriend bought me one of the comics in trade. Since then I've loved the franchise, if just for the books alone. This game however, while not as great as the books I've read thus far, is still great and show off the potential the developers have. I haven't played the other Witcher games yet but I'm excited to. While the combat, character models and English voice acting is wonky, the story, world and unique alchemy and daytime system really make this game work. Once you get into this game, you'll begin to trully roleplay as Geralt. You will fully understand why Geralt in the books is written the way he is and you as the player will sympathize with, or in my case agree with, his choices and world view. For those wanting a unique and extremely different fantasy experience, look no further than the agressively, yet lovably, Polish Witcher.

It felt too broken to be worth dealing with anymore.Also, much of the gameplay felt more like chores than fun.  People sending you back and forth across the entire town consecutively for a 30 second piece of dialogue.  It seemed unnecessary and boring.  Other than that, the story was interesting, dice and fighting was fun, and the combat was unique and skillful.  But these factors weren't able to redeem the negatives for me.

												One question, one answer.Should you play this game before the other two or just skip it?Yes, play it, or well, it’s up to you. It will set basis for you knowledge in the universe of The Witcher, and even though it’s a long game (for me 77 hours my first play trough), I felt it was totally worth it, and very rewarding. The game plays different than in The Witcher 2, instead on focusing on skill play, it focuses on tactics like alchemy and oil coating, etc. It may not sound good, but it is pretty fun. Plus the tactical knowledge carries over to the following games, letting you play I higher difficulties than before.The length of the game was in my opinion perfect, it didn’t felt repetitive, or like being obligated to do chores. Heck, I got bored of Alien Isolation halfway through the entire game which only lasted about 15 hours. I just don’t play games for long, still, this is my second most played game of all time, I would never had tough!!!For the price you get all this content, it is just a crime not to get, less than $2 for in sale sure.The only thing you have to get pass to is the gameplay, if you come from The Witcher 2 like me, don’t quit in the introduction because of the combat. Stick with it for a little and you’ll get used to is very soon, as I already say, the gameplay is a little different, but it’s still fun.Thank you CD Projekt for this Masterpiece, I’m a fan of the series now.

content:
Posted: April 21
												For fans of older/classic action RPGs, The Witcher (EE) is a must-play.  I would rank it up  there with KOTOR personally and (not coincidentally, I'm sure) the actual alignment paths you can follow as Geralt are pretty similar: good/Hero, neutral/Witcher, and evil/Wild Hunt  Champion.  It's an old game though so don't expect to be blown away by NPC/enemy  variety.  In fact, I would say that is really the only downside to The Witcher: the limitations  of an old engine which basically builds in a lot of repetitive gameplay.  But the engine is so great for what it is though; a build of Bioware's Aurora engine (Neverwinter Nights' engine) which would act as the foundation for Knights of the Old Republic (I and II).  The story and the character of Geralt, the world you inhabit--a dirty world (uncensored!) that almost benefits from less color depth, kept me so engrossed that I hardly noticed and definitely didn't begrudge The Witcher it's quirks and old age.  It is especially worth playing if you plan to continue the series since you can import your save game and give yourself some cool continuity game-to-game (RIP Bioware trend).  The game is fully voiced and it is full of  dialogue and conversation trees and every interaction has some kind of impact on the overall  game and story.  Read as: this game is chock-full of content.  Take the "risk".  If you need some more assurance, continue reading as I try to address the common detractors.	The "scariest" thing about The Witcher is the combat system but really, it's very streamlined in my opinion and once you understand that it's all about timing and selecting the correct fighting forms (and thus, levelling up the corresponding forms and attributes/talents) it becomes very easy to navigate.  I'll try to break down  the system so you have a slight primer going in: Geralt has two swords; one steel and one silver.  Steel for humans/normal animals and silver for monsters/magical creatures.  PC Master Race so movement is WASD with Q for pulling steel and E for pulling silver, M1 for attack.  Each sword has three forms: strong, fast and group.  Each form has a different animation set and a different effect on enemies.  If you notice you're hitting the crap out of something and it's barely taking damage, change forms (one button press cycles the forms, Q for steel, E for silver) until you start landing blows and doing damage.  Time your M1 clicks with the "firey" sword pointer. STR, DEX, END all correspond to the different forms so when you level up, look at the different talents and you'll see how to buff the strong form, for instance (HINT: it's in the STR tree).  INT is all about your magic abilities (and certain crafting abilities; Bombs and Oils) so levelling up INT will benefit your Signs arsenal, which are offensive/defensive magic "spells" you cast during combat with M2.   Geralt starts with one sign, gets another fairly quickly and then eventually you get five signs that all loosely represent some elemental aspect (air, water, fire, etc).  You cycle through signs by hitting 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  THEN there's Alchemy which isn't really tied to any attribute and depends more on whether you have the recipe--alchemy is all about collecting materials and strong alcohol to use in mixes for cool potions which you can put into quickslots (which you can drink on the fly during combat, very useful).  Potions are all toxic to some degree though so you can't abuse them.   (I didn't even use bombs or sword oil on my playthrough.)	The other thing, the dreaded fetch-quests.  The Witcher's fetch-quests are obviously labelled as "Monster X Contract" with the note of "Must have Monster X  bestiary entry to complete".  They all boil down to: kill X number of monster Y to collect mat Z.  Some are collected as "proof" but most are for alchemy mats.  Early game they are useful because you'll be killing monsters anyway, late game they are entirely skippable although the rewards get better and better as you progress through the game (typically, sometimes it's just gold).  	The game has tons of onscreen information and tips too if I've been too presumptuous... I mean, not everyone grew up playing Dungeons and Dragons I guess.  Roll for initiative!  (Oh yeah, Dice Poker in-game!)

												A solid RPG that features moral choices and an immersive story line. The decisions you make throughout the game have thier consequences which alter the overall ambiance of the game. There are many side quests which you can explore and unlock new equipment along the way. The natural environment, alongside with the NPC interaction, really demonstrate the immersive essence this game has to offer. You can distribute your skills within a huge skill tree with unique abilites that ultimately reflect to your playstyle. Though this game has many great aspects to it. There are some flaws that may seem unappealing to certain individuals. For example, the character models have little to no facial expression and many characters are recycled using the same model, but use different colored clothing. Also, the combat system is somewhat clunky due to the combo mechanics and various types of attack styles. It is quite tricky to get use to it, but overall it could be better. Lastly, the animations and cutscenes in the game seem unnatural and are often obstructed by the natural environment or camera angle.Overall this game has plenty of content that any RPG fan would enjoy and I would recommend this game to any Witcher or RPG fan.

												The Witcher is a captivating series based on a series of Polish books. It took some time for the series to gain momentum, but this games sequel was a resounding success and the third and final game is set to be the greatest game of all time.If you can get past the prologue and the combat system you'll begin to really love this game.I was committed to completing this game and I had a lot of trouble getting started, I nearly gave up on this game at that point. The game has very bad mechanic but it will grow on you with continued use, and these mechanics have divided audiences between both hating the game and loving it. Once you've adapted to these mechanics, you can emerse yourself in the story and you really will love this respectably long game - it will hype you for the sequel and the sequels sequel prior to its release.The decisions made in the game will affect the plot throughout the entire trilogy, so make sure you choose the moral choices you'd actually choose in the situation, otherwise you could play the entire trilogy to a particular moral style.It's one of the longer games I've played and I normally don't really like role playing games, and I would play this again without question.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												It's remarkable, genuinely remarkable to me that the Witcher 3, one of the best RPGs in recent memory, was a continuation of this game. And before I say anything else (because frankly, most of what I can say about this from a critical perspective is negative) I would recommend this game, for two main reasons: first, it's actually got a very intriguing and deep lore behind it, and the gameplay works off that lore, with dozens of enemies that require unique tactics and adaptability to defeat, making the Witcher a game that really rewards you for preparing before wading into a fight. Secondly, the third instalment is an incredible game and playing this through has only enhanced my appreciation for what the third game told me.I had a disk copy of this game for about six years before I bought it on steam, and the only reason I even have it in digital form is that due to a steam offer, buying all three witcher games was bizarrely cheaper than just buying the third one. When I first got it, the game became one of those things you stop playing for about a year, go back to it wondering why you ever stopped playing, and then remember instantly as soon as you start a new game. I'll get the negatives out of the way first: the game is about as unpolished as you can get without being unfinished; awkward voice acting, convoluted character motivations, and a combat system that's faaaar too big for its boots. To name a few instances, I spent far too long on what should have been evenly matched fights because when you enter a new area, enemies are able to react and swarm you about three seconds before you regain control of your character, and with the game's janky collision where the witcher seems more than content to wait for his axe wielding foe to step aside and let him pass rather than his dodge function actually moving him past the enemy, you're virtually unable to escape such situations. Additionally, good luck dealing with situations where you need to use multiple weapon types, since Geralt will be in at least twenty six pieces by the time he's switched weapons.But I'd still recommend this game. Because, while we can take it for granted today with its HD, triple A, fantastically polished descendant at the very top of its game, the Witcher 3 may never have been made without CD Projekt Red having the balls to do something different. And by god was this different. One of the few fantasy worlds where your character feels like both a blank slate on account of his memory loss, giving you the excuse to react to situations in your way, and also like you're a part of the world because of how people react to you because you're a witcher. And yes, I could harp on the combat mechanics for a long long while, but this bizarre, off the wall system paved the way for something beautiful years later. It's the type of game that will entertain you if you have an attachment to the Witcher series because of the books or later games or if you're an RPG fan. If either of those apply to you, I'd give it a try.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I can't make up my mind whether to thumbs up this or thumbs down it. I keep changing my mind.When I first got it. I was shocked by the dreadful controls, the lurchy, awkward, 45 degree granularity camera angles. The strange inability to jump. Being unable to drop off ledges, or drop off an in game height of more than a millimeter. If there is a brick or a pebble or an insect on your path, or just a drunken lardarse blocking a doorway. You're out of luck, you cannot procede. Parkour in this game is absolutely zero, it is totally unforgiving. Forget jumping over gates. You've got to walk 10-20km around to get somewhere 2 inches away.Then after about 30 minutes swearing at the sword controls, wondering why I was completely unable to hit anything, consulting with the controls menu several times, and restarting the game 3 times in case it was some bug, i eventually after much googling found you have to hold the ♥♥♥♥ing button to slash someone. Okay, from then on the game got a little bit easier, but there were still things that were annoying, you don't learn about anything until after you've killed a main character, and that's soo frustrating. The map is completely ♥♥♥♥ing useless. It took me 20-30 minutes and a main character death of the bar maid to work out that there's a second map option. What is the large map even for?! Why was the barmaid i was supposed to escort home refusing to tell me where she lived? Why when i approached her and engaged in dialogue does she say nothing, when all the other characters have indepth dialog trees? The game was growing on me upto this point. But then something terrible happened. I enabled fistfighting powerups. And that totally broke my game. It was completely and totally impossible to throw a punch of any kind, if you did because you had to hold the mouse button to throw the punch, the powerup would come on, preventing you from throwing the punch. God knows how the powerup works, because after dying repeatedly to weaklings in pub fights, i still to this day don't understand how they work. Some clue, would be nice with these things. All i can do is throw pathetic punches at the ground where spotty nerds with no muscels, no life and no fighting ability capitolise on my total inability to do anything but lurch around throwing punches at the ground, unable to get out the way, or do anything really. I mean the fighting is broken anyway, but that just breaks it so you can't even exploit the game bugs to win.With several main characters dead I tried to restart the game off an old game save repeating 6 hours of gameplay because of in game faults. Seriously, you have been warned. Fist fighting powerups are just horribly broken. So I go back and try and save the woman who died due to the game's poor design. That's when it happened again. Yes. And a third time. And a fourth. The game isn't on difficult mode. It's on easy. The problem is control. Control over the character. Control over the camera angles, control over the flow of gameplay, control over upgrades. There is no control. You see some missions happen at night. This woman comes out and needs rescuing at night. Unfortunately it occurs at the exact same time as a different mission you are on which involves glow in the dark dogs to be ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere. So unsurprisely she turns into dog food. I can't work out if there is any way to restore her health, the game is obtuse in that regard, you've got to read the mind of some developer who was smashed on crack when he designed this thing. Because the exhaustive information in the menus are only there to tell you about magic. If you want to actually know how to use the magic, then you're out of luck kiddo, you're best bet is to randomly click on buttons until by chance you the right combinations or you click on something that is fatal to your game's progression and you wont realise you've screwed up until several hours later when some game feature you've been using for hours goes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and malfunctions and you die. Repeatedly. Without knowing why.So now I have to redo the first 6 hours of the first level again. Because some developer somewhere didn't think to disable concurrent missions. In my opinion that is a bug. A serious one. I know of no other game like this that allows concurrent game missions - for exactly this reason. ♥♥♥♥ this. Bad controls. Bad camera angles. Bad design of level and mission structure. No feature to postpone or disable missions. Game breaking skills tree. This game is just there to completely♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. How is it possible to know in advance that you've activated a bad combination of missions? Oh wait you can't. You just have to do missions ONE AT A TIME. String out the entire game for the rest of your life. Get to some point where the game 99% complete and find out that something you altered in the first 10% has broken that final 1%. This is what the game is like. Thanks, but no thanks.And that's the problem with this game. It's a lovely game, and you want to sit down and play it bugs and all because it's such a nearly perfect game and it's immersive and charming. But each and everytime you get into it, some game breaking bug jumps up out of nowhere and nuts you in the balls. Nobody really sat down and thought it out, or tested it, or patched the problems. I don't like giving thumbs down. But some games utterly deserve it. This is one of those games that if you play it, it's just going to make you angry.The reason it makes you so angry is because if it was a bad game you could just walk away, but it isn't a bad game, it's a great game with awful annoying issues that just totally ruin the players enjoyment.I don't want to be angry. I want to relax. Games should always be easy to control and flowing, the difficulty should come from problems that need solving within the game. The game should not be difficult because you have crippling design problems and bugs and controls which decided to go the opposite way to the rest of gaming history.I will probably continue playing this because it's such a charming game, despite the "idiosyncracies", and it definitely does the "je ne sais quoi" which defines a classic life changing game. Who knows maybe it's the awkward control and camera angles and the crazy haphazard mission layout that we love about it...I'll thumbs up I guess. God only knows why...

												This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. I played it just last year, and in spite of the outdated graphical quality, it pretty much blew my mind. And what honestly is the most impressive to me is the soundtracking. I haven't played a game before or since this one that is soundtracked as well. Overall, I'd say 10/10 for anyone who enjoys RPGs, or any kind of fantasy game.

												If you want start playing the Witcher series, but not sure which one to start with, PLAY THIS ONE FIRST. No matter what anyone says, this game is a game not to be missed. (It's like, $2 during a sale anyway)Because I saw The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt coming soon, I decided to start this series. At first I thought, "Oh, I should just start with the second one. This game is too outdated anyway." However I convinced myself to play this game first. So I did. And I'm very glad I did.When the game starts, Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, has mysteriously reappeared from the dead. He was taken into Kaer Morhen, a Witcher stronghold where they guard the secrets of creating a Witcher.After a period of time, Kaer Morhen is attacked by unknown bandits, and the secrets are stolen. It's up to Geralt of Rivia, the famed White Wolf, to retrieve them and take revenge.The game takes place after the end of all the novels of the Witcher novels written by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, so you needn't worry if you hate reading. However, if you love reading like I do, I recommend reading the books too as they add lots of depth and background to the characters. The story is easily the best part of the game. Chapter 1 is really a chore to get through, but at Chapter 2 it starts to pickup, and at Chapter 3 it really starts to get interesting. There are 5 chapters total, with a prologue and epilogue. The game really makes you feel like you're in the world, with some NPCs you pass by calling you a freak and some you used to know surprised of your revival. The voice acting is superb. Most choices in the game have great impact, and you have 2 sides to choose from, or neutral. (I recommend the neutral path cause it's more true to the novel Geralt) The devs don't lie when they say, "NO GOOD AND NO EVIL - ONLY CHOICES AND CONSEQUENCES." The game is pretty long too; I skipped all of the notice board quests and did a large amount of sidequests (I got all the cards too...) and I clocked in at around 30 hours. If you weren't rushing like I was, or a completionist you may clock in at even more hours, like 50. The amount of content in the game is pretty large.For graphics, there's not much to say. This game is fairly old now, but it doesn't look TOO bad. Just don't look at the later games, cause the devs really went leaps and bounds on the graphics. Personally, I thought they were bearable, but if you just finished playing a more modern game, you're eyes might get sore.Now the gameplay. The reason that made this game get mixed reviews from critics, I'd say. The combat isn't your typically hack and slash. Instead, you attack and wait for Geralt to do some moves, and then attack again and specific intervals. This system is extremely clunky and annoying, and there were many unnecessary difficulties and frustrations. By the end of Chapter 2 though, I would bet you would get used to it by then. I didn't viciously HATE the system like some, but I definitely disliked it a fair bit. I thought it's less of a glorified quicktime event as many say, but more of like a "automated hack and slash". Regarding music, I think this game's soundtrack is pretty good. I even enjoy listening to it when studying or whatever else. I really love it when games have excellent music. It wasn't a masterpeice as say, The Legend of Zelda's soundtrack, and some tracks get repetitive, but some others like Vizima Trade Quarter and Chapter 3 Inn music really stood out for me. And hearing it's "main theme" in the Witcher 3 trailers gets me pumped. All in all, I really recommend this game.I cannot emphasize enough though, play this one first. Pick it up, and play through chapter 1 and a bit of 2. If you can't play it anymore cause you don't like it, I won't judge. But don't let this one pass by without at least a look.7/10, for outdated nuisances (like loading screen immersion breaks, lack of the ability to jump, subpar graphics by today's standards and invisible walls), a really bad combat system, and a painful, hard to get into beginning.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												It's not as flashy as the later games and might not have the same widespread appeal, but if you're a fan of the sequels, or just want an old-school yet approachable RPG to spend several dozen hours with, The Witcher is definitely worth considering.It's starting to show its age, and it was never a very big-budget game to begin with, but for a 2007 game running on a 2002 engine it's more than presentable.I'd say I did the majority of stuff there is to do, and the game took me 40 or so hours to beat. There's certainly replay value with the choices and leveling.The Witcher conveys the sense of "monster hunting" better than either of its sequels. The creatures are straight out of folklore as opposed to common fantasy, and the requirement of having to read books and learn about your targets is something you don't see in games very much at all.The potion system is still incredible.Combat is pretty much passive and I'd recommend playing on hard.The tone is markedly different from the later games. There's certainly gray morality, but it's not exaggerated as much, and feels more "organic," in a way. The story has a really unique feel, combining the feeling of a classical epic with subtle social commentary which the later games focus on more.Some of the dialogue, cutscenes, and such is silly, and I wouldn't call it a classic, but The Witcher is a great game and a very worthy start to the series. If you haven't done so, check it out.
