number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												This review comes from me having played this when it came out in 2007, and beaten twice so my Steam hours don't do it justice.__________________________________________________________________________________________If you had ever played a role-playing game before The Witcher came out, chances are that most of the game involved people asking you to go places, deliver items, and kill things. Then this little beauty was born.After the Witcher 3 came out and caught everybody's attention, many people who haven't played the series end up asking the question "should I play the first two games in the series?". Inevitably, many people will recommend playing The Witcher 2: a great game with solid controls and outstanding visuals. And what visuals they were, able to bring the gaming rigs (at the time) to their knees. While I'd agree with all of that, I'd also add that everyone should play the first game, because I found it to be one of the best RPGs of all time. It is, through and through, a true RPG. One that focuses on choice and the resulting consequence, rather than character building etc.Usually in every conversation I have regarding The Witcher, someone always admits to quitting, usually due to the unique fighting mechanics or during the game's extensive swamp section. But because The Witcher is structured linearly, and it seems as though it was built that way, it results in a game that constantly gets better as the story progresses. The second act improves upon the first, the third improves upon the second and so on and so forth. Despite the game's initial awkwardness, it becomes apparent to the player that things are picking up and where a certain brilliance can be felt in the story. But it's the fourth act where the crescendo really occurs and is that which really makes The Witcher what it is, what it's meant to be. Every moment in the act is interconnected in some way. Every character seems to have a relationship with every other character. And each character has a little quest for you, which in turn will all lead back to the original quest. It's a beautiful thing really. Alina and Julian are getting married, but Alina's taking care of Alvin, who leads you to the local hermit, who takes you back to the Lady of the Lake, who wants you to kill a monster in a particular way, and on it goes.The thing about these quests is that they are different in regards to other RPGs. Tasked with killing things in order to obtain items is fine, but it's a simple approach to a more full-filling one that these side quests can offer. The Witcher recognises that these games aren't so much about the skills players choose, but the choices you make. Each choice leads to a different outcome. And these choices are generally based off the player's view on matters, or how they feel, which makes the whole experience that much more authentic.Of course The Witcher is not unique in this regard, but it can certainly serve as a more refreshing approach to how RPGs should be made. Convincing a ghost that she is, in fact, a ghost so as to help her pass on to the afterlife is not a quest that would be present in many games. Nor would a quest, such as the aforementioned, end with the main character participating in a poetic duel with a bard. The Witcher isn't the most beautiful game, with its wonky animations and the odd poor texture here and there, making it incomparable to its successor The Witcher 2. The more I played, however, the more I found myself sucked in. You end up learning that ignoring side quests is not an option. You just have to see more, play more, experience more. The Witcher shows us that there can be more to RPGs than just fighting.I, personally, thoroughly enjoyed the underlying themes in certain parts of the game.Act IV explores the different topics present in its story through the actions taken by the NPCs and the player. Two species with two different sides to the story. A ghost who isn't so much evil as it is misguided, and even in death it loves gambling so much that it tries to gamble for a human life. The monsters themselves seem to embody failed loves and desires. So much seems to be going on and somehow, through all the intricacy of the narrative, the clever role-playing ideas of the initial parts of the game are brought together in Act IV to form a cohesive statement about love and other things. Laying it all out, dissecting it, and examining it, resulting in a culmination of understanding. So go ahead, do yourself a favour and pick it back up if you haven't already. Beat the game, and possibly end up having one of the best roleplaying experiences of your life. From Act IV onward. Or not. I don't mind.Update 3/12/2016: I've just discovered the OST and Inspired by soundtrack that come with the game. Seriously, such value for money. When on sale, it's $1.50. Outstanding.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												The first Witcher is a game which differs from Witcher 2 or 3 very much. First of all: combat relies on sequences of attacks which needs pressing the mouse button in the correct time. I understand that some people might not like it, I liked it very much, especially when you unlock more sequences, fights can get quite spectacular. The skill tree is also different comparing to Witcher 2. Every level in experience grants you some skill points which you can assign to strenght, durability, Aard, Igni (sort of magic spells) or to some of the combat styles. There is quite amount of sidequests to complete, maybe not a lot, but still quite a few. They are fun, but some requires bactracking which can be boring. Still, the story is very nice and your decisions have an impact in the future events. Soundtrack is astonishing, in my opinion way better that in the Witcher 2. It really lets you feel the atmosphere of poor countrysides, filthy city or the horrific tombs. I do not know how well english voice actors did theirs jobs, but in the polish version of the game they did suprisingly well.Although I think that characters are quite interesting they do not have much to say so they do not stand out from the rest of the NPCs. I noticed some minor graphics bugs but nothing too serious. To sum up, i think that The Witcher is a very good game with great plot, music and combat system, but it is specific type of game and I will understand a person who will not agree with me.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This has one of the slowest starts I've ever seen in an RPG game, first of all the game begins with terrible combat, an uninteresting story, and sketchy graphics. Everytime you move there's another cutscene or jump to boring dialog. This wraps up in an hour or two however and then the game really opens up. Eventually you get used to the combat and it starts improving as you unlock new skills and weapons, the main storyline still feels pretty irrelevant but there's a huge amount of side content to keep you busy. It does start out as one of the worst games I've played for a while and almost prompted me to uninstall it, however after sticking through it, I now think it's one of the best games to come out in recent years.

Product received for free
												This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. I played it just last year, and in spite of the outdated graphical quality, it pretty much blew my mind. It took me roughly forty hours to finish the game (and I left out maybe a third of the side-quests) and it was a forty hours well-spent. Not only is it a fully compelling story, the characters are well-developed and fleshed-out throughout. The gameplay is remiscent of Dragon Age-meets-rhythm-game, but it works incredibly well. And what honestly is the most impressive to me is the soundtracking. I haven't played a game before or since this one that is soundtracked as well. Overall, I'd say 10/10 for anyone who enjoys RPGs, or any kind of fantasy game.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I'll keep this short and sweet because I think the majority of people that played The Witcher did so in order to get some backstory for preperation for The Witcher 2 & 3, thats just how I feel about it because I suppose thats the purpose of my playthrough because what it comes down to is the game alone isn't very delightful on its own but its not terrible either. I suggest playing it before going at The Witcher 2 so you have an idea of whats going on, plus it will make The Witcher two more enjoyable.The Witcher is a great RPG with anywhere from 50-80 hours of gameplay depending on how you want to take it along with choices to make that effect the story down the road and the game doesn't hold your hand. Minus chapters 2 and 3 (due to their watered down quests that seem to go on forever and the boring environments) out of 5 chapters along with a Prologue and a Epilogue the game is pretty fun and entertaining. Combat in the game turns off a lot of people right off the bat, I say give it a chance because once you get used to it you'll feel more intune to the way it works and you possibly may even enjoy it. For those who want to take on the hard difficulty, prepare to possibly rage due to a few boss fights and a few other silly encounters that are just plain unfair, unfourtunatly. The voice acting in the game is decent but often times laughable and the animations minus some of the combat animations are just plain silly. Character models are reused frequently as well throughout the game which was just plain lazy. All in all I'd say pick this one up even if its for a quick runthrough if you are planning on playing The Witcher 2 and 3.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												I had a great time with The Witcher. It's a game that I was always going to love, being a fantasy role playing game with a satisfying world and a LOT to do. It reminded me of Dragon Age: Origins, albeit with adult themes (the player is encouraged to have sex with pretty much every female character they meet) and a unique fighting system (which involves stringing together really impressive sword movements to take on both monsters and human opponents).It should be noted that The Witcher isn't a perfect game. The story is highly praised, but the "decisions" I was given along the way didn't always impact proceedings as much as I thought they would. There are also parts of the game where I felt the story was being forced forward, and I was becoming a bit of a passenger. My only other negative comment is that I was so overpowered by Chapter V that no enemy could possibly hurt me, making combat very predictable.Despite these flaws, I found myself totally sucked into The Witcher's world. The visuals are jaw dropping, particularly those sunsets near bodies of water, and the romantic storyline somewhat satisfying. Being a completist, i was determined to complete every side quest, stretching my play time out to close to 60 hours. A sign of how much I enjoyed that commitment is that I'm super keen to jump straight into The Witcher 2. I've heard it's even better, so who knows, perhaps Morrowind and Baldur's Gate II will finally have a challenger in the fantasy RPG genre. Time will tell...

content:
Posted: January 13
												WARNING:  OPINIONS ON THE INTERENET ARE FREE TO COMMENT! DON'T LIKE WHAT I HAVE TO SAY? DON'T READ IT.Alright where to begin.  First off the controls.  Geralt is hard to manuevre and control, this is most prevelent in combat, where it could take a long time between when the button is pressed and when the sword is swung.  This type of unresponsive control make me furious.  I don't want instant gratification, but reliable combat tactics.  Next, healing.  Healing during combat is impractical and a waste of time.  As you first need to select the item, and then watch Geralt drink the potion, all the while taking enemy hits, they won't for you.  The healing is also slow, and you can die before your potion finishes healing you.  Let's put it like this, when Dark Souls is considered fair compared to this; you know you have a design flaw.  This doesn't upset me, surprisingly.  This was CD Project Reds first game, they wanted to make a game world like the books of the Witcher, and succeeded.  But they didn't think about about what there mechanics stated to the player, that was their f&@# up.  Now they have since apologized for this misgrievence (in my opinion) with the other titles they have released in this trilogy.  If you want an example of bad top down design this is it right here and by all means play it for that.  But this really isn't worth it unless you want a headache.

												I first purchsed The Witcher about three years ago and gave it an honest go. I was not impressed. When it became available on Steam, I decided to once again give it a shot... I was once again disappointed. I have tried at least a dozen different times to get into this game - or to get any enjoyment out of it at all, really. However, over the many hours I have devoted to this game, I can honestly say that I have never had a single moment where I even began to like any part of it.I really wanted to get into this game (because of all the praise that seems to be constantly showered upon it), and I really did give it the best possible chance(s) that anyone could expect... But The Witcher is without a doubt one of the worst games I have ever had the unpleasant experience of playing. Every aspect of the game: Gameplay, Storyline, voice acting, etc., I found to be repugnant. The only recommendation I can offer is this: Do not get this game. Save yourself the disappointment that I had to endure every time I launched the game.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Pros:- Engaging story with non-obvious plot twists.- Excellent voice acting.- Choice-based story consequences.- Long adventure.- Good mix of spells/swords/crafting to keep you entertained.- Additional adventures included by devs and fans that add backstory. Neutral: - No controller support. - Ok background music.-Your decisions not only impact the story, but some lore-important side-quests will be closed off to you depending on what you choose to do/who you do or do not randomly run into in the cities.  There's no real way to experience all the quests without looking online the first time you play.  Some people may like this, but I don't feel this game merits a second play through just to pick up the remaining quests that complete the background lore.  There's often no warning you are completing a main-quest segment and will be leaving the area either, making it double challenging to find all the side-quests yourself.Cons:- Quite unstable for me on Windows 10.  It took me 5 in-game hours and many tweaks to get the crashing down from once every 20 mins to once every couple hours.  They should really re-think the two-hour return limit.- Many glitches and bugs.  There were times a character would try to hand me an important quest item, but my inventory was full, so the item just disappeared from the game.  The last chapter is totally unpolished and many of the mechanics don't work normally at the end of the game.  Several randomly bugged character textures as well, making me think a disfigured monster was attacking when it was actually a book merchant. - The swordplay is based around timed clicking.  This worked ok for Legend of Dragoon, but for an action RPG it feels a little silly.- The cities would often drop down to less than 30 fps in crowded areas, despite using far better hardware than was available when this game came out (using an i5 4590 and an R9 390).- The country-side part of the world feels big and empty, almost like this was supposed to be some kind of MMO but is void of life.- Some weapons and ability upgrades are not spaced out well and come FAR too late into the game so that most of them are pointless.- If you don't do things in the order the game was expecting, it can get confused and your journal will tell you to go somewhere that isn't where you are supposed to go.  The game catches up eventually when you pass certain checkpoints, but the story feels out of order and you wind up feeling like you are missing something.Conclusions: I view a "thumbs up" as saying this game is worth paying full price for.  If you want to play this game for the full Witcher experience, wait until it is on sale.  I view this game as skippable in the series.  Obviously I trudged through and I enjoyed the story, but the game was a mess to play with few solutions to common problems, and it single-handedly convinced me the refund window needs to be lengthened.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												After hearing such good things about The Witcher III, I decided to finally finish a full playthrough of the earlier games before starting in on the third, but I guess it took at least one iteration of Witcher games for CD Projekt Red to actually figure out how to make a functioning game, because The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a pile of beta-stage crap.- Half of the "innovative" combat features are pointless and often do not work at all. Parrying, bleeding, precise hits, etc. are nothing more than behind the scenes numbers that offer nothing to enrich tedious combat (which consists of absolutely nothing more than swing format A, B or C). Dodging is slower than simply turning around and moving forward, and often enough Geralt is simply not allowed to dogde at all, for seemingly arbitrary reasons. When moving any other direction But forward, Geralt moves like an arthritis-wracked stump, lurching and dragging himself to his death (This gets worse when intoxicated, which is amusing because the game encourages drunk fighting via particular talents). Geralt will frequently refuse any input, disallowing motion, signs, combat, anything. Hit recognition seems to have been abandoned halfway through development, allowing Geralt to be hit across rooms, while opponents spend minutes at a time dodging every single combat style Geralt is allowed, even when knocked down or stunned.- A large amount of talents serve little to no purpose at all, only being taken because of the poorly conceived level system shoving enough talents in your face to unlock literally everything in almost no time at all. So much for strategic specialization. The same goes for potion-brewing, where even on the highest difficulty, where "potions are necessary" the lore-based toxicity system means you will use the same three (out of a few dozen) potions the entire game. The same goes for signs, with nothing past your first unlocked sign being of any use at all. All signs will often have no effect whatsoever, and no explanation is given as to why, not to mention arbitrarily "failing" every few attempts, and not being cast at all.- Sub-quests are the same tedious gather and kill quests RPG players have been tired of for years. Inventory is even more menial, being filled with dozens of random item variations (no doubt meant to be exotic, but instead are just a bother). You're forced to keep everything in order to satisfy the insanely random whims of NPCs desiring particular gifts, but are offered exactly zero in-game functions to track the inane demands of the masses.- Progression consists of new areas filled with old enemies, recolored and renamed. For being a monster-hunter, in a world that is, according to the story, more filled with monsters than ever, there are no more than about 12 species of monster in the entire game.To contrast what Projekt Red brags that their game is:"Enhanced inventory" forces collection to satisfy obscure quests, and storing items in the inn forces you to complete a quantity slider for every single item withdrawn. Red boasts superior item organiztion, but inn storage has absolutely no management options, and does not sort item categories at all, giving you a jumbled, small-fonted mess."Technical improvements" that list combat responsiveness improvements make me shudder to think how slow the game was beforehand. Input lag for signs and dodging is so long that it makes them liabilities in combat as opposed to boons."Character differentiation system" is a cute, bashful way of asking players if it's okay that they don't make new models, because this new enemy is two shades darker than the monster you fought last chapter, and that ♥♥♥♥♥s skirt is blue instead of green."Choose from over 250 special abilities" there are 226 talents, many of which are, as mentioned above, obselete. If you're going to blatantly lie in your bragging, at least make sure what you Did manage to cobble together is at least worth a damn.Later Witcher games might be good, I couldn't say. But skip this one and read a summary, because all playing this game is going to do is put you off the series by being a really garbage game.

number of helpful: 144 of 283 people (51%) found this review helpful42 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
The Witcher ManBefore I begin, let me make a couple of things clear:I have not read the books, and this is not a book review. I'm also not here to make comparisons between the games and books. This is a game review only.If I could give this game a rating between thumbs up and thumbs down... say, like, a fist... I would do that, because my opinion is very mixed. But since I have more negative things to say than positive, I have to give it a thumbs down.I'm not out to "get" you if you enjoy this game, and what makes the world go 'round are differences in opinions. Do not take my criticisms as personal attacks on you and understand that reviews are opinions, and nothing will make me reassess mine. If you want to yell at me about my opinion and tell me how wrong I am and that I'm just some "simpleton", understand that nothing is going to change my mind, so you're only wasting your own time. This review is based on my own experiences with the game and how I reacted to it. Know that not everyone will experience a game the same way.What I liked about the game:1) In The Witcher, there are some pretty decent RPG elements. I like the leveling system, for one. I enjoy the fact that Strength, Dexterity, Endurance, and Intelligence have their own trees to pick from, and that you can also level up your weapons.2) The characters are amusing. Well, the male ones, anyway. The female ones are just sex dispensers with legs. I’ll get to that later.3) I love the alchemy. The starting potions are very “meh” but later you can craft much better ones and be practically unkillable. I also love picking up herbs to craft potions.4) The game on normal is just that: normal. Some games I’ve played on normal (especially fantasy RPGs) seem like the developers misunderstood what “normal” difficulty means.5) The brawling. It's stupid easy to do, so you can make some pretty decent cash off of it.6) I love the music. It fits a fantasy setting perfectly.7) The graphics in the Enhanced Edition are lovely and colorful, especially on the high graphics setting (Although it does seem to have a lot of stuttering and optimization issues).8) The gloomy, rainy weather.What I didn't like about the game:1) The dialogue is very dragging and leaves something to be desired. I'm all for story and role-playing, and I know this game was a book first, but there is a lot of talking, and much of the game's length is padded by it. What the characters sometimes say is very pretentious at times, and at other times, it tries too hard to be “edgy” by making everyone cuss all the time. I have nothing against swearing-- I swear like a sailor in real life-- but I don't do it half as much as this game did. You know that one kid in school who just learned to swear and thinks it’s the greatest thing ever? Yeah. That’s this game’s dialogue. And target audience.2) Female characters almost always have one of two purposes, or at times, both: to be rescued, or to be boned. No matter who the woman is, she will throw herself on Geralt (or whom I love to call "Greyalt") at the opportunity to screw him. I once talked to some elf girl who said she could teach me her language. “Cool!” I thought. “I want to learn elf language! That might come in handy for my character!” Next thing I know, her half-naked trading card flashes me out of nowhere and we’re screwing each other (or gelling together in the background, at least). What the hell? I wanted to learn elvish! I didn’t want to screw her! Then she wandered off and I never saw her again. Great. Pointless. Thank you for wasting my time. Many encounters I had with women were purely accidental out of my desire for completing all of the quests in the game.Despite this complaint, it is really good for a laugh seeing just how hard they were trying to up the sexiness of the game. People say the weirdest sexual things at really odd, inopportune moments, and it’s over-the-top, cheesy as all get out and hilarious. For example: "I can conjure up ♥♥♥♥♥♥s". Who says that, even if you are a sorceress?3) The combat. Yeah, you knew this was coming. This is the most common complaint about The Witcher, and it is 100% justified. It's extremely boring. Click. Wait for the cursor to turn orange. Click. Wait for it to turn orange again. Click. Again. Again. Again. It’s not that it’s hard, or complicated. It’s tedious and puts me to sleep. I have yet to try out Witcher 2, and I pray the combat is nothing like this one. One of the more tedious things about it is switching weapons for different enemies and situations, and how long it takes for him to pull out the next weapon. The game has to register that you made the change, so while you're waiting for Greyalt to pull out his other sword, you're standing there getting pummeled.4) There are no faster means of travel, and the maps are huge. This isn’t too big of a complaint, because I love massive environments. However, I still would have liked a mount of some kind to make it a little quicker.5) The quest tracking is a great feature, but sometimes it’s just plain wrong. It’ll tell you where a character might be rather than where they currently are.6) Those sub-weapons. They’re useless. Except the torch. I love the torch.7) The Signs aren’t good enough for me. Never used them, and I still completed the game just fine without them.8) Fetch quests. I eventually avoided taking contracts. I made money punching people instead. This didn't change the game's plot at all.9) Greyalt is a lousy protagonist. He’s a sarcastic♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that is always looking to start fights. I get that he’s supposed to be a “tough guy” or whatever, but he doesn’t seem to like or get along with anyone unless they open their legs for him. He talks in this really annoying Batman voice and never smiles. He's too busy brooding about which woman to be with.10) This contains semi-spoilers: Alvin (who I call "The Chipmunk"). There was no point to his existence other than to hook you up with one of two women and to pad the game with even more dialogue. You waste so much time playing around with this little runt, and nothing (interesting) ever comes of it. When the game came to its conclusion, I hadn't seen him for two chapters, and he never showed up again. It's possible that your connection with him is based on the path you chose... but should that really matter?11) Greyalt’s “amnesia” is conveniently gone when the plot calls for it.12) Drowners.Biggest Disappointment:This conclusion contains spoilersI have two: the romance elements, and Rayla.Simply put, Rayla was the only female character in the game I actually liked. However, she is never a romance option for you. Well, you can bone her once. But that doesn’t mean a thing. Because she dies immediately after. Twice. First by what’s-his-elfin’-name, and again by you, and you have no choice in this matter. The game saddles you with two possible perma-romance options: Shani (who I call "Yawni") and Triss ("Twits"). I didn’t like Yawni or Twits very much, but because I wanted to give Alvin a place to stay, I figured “here, Yawni, you take him. He’d be better off with you than Twits, who I swear is a psycho in disguise.” Yawni immediately attaches herself to you, even if you don’t want it, and begins to tell you she loves you and pretty much asks you straight up to marry her and have a little family with her. Um, holy crap? I didn’t want this. It seemed like the game refused to move forward unless you settled down with one of them. Well, I didn't like either of them. I called Yawni my "friend" and went about my business. Take that, game.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												The Witcher is an amazing RPG that features some of the best storytelling and decision making I have ever seen. Everything decision, whether through actions or dialogue, carry weight and actively change the world around you. The game takes around 35-45 hours to complete, depending on how many side quests you do. There is a large amount of content in the game and warrants several playthroughs to see how different decisions change the course of the game. There are only two minor complaints that I have in this wonderful game. The first is the combat, while engaging, tended to be either a bit buggy or laggy, one of the two. The second complaint is a very minor complaint and partially is my fault for I have a short attention span. Some of the areas require a long walk to get from eachother, and you have to go back and forth quite a few times. I started to get bored of the long walks. Overall, the game is a very indepth RPG that defiently warrants several playthroughs. I highly recommend The Witcher to anyone who is a fan of RPGs.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												The Witcher is a rich RPG with a deep storyline and an old school styled combat mechanic in the style of KOTOR. I heared great things about this game for years I regret not playing it sooner. Geralt is a mysterious figure who's past is un certain, he's a member of a group of mutants called Witchers. Witchers are former humans who take mutagens to enhance their senses and fighting abilities. A Witcher is essentially a monster hunter who takes contracts to gain money. In the age that the game is set there are only a handful of Witchers left in the world and they are threatend by a force tha wants to destroy their way of life. This game forces you to make tough decisions and pulls ou into a murky world of politics every decision you make could have consequnces for Geralt down the road.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The Witcher is a RPG game set in a dark fantasy universe. The atmosphere resembles the dark middle ages, where poverty, war and disease has struck down on the denizens of this world.You are Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher who is both respected and despised for his line of work. Your profession is to dispose of creatures of the dark, demons and foul creatures by means of spell, sword and alchemy.However, in the beginning of the game you are struck by amnesia and thus your past is unknown to you. This is a central plot in the game, as you will carve your own destiney in the god-forsaken universe of the Witcher. Choosing between right and wrong is difficult, if not impossible, as every decision you make will depend on your own moral code. There are no heroes, no real villains, as everyone is fighting for themselves and characters are thus "grey" - they all contain classically noble character traits and "evil" traits. Consequently, the demons you are sent to kill can appear more humane than the village priest who would rather have you kill seemingly innocent people. The game is highly recommendable, despite its now outdated graphics. The quality of the game experience is enjoyable, and several replays is almost inevitable if you want to know what would have happened if you just had sided with the other faction.. or none at all.

												The Good: "The Witcher" has a detailed story, characters and environments, leaving you to explore your way through the game; The soundtrack is spot on and immersive, the artwork is beautiful and the game world feels alive and vibrant. The potion crafting and the minigames are a nice touch too.The Bad: Dull combat and awkward UI/movement interactions. the English voice acting lacks of any kind of enthusiasm.Recommended for fans of "The Witcher" book series, or if you are looking for a mature, slow burn RPG and you're willing to overlook the clumsy fighting system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												You are Witcher Gerry.You're peely-wally, scarred and can't remember jack♥♥♥♥♥♥but you have a gravelly voice and uber powers so it's okay. That's right folks, you get to play this brilliant RPG as a monster-slaying mutant. There's freaky powers such as force-push (but called something else to avoid a lawsuit) and the ever useful lets-set-everything-on-fire-with-my-mind power.If that weren't enought fun, you travel the lands wielding two swords (because one would just be average). A normal sword for slicing up men/women/children/dogs/hobos/justaboutanyoneyoucanthinkof and then there's your silver sword for all the monsters that want to eat you. The fighting system is a helluva lot of fun and very simple to use - it works on the basis of timing mouse clicks. Get it right and witness some awesome ballet of the lethal form, get it wrong and watch as a giant man-eating plant starts munching on your pale corpse.Story's excellent too and it's nice to see a RPG that isn't afraid to be for adults. When Gerry's not slaying monsters, gambling with dice, or boxing fat people, he's chasing every bit of skirt he can find.BUT NEVER FEAR! Our witcher is sterile and immune to all diseases, so no worries about pregnancies or STIs.It's not all blood and boobs, there are the game hangups that can frustrate you whilst you wait for it to sort itself. There's also only about 8 voice actors (I swear one of which narrates the tv show "How it's made") and just as few NPC models - hint, every merchant is the big fat guy with the hat.Still, a great game that'll have to raiding tombs and knickers (but never at the same time!Game on!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2011
												A dark, gothic, action RPG that is neck-deep in story. The action is flashy, however combat controls are obtuse; and when those clunky controls are paired with nearly brain-dead AI the action is underwhelming. The CRPG elements (item hoarding, inventory management, skill upgrades, etc) are very classic in nature - which is a hate-it or love-it affair. Likewise the presentation is something players will either hate or love - being a Central European RPG the story begins in medias res, there is a ton of dialogue, and the supporting characters are mostly ordinary folk with fairly rich back stories (as opposed to typical JRPGs which start "at the beginning" of a story, include minimal dialogue, and include flashy but hollow characters). The only issues holding this game back are the bugs and how poorly it performs (given its fairly dated graphics).

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												This game is worth playing.  The combat system is very wonky but once you get the hang of it, it isn't so bad at all, and the story is very good.  Also the choices you make in this game carry over to 2nd game.Act I, III and IV move along quite well.  Act II, V and Epilogue seem to drag on.  The alchemy system is a bit confusing but the game tells you what you can make so it isn't too bad.  Level up Igni a lot, it is very powerful, maybe a bit too powerful.  To answer the question:  Is it worth playing this game or should I just skip to the 2nd game?  The short answer: Yes, play this game!  The long answer: if you are a roleplaying enthusit you will enjoy the many nuances the game has to offer, also Geralt's sense of humor is amazing!  The game is a long one, I clocked over 50 hours on it.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												This game was a great game to play, a challenge even. Though this game is quite challenging at times, that only makes the end even more satisfying. Some parts of the game are quite unfair so preparing for missions takes just as long (or longer) whether that's finding the ingredients for the potion or helping someone out so they trust you, this game isn't just a time-spender, it's a second job (not in a bad way). The story is great and it doesn't just give you all the answers, it might even stop tracking a quest, leaving you with but a hint of what to do, so make sure you're connected to the internet because you'll be looking up answers a lot (if you want to). One of the few downsides of this game is it's hard to progress, I went through the whole game with the starting equipment because by the time you have enough money (without doing bounties and side-quests) you're in another area that doesn't sell the item you save up for! The other big problem is the fight styles, they add a great strategy feel to the game but when you're surrounded by tough enemies, you're dead, the same goes for fast-hitting enemies, because you can't block and you're surrounded, you cant do anything, attack? they interrupt, run? you're surrounded, block? you can't, even more reason to be prepared and upgrade your push spell and bring a few (hundered) health potions. Overall the story will drag you in, you'll die quite a bit on the easiest difficulty, and you'll love every second!      8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4
												Just finished playing this game, and it was quite a journey. I got gifted Witcher III as a Christmas present from my friends, but I felt I should play the first two iterations before doing so and so far I don't regret it.While the game has aged, it's not ugly looking in my opinion and although I had some issues with the game crashing and freezing occassionally, I think it might've been due to something on my end.As a master of getting distracted from the main quests and losing myself in side quests, I was quite happy to see that there was plenty of those. Some of them were kind of mundane (fetch me 10 of these and I'll pay you kind of quests), but since I'm always a greedy hoarder when playing these types of games, I was quite happy to do as many as possible.Things that got tedious after a while was all the running around. I really wanted a horse or some sort of transportation means that didn't mean having to run from point A to B. You could teleport between some areas, but not as many as I had wished for. Oh well, I'm lazy.I felt that the battle mechanics and the potions/blade coatings and magic opened up for some interesting fighting possibilties. However, since I am me, I just ran in circles and threw fireballs at everything and then wacked them in the head with the appropriate (sometimes) sword. It worked out quite fine in the end.A lot of interesting moral choices had to be made while playing this game. Some of these choices caused some NPCs to stop talking to you, while others berated you but was still willing to do business with you. It was intersting that not everything was black or white and that it could be quite tricky to figure out which choice might be the "best". Just to be clear, there are no best choice, just less bad ones.In conclusion, I feel that is was a good game and one that I would recommend to anyone interested in the Witcher's series to play. Yes, it's old so the graphics aren't up to snuff, the fighting mechanics felt a bit clunky at times, and there were some parts I had to play over as things didn't always work as they should (if this should happen to you - Google is your friend). I did like the story though and I look forward to playing The Witcher II now (although I've heard it's not as good as the first one, we'll see).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The graphics are terrible by today's standards, the narration is very unemotional, the combat is ok, and there was a mass of crashing issues, but I could not stop playing this masterpiece. This was CDPR's first game ever, I even heard that they didn't know how to make a game when they decided to start this process, but somehow they nailed almost every aspect of the game. This game will probably seem crappy to those who came here from The Witcher 3, but as many have said, over the course of this franchise, the games have improved in almost every aspect. There is plenty of stuff to do in this game. You are introduced to new sections of the world after you complete a chapter, but sadly you cannot go back during the next chapter of the game. I thought I would just slash away like in Skyrim, but CDPR made combat very smart and it requires thinking. You have potions, bombs, armor, signs, and many weapons to get you through the story. The main and side quests dont feel like the 'go here and kill this for some $$$' type of quests they have stories and rewards and they are engaging. I wasn't distracted by the graphics because the atmosphere of the game was so great. You are a witcher and people hate you, but they will pay you to do their bidding. The standards have been raised a lot since this game was released 9 years ago, but if you can, play this masterpiece before the Witcher 2 and 3, and you will love it.(if you go to the game location, you can find all the soundtracks, vlogs of making the movie world maps, etc)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												The game makes a great and mostly efficient effort at immersion, especially in OTS camera mode, and it's greatly appreciated.However, it all tends to get wrecked by how poorly the quests' parallel timelines are handled: nothing prevents you from advancing in the "wrong" order, but the game often can't deal with you coming at an event from a different angle, and you can quite easily find yourself trecking up a questline backwards, or triggering two or three cinematic scenes at once because you're "catching up" with how far you advanced the other related quests before reaching that trigger zone.A couple of hints for that:1) If a fight seems difficult => you're doing it wrong. You're not supposed to be there, or you missed an environment clue to help with the fight.2) When investigating Salamandra in Vizima => go back and visit the detective's house often, as soon as you get any new developement in any other quest, even minimal…Another point that annoyed me, but it may be nothing to you: the game gets disturbingly sexist, esp in Chapter 3 which deals with Geralt's personal life.The "all named female characters can be swooned by the mere appearance of Hero" I could deal with - F9 is your friend -  but the systematic tone and direction of "Aaah, these damn women, they're unreliable, demanding, unappreciative and impossible to understand, but do we love screwing them!" seriously got on my nerves after a while. =.=Not to mention the infamous catfight rule: 2 women in the same storyline? They're going to be jerks to each other and fight for the attention of whatever man is in the middle". Meh, come on game this is painfully childish. At its worst it felt like the story had been written for - and BY - frustrated teenage boys who watch too much bad TV. :|Yet when all that is said and done, I do recommend that game. I loved more aspects of it than the bad ones annoyed me, and I'm definitely going to replay in hard mode to get the best of it. :)I love the fighting mechanics, even though they may seem a bit… aged if you play the more recent famous titles, but they're clean and easy to master, making the game much more entertaining than stressful for fragile hearts like mine. i only scare-jumped ONCE, and it was my fault for forgetting I wasn't paused when I turned and - Hi, ghoul slashing my face. :<

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												If you played Witcher 2/3 and wondering if this game is worth checking out, I say yes if you were big into the stories of those games. I played 2 and 3 first and was very surprised first of all by how ambitious the story of this older game is, but also by how much continuity there is between all three games. If you played 2/3, you probably followed along the story just fine, but you missed more than you think if you haven't played this game. And again, the story of this game is just as ambitious as its successors, even if the game itself is pretty rough around the edges.As far as the gameplay, the combat bears little resemblance to its sequels, while the quest format felt surprisingly similar to Witcher 3. I think Witcher 3 is the game they wished they could have made in 2007, if CDPR had the tech and resources back then. But I must be clear about one thing: "clunky" isn't even a good descriptor for this game's combat system. The combat in this game straight up sucks. It's as idiotic as it is frustrating. However in my view it is worth putting up with if you were a fan of Witcher 2/3's stories or just a fan of story-driven games in general.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Surprisingly beautiful for a game this old. The combat system is a bit wonky but you do get used to it after a while and it's fun to make a few mouse clicks and watch Geralt slice and dice like a maniac. I got a lot of good times out of this game. Probably the only irritating thing is how slow Geralt runs and how often quests will require you to traverse the same ground over and over. The story is top notch and the choices you can make are interesting and matter quite a bit. Plus you can bring your save file over into the second game which can earn you some special armor and weapons if you've gotten them in this game. They're not the best stuff you can get in the second game, which is a bit lousy since they're given much adieu in this game to just be sold off for a pittance in the next one but I guess that's their way of balancing things.Overall, it's an experience that is worth having if you want to have an understanding of Geralt's backround before heading into the second and third game.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												As this is the first entry of Geralt's gaming appearances, and CDProjektRed's first published product, it can at times feel a little janky. Bioware's Aurora2007 engine contributes to that jankiness a bit as well. For anyone that's played Neverwinter Nights (the original, not the f2p mmo), it kind of feels similar to that. The combat system is odd and tends to be a little bit difficult to get used to, but it serves as only a tool to let you indulge in the weird and wonderful world of The Witcher. Like all the other entries of the series, it's filled with great characters and a story that is echelons above most RPGs. All in all, this is a rough gem that exceeds its value by far. Especially when you can get it on sale sometimes for just over a quid.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												I've played several RPGs so far, including some of the best the genre has to offer, like Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic I and I would say The Witcher is now on my favorite!It has a realistic medieval world, an enthralling story and several unforgetable characters in its cast. Geralt of Rivia is a character I don't think I'll ever forget. His, well your, decisions make an impact on the game and sometimes will have you thinking what's the right thing to do.The combat mechanics aren't really anything much, just a twist to the usual clicky formula, but what DOES make it more interesting is the various potions you can conjure to drink and augment your abilities as well as blade oils and bombs. The potion system is very interesting and necesarry to use in order to succeed in combat. There's also a toxicity meter limiting the use of potions so that you can't abuse them.Overall, it's a great RPG that everyone fan of the genre or of good stories should experience!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Picked up both the first and second Witcher for a great price, Figured why not. Definetly makes my top 5 purchases. Ive only played through about half of the first one but i am loving every minute of it. What really stood out to me was how in depth and involved you can get in the storyline. Also how your actions effect the outcomes of situations, you literally hold peoples lives in your hands! Alright enough babble, pro's and con's time.--Cons---Combat system is visually appealing but not engaging, you just click your RMB to continue combos.-Sometimes you do get lost as to what to do next due to the sheer amount of things to do. -Events where you have to meet someone at a certain time or be somewhere at xx:xx hrs sometimes bug out.-Game occasionally freezes on loading screens between areas, happened about 3-4x in my 11hrs or so of gameplay--Pros---Geralt is a baddas OG-Dialouge is the funniest ive seen in a longg time-Your actions effect the storyline-There are factions you can join if you wish-Fun crafting system-You can free roam and do whatever you like in whatever order you like-Fun gambling minigameWould I suggest for a friend to play this game? YESShould you play this game? YESShould you only buy it if its on sale? NO

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												the Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a great role-playing game. Developer CD Projekt has corrected almost all of the problems that made the original something of a flawed gem. Butchered English dialogue has been rewritten and expanded upon, removing the nonsensical lines that made the plot something of a guessing game last year. Engine performance has been dramatically improved across the board, so the game runs smoother on moderate systems, and you no longer have time to read a magazine while waiting for levels to load. Character models have been dramatically enhanced, removing a fair number of the unrealistic features that made the original game come off as somewhat cartoonish in spots. A pair of new stand-alone adventures has been added to bulk up gameplay outside of the main storyline. by 8.5 out 10 its a great to play!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												There is something inescapably engrossing about this game. The world is rich, feels real and although the storyline is not epic this lends it an authenticity uncommon in many RPGs. This game can be both frustrating and ridiculously hilarous at the same time - probably the best simulator for being drunk I have experienced! Realism in a purely fantastical world = truely awesome. PROS:- Characters and character development - from the start people feel real, unique and - until you get to know them - unpredictable.- Semi-open world - means that the game moves at a nice pace, with some choice as to what to do next.- Decisions - you feel in control and your decisions impact on the game, dictating (at times) who survives, who triumphs, and of course who is left behind. Decisions are not easy to make which also enhances replayability.- Baaaabes.CONS:- Some clunkiness in terms of navigation (I think there is a mod? I have not tried it) and a unique fighting system which I started off hating but really got the hang of and ended up liking.- Some bugs - be careful not to let your inventory get too full or you might end up losing quest items.- As TW2 and more so TW3 will show there could be considerable improvements to UI, Inventory System.- Sometimes quests are not very clear and it can be difficult to know how to find someone/something necessary. However can also add a fun challenge to the game.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This is the most Slavic game (or Polish in particular) that I've ever played and this is the best thing about it. Additionally, the main character is really interesting as he has to face common fear and disgust of both human and elves. You as a player have to make moral choices and try to reminise who you are (create identity of "your" witcher). Graphics isn't that good anymore and there are some glitches (jumping breast, hair and beards :D) and ocasional crashes. However, all in all it is worth it to start the journey from the beginning. Score: 7/10Pros:- Slavic identity and interesting lore- Very likeable main character- Extremely good voice acting in Polish- Not only for fans of Witcher novels- Decent storyCons:- boring fighting model- lots of backtracking and quests like "ask the person at the other end of the map and come back with the message from him"- technical problems- multiple "end fights" - ending is kind of inconsistent- I wasn't skipping side-quests in general and still my character was too weak to pass through Act V. I had to use the save editor to be able to finish the game as I didn't want to replay Act IV. It just didn't feel right. There were no warnings in previous acts that I am skipping too many growth opportunities.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I played through the entirety of Witcher 1 and I enjoyed it overall. Honestly the mechanics of the game are bad. The three stances you have for combat feel like rock paper scissors - enemies are basically defined as fast, strong, and mob-type(multiple yet weak). I would not recommend playing on a hard difficulty as it only makes things tedious rather than interesting. The simplicity of it on easy will let you breeze through the game letting you take in the story which is really where you will enjoy the game.Combat aside, side stories and hidden interactions with the npcs keep the game interesting and it feels like anything could happen. The choices you make have an impact on what happens later in the game. Some do not give an immediate outcome and may come back to you at a later point in the game.The graphics, while dated, do not take much away from the environments built within the game. The first area you start in really turned me off and I had very little desire to play it at that point. The areas after however are well made visually. It's not a true open world but the areas feels large with many areas to explore.If you want to get right into the witcher 2 or 3 games, it may be better to watch a playthrough or read a summary, but I was satisfied and did not regret playing through.Lastly, I can't say how it compares to the books as I have not read them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												First impressions, I love games that have that learn-on-the-job-or-die intro to controls and combat. It really gets that initial thrill of the first few levels of gaming. After reading lots of negative reviews on the combat system and controls, I dunno what they're complaining about: the integrated combat styles, moves and weapons for different enemies gives it more quick thinking when enemies come out of nowhere. The timing of attack combos and chaining is also pretty nifty despite taking abit to work out initially. One downer is that I would have liked that silver sword a little earlier on in the piece, but that's pretty much it. I'm not that far into the game, granted, but another downer is the time it takes to walk/jog everywhere. AND I usually have to wait/meditate until nightfall to actually find something to fight along the way, otherwise it gets painfully boring. BUT! Even set at 'easy' difficulty, it still has that element of supreme power and mettle while in combat if one does it well. Cinematics and dialogue are decent but definitely has room for improvement on the creative side. That said, I've definitely seen worse games in that respect, so it's 'okay'. For what it's worth, price-wise it's okay but it's an old game so if you're after the true Witcher experience, save up and go for Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt or the trilogy for a little extra. Peace.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Witcher 1 is an interesting, captivating and even at times, funny game, that is if you can get past many of the little quirks that are guaranteed to annoy you, just a little bit. The main things that annoyed me is, obviously the combat. It is boring, tedious and doesn't seem very inspired, just click, wait for the mouse cursor to change and click some more, this makes the monster contracts somewhat of a chore instead of "Oh boy! A new creature to slay!" At least for me. Probably not a complaint you'll hear often, but I found the dialogue to be at times very strange, and the characters animations while talking can sometimes be very distracting. Now for some positive things about it; The story is very well done, same with the characters. It's got a dynamic weather system if you're into that type of thing, although for me, it seemed to always rain! Made it a drag sometimes, ha. I really enjoyed the poker dice game, probably a couple hours from that alone. I'd say if you're into RPG's The Witcher is something you should at least give a chance, I know I'm glad I did.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Witcher is a great rpg based on a series of novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. Although some of the gameplay feels a bit clunky and dated, all the rpg elements around it are top notch. The Witcher has a fantastic storyline, great world building, interesting characters, deep lore, and some difficult moral choices.The graphics are great for a 2007 game. It's not the best looking game today but is quite serviceable. The music fits the mood of the game perfectly, feeling very folksy and at home in the Witcher's medieval Europe style world.Gameplay involves questing in each of the 5 chapters. There are many varied quests throughout the game. You'll be slaying monsters, chatting up politicians, romancing ladies, gathering herbs, playing poker, bare knuckle boxing, and more!The game is long, easily over 40 hours long on a first playthrough. If you do absolutely everything it might take you much closer to 80 hours. There's definitely not a lack of content in this game.All in all, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a meaty rpg with a strong emphasis on story and setting. Also from what I hear you can import your Witcher 1 saved game into the sequel, the Witcher 2, which is reportedly also fantastic. The Witcher 3 is due out next year and looks absolutely beautiful from the screenshots and trailers. Definitely recommend starting with the first one and playing through the entire epic trilogy.

												The Witcher is a nice epic-medieval oriented 3rd person RPG game with a very interesting story-line.The graphics are quite awesome for a 2007 game and the effects very nice too.The characters are very well roled, each one has a meaning for his/her existance, good AI.The game also brings the player into positions to make choices that affect the rest of the game which is interesting.The fight system at start is VERY boring till you gain a few levels, there's not much variety on attack styles which migh make the player bored.The main character is very cool, nice voiced, awesomely designed and ingame you can also choose the way of your sexlife (The European version has totally uncencored "se cards") or to have a romance story.I was amazed that a Polish developer team managed to create such a brilliant game.Recommended for the lovers of the kind, specially for those who like interesting story-lines in RPG games.Can't wait to get my hands on Witcher 2.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												The Witcher is a wonderful RPG. My favourite aspect of the game is how well developed the characters are - I guess we have the books to thank for that. Sure, the game is not as expansive as Elder Scrolls: Oblivion but there is still plenty of hours of enjoyment set in the city of Visima and the surrounding villages. The game takes a more philisophical bent than other murdering-and-looting RPGs. Hard decisions have to be made frequently as amnesia-suffering Geralt looks to find his own identity. Couple this with some beautiful soundtracks and it is a must-play game in the world of RPGs - If you thought all RPGs were just like Skyrim, you'd be wrong.

												I've played several RPGs so far, including some of the best the genre has to offer, like Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic I and I would say The Witcher is now on my favorite!It has a realistic medieval world, an enthralling story and several unforgetable characters in its cast. Geralt of Rivia is a character I don't think I'll ever forget. His, well your, decisions make an impact on the game and sometimes will have you thinking what's the right thing to do.The combat mechanics aren't really anything much, just a twist to the usual clicky formula, but what DOES make it more interesting is the various potions you can conjure to drink and augment your abilities as well as blade oils and bombs. The potion system is very interesting and necesarry to use in order to succeed in combat. There's also a toxicity meter limiting the use of potions so that you can't abuse them.Overall, it's a great RPG that everyone fan of the genre or of good stories should experience!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												The Witcher is a rough diamond.  Some of the translation to English results in odd conversations, some sections (mainly the swamp) are a bit of a grind, the combat can be repetitive and I had the occasional crash.  There are also some upgrades, signs and potions that are much more useful than others.At times, too, it wasn't particularly clear about why you were doing what you were doing, or which speech option would get you which result.  But that's part of what makes The Witcher rewarding to play - it doesn't always hold your hand or telegraph every step in the plot.  The story is engrossing and, translation aside, the characters are great (even though most of the 'romances' are just Geralt saying "let's bang, ok?") and you will quickly realise that you can't please everyone.  There are definitely a few tough choices to make.The game takes a while to warm up so don't be put off by the slow start.  Also, if you're finding it difficult and dying a lot then - like me, initially - you're doing it wrong.  There are always potions, blade coatings, signs or upgrades that make beating particular enemies (and the game) much easier.  When in doubt: Swallow.While The Witcher lacks some of the polish (not Polish) of its AAA RPG cousins, it more than makes up for it in the depth of story and the adult RPG elements.  Highly recommended for anyone who wants to lose themselves in a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												An enjoyable game, with a few reservations.In the beginning, the combat will feel incredibly clunky. This is possibly down to the fact that it is. Curiously, however, I found myself enjoying the combat, despite it having more in common with a rhythm game than comparable RPGs. Imagine KotOR combat with a touch of Crypt of the NecroDancer, and you'll be half way there.As for the story: If you're a newcomer to the Witcher franchise, you'll get the gist of it rather quickly. What comes across as a standard amnesia scenario is, from what I can tell, a way of shielding the player from having the assumed knowledge of Geralt's adventures in written fiction. Overall, the story does get rather engaging, especially after finishing the first couple of "zones". This is good as it provides the impetus for you to push through the atrociously designed swamp section.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I started playing this game back in the day it was released... A friend of mine actually participated in Czech localization and lended his voice to a character in the game, so I was really curious about meeting "him" in the story :) Yet, due to a little mishap, I lost all my savegames, being almost at the end of the game at that point, I couldn't bring myself to replay it that soon after I had gone through it once... and the game lay on my shelf for years to come... Later I purchased another copy on Steam, thinking I could play through it again then, but I didn't... Then I got it for free on gog.com as a bonus to another purchase, so my third copy in fact. And third time's a charm, right? Right. I started playing then, finally. Got all the way to the Chapter IV... and stopped... for nearly a year! But as life has it, unexpected has happened and here I find myself, finally having finished the first volume and its gripping story, I must say... IT WAS WORTH IT!!!! The game truly deserves its rightful place in any RPG lover's collection. This is where it all began, and despite its many flaws, the game really is a gem, a diamond in rough, and a testament to the hard work and gallons of love poured in it by its developers to whom we should be greatful, for breathing life into Sapkowski's legend and showing it to the whole world. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Short version: Great game with good story. Some unique elements that are mildly annoying, but add to realism/immersion. Morally grey decisions that cause game-lasting changes to various elements. 8.5/10Great action RPG with some unique elements that separate it from the rest of it's genre. On the hard difficulty with the Extreme Immersion mod installed (which removes much of the HUD and other elements that make things feel more game-y), it presented a good challenge that never got too frustrating.The combat system is a bit weird, but not bad once you get used to it. Instead of 1 click per attack, you click once and Geralt launched into a combo. Then you click again at the end of the combo to begin the next flurry. Proper timing leads to much better (and cooler looking) attacks. Items/potions that restore chunks of health instantly are rare (I know of one). Instead, everything just makes your natural health regen faster. A bit annoying at times, but it does add a bit more realism to the game.You can't gather alchemy ingredients if you don't know they exist. Again, a bit annoying, but adds realism. If you didn't know that a dog's liver was good for making potions, why would you ever take it out, right?Finally, this is one of those RPGs that forces you to make various moral decisions (many of which will affect the later chapters in the game significantly, so choose wisely). However, unlike many games which hvae clear "good" and "bad" choices, Witcher almost always makes you choose between two equally bad options. For example (spoilers incoming), at one point you decide whether to support a village whose leaders are murderers, rapists, and child traffickers or to support the witch they are trying to lynch, who aided many of those same leaders herself. Both are clearly in the wrong, but you must decide which to kill and which to save. That decision will affect various things for the remainder of the game (my advice: save the witch).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												The Witcher. We all know why you're here. To play this game before witcher 2 then 3. You may be hesitating whether to buy this game because the graphics look old, and the dialogues are horrible. And you're right, they are, but once you get past those, the game is pretty fun. There are some sex scenes (which I don't mind), but they're opitional and are just pictures of nude women. The story is average, if not above average. A group of super mercenaries, witchers, gets their mutant secrets stolen by a group of bandits, so Geralt must find them and grab it back. One complaint is that the quests makes you walk back and forth around the map. Receive a quest on the left side of the map, complete it the right side, then talk to someone at the top, go back to the left, then receive reward at the right. The majority of the quests just make you run around until you get sick of the maps.But the major flaw in this game is the glitchy combat system. There will be times when you need to tap to attack, but Geralt acts like an idiot and just stands still. There have been times when I would want to punch my monitor out of how frustrating it was.Overall: 7/10Although the combat and dialogue sucks, the story is indeed worth playing. There is a good sense of lore where you play a medeival fantasy setting. I would recommend this game if you plan on buying the sequels just so you can get a better understanding with the characters.Some tips if you play this game: spend time to make potions. The only other way to heal is sleeping or waiting for your health to regenerate by eating food. Also, if you deciede to play the extra adventure games, "Price of Neutrality" is the only one worth playing imo.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												A trully epic adventure!Argh where to begin!? The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is definatly one of my new favourite games.  The game starts off pretty slow, paired with a not so great combat system it did take me a few attempts to get started with the game. After a few hours (and a few restarts) i got my head around the interesting combat system and by the end of chapter 1 I had fallen in love with it! It adds a layer of depth to the combat, instead of just running around and swinging your sword at anything that moves; but instead you have to learn which enemies are vulnerable to which witcher combat style and then use that to your advantage and this does not only it makes meeting new enemies and fighting bosses that little more interesting, but also keeps you one your feet if you are fighting a large group of enimies.The first chapter can get a little tedious.. well boring really and i ended up taking a break from the witcher becuase of that. But i came back a few months later craving for Witcher and soldiered on through the first chapter. The second and third chapter were really enjoyable but there was alot of running around and go here, talk to this person, go find this person and sadly everynow and then the NPC would not be where he is supposed to be ( I found this can be fixed by just going to a fireplace and meditating for 48hrs). For me however the game felt average at this point and it wasn't really getting truly immersed into the game. By the end of chapter III i was almost at the point of just giving up on the game and moving onto witcher 2, but how glad i am that i stuck with it for just a little longer! Chapter IV was honestly my best experience in any RPG i have ever played. I was finally fully immersed into the game and just could not stop playing. The game picks up quite alot during chapter IV, and as soon as you know it you will be on your way to chapter 5 and finally the Epilogue. The ending was very diffrent than what i thought it would be it was amazing. I will not reveal any details because you must play this game and experience it for yourself! My favoruite part of the game was that your choices that you make throughout the entire game trully matter and can make a huge diffrence to the game and how it is played. I will one day go back an playthrough the game again and choose completely diffrent choices to see how those effect the game and see if the choices i made were even the right ones. I definatly recommend this game to anyone who is keen on a story rich game. I am keen to play The Wither 2 with the save file from Witcher: Enhanced Edition.

												The Witcher is a nice epic-medieval oriented 3rd person RPG game with a very interesting story-line.The graphics are quite awesome for a 2007 game and the effects very nice too.The characters are very well roled, each one has a meaning for his/her existance, good AI.The game also brings the player into positions to make choices that affect the rest of the game which is interesting.The fight system at start is VERY boring till you gain a few levels, there's not much variety on attack styles which migh make the player bored.The main character is very cool, nice voiced, awesomely designed and ingame you can also choose the way of your sexlife (The European version has totally uncencored "se cards") or to have a romance story.I was amazed that a Polish developer team managed to create such a brilliant game.Recommended for the lovers of the kind, specially for those who like interesting story-lines in RPG games.Can't wait to get my hands on Witcher 2.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												In 2007 when I was 14, I was looking at this in a game shop, then an obese Indian woman came up to me with piercing eyes and displeased face and asked "How old are you?!" I said nothing, and slowly backed away round a corner in fear.Five years later I bought this on Steam, at its full price. Then of course a week later it was on sale.Now finally on with the game, The Witcher is a fantasy RPG based on a series of Polish novels I haven't read yet. You play as Geralt, a lady's-man-warrior-witch-bloke, and embark on an epic quest, meeting friends and foes, bandits, possessed children, fiery dogs, mad scientists, squids, gremlins, floating naked chicks and frog mages. The usual.You level up your guy, get upgrades and make potions, as you do. The combat system is good, switching between swords and speeds. It's gritty, with gore and swearing and sex. Reminds me of Game of Thrones, for Eastern European jews or something.It's a great medieval yarn. It just repeats the same characters over and over. I freaking hate that old lady that's everywhere.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												An excellent story, unmatched characterisation and a world brimming with life and character sets this apart from the crowd. Aside from the gripping plot, it's the little things that make the difference. Townsfolk huddling under canopies to shelter from the rain, birds flocking from a bush and you approach to harvest herbs. Features that The Witcher's big-budget peers (The Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age) lack. Round it off with a simple but elegant combat system and more than a few original ideas to shake up the classic RPG progression path and you've got one of the best action RPGs ever made. I implore you to finish this one and it's fantastic sequel before The Witcher 3 storms onto the scene and rocks our world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Overall rating: 4/5Summary: Utterly visionary game, denied a fifth star because its glitches show its age.  We aren't talking about bad voice-overs or unresolved plot lines, we're talking about frequent hard crashes and the occasional game-ruining bug.Pros:-Storyline(s) utterly captivating.  This bullet was almost very long, so I'll put it this simply: You will make choices that will torment you in a good way.  I'm usually really into (approximately) optimizing characters and producing well-thought out builds, but I passed up a few upgrades because I didn't support the choices I needed to make to get them.  Furthermore, many of the choices I made were difficult, with no clearly wrong answers.-This game is aggressively beautiful.  Sometimes you'll be at the height of a major confrontation, and if there's a lull in the battle you'll find yourself playing with the camera just to check out the scenery, the behavior of NPCs, or Geralt's gear - which largely reflects what you equip.-Character levelling paces nicely with the game.  If you're vigilant about quests, then your character will start becoming overpowered towards the final stages - but this feels natural and believable, since you have to be thorough to build a really epic character.  -NPC allies, though weak, feel very believable.  They make mistakes a rookie might, and it makes sense that they should be fragile compared to a witcher mercenary like you!-The resource management system, if you figure it out, is addicting.  You are allowed to carry JUST ENOUGH that you can be super well prepared for a lot of situations, without being able to "hoard" items without being forced to dump things of value.   You're forced to think hard about what you carry around with you.-The game rewards a studious character - most knowledge that is needed to win fights without a lot of agony is available at financial cost, and those costs are greatly diminished if you're pretty diligent about chatting up NPCs.  Things you learn are neatly inventoried, so gaining knowledge never feels like a waste and you don't need to read things that don't pertain to your immediate needs.-The battle system rewards good thinking.  Choosing the right sword style is a piece of cake once you get the hang of it; deciding what spells should compliment what build requires some thought, and there are mechanisms in place to limit any advantage you can imagine.  Cons:-This game crashes........A LOT.  I would give it a top rating if not for the raw quantity of crashes I had to put up with.  The complaints I've heard from others (of which there are a lot) suggest that it's mainly an optimization issue, and mostly affects Mac user. Honestly, it's inexcusable that the makers OFFER this game for whichever platforms are affected to this degree, and are churning out sequels but haven't bothered to patch the original chapter in the series.  I can't understate how annoying the crashes are.  I played the whole game with all optional quality settings at their lowest possible levels.  I still experienced at least one crash every, say, 90 minutes - and sometimes could get a crash in as little as 15-20 minutes.  This game is so good I recommend tolerating and intolerable level of stability issues.  SAVE REALLY OFTEN and lower your settings as much as you need to to minimize crashes - even the lowest settings are mostly quite good.  If you have the hardware to enjoy the upper settings, I imagine they're even better.-Your CPU will run fiery-hot while you play this game.  If you're playing on a Macbook, as I was, you may need to shut down everything else and put a fan on.  If it gets too hot, that's one thing that can cause the game to shut down.-There is moderate sexism in some of the dialogue.  With a male protagonist with mostly male friends in a Middle Ages setting, this isn't the worst or most unbelievable element - but it's a bit hammy.  One major character offers you the advice of several other major characters, mentioning that the one who is female will advice on "x, y and 'female intuition.'  Little stuff like that makes some of the voice acting feel forced, and makes the NPCs seem stupid at times.-Minor con:  There is a room that, if you re-enter it looking for treasure, you may become unable to leave.  An unlocked door behind you simply will not open, and your buddies will eternally wonder WTF happened to you.  If you somehow saved your game after that point and don't have earlier backups, too bad.  This point is near the end of the game, so you can lose a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of valuable progress that way.  Also, some dialogue trees don't acknowledge differences in choices you can make.
