content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I recommend this for RPG fans.  This game has gathered some attention for some of the adult-themes in it, and while running around carousing is mildly amusing at first, it is the gameplay and the story that win out in the end.  After spending around 800 hours between Oblivion and Fallout 3, exploring every nook and cranny of those games, I just couldn't get into New Vegas and haven't bothered with Skyrim because they just seem like more of the same.  While I would have thought that to be a good thing, I think personally my RPG cravings were just ready to be immersed in something new.  Enter The Witcher:While you don't get to choose a character or class in this game, the main character has his own qualities and abilities that make it unique.  The story in this game is compelling and there is a lot of entertaining detective work to do and choices you have to make to keep the game advancing. The characters have more depth than most games, quite possibly due to this being based on a novel—a medium where if the character development is lacking,...it just plain sucks.  For example, Geralt of Rivia, the main character, has a personality that is mostly  polite, cordial, and heroic at times, but depending on who he's talking to there is a sarcastic, snarky side, as well as a naughty side.  Rarely are characters in games given this much dimension.By today's standards, the combat system is seems antiquated, but after you get used to it, it's fine.  It does the job and makes getting contracts to slay monsters for gold a fun and worthwhile profession.  The item pickups are not plentiful, and if you want a new weapon every 10 minutes, this isn't your game.  Honestly though, I found this aspect of it kind of refreshing, the upgrades seem well deserved and its kind of nice to not have to learn to use a new toy or ability every few minutes or keep looking at weapon specs all day trying to figure out which is better,...this way you can just keep playing. The alchemy on the other hand is one of the deeper aspects of the game, and it becomes a fun hobby as the game progresses.My biggest gripes about this game, which are few, are how I was robbed of some of the mission completions.  For example, I escort an NPC to safety,...end of mission cutscene ensues, ...story to be continued later, but then the NPC randomly gets killed instead of being safely immune from danger,...and then there is no continuation on that plot because the NPC has perished.  Maybe I'm just too picky. This game reinforces the tried and true RPG mantra: save frequently, and make multiple saves.

												I was given this game in 2007 by my girlfriend at the time. I took one look at it, got angry at her and said something to the likes  of "what the hell is wrong with you; im not gonna play this crap;" I have never been more wrong in my entire life. I didnt get to installing the game until later, and when i first played it i was disappointed. Long load times, Average graphics, obtuse combat, and the bugs, oh god the bugs. But this game is like another great masterpisece deus ex in that, if you can get past the dreadful first mission, the game opens up wonderfully in so many ways. The combat, the alchemy, the perks, the actual story and choices and the consequences that come with them. If you can get past the sex cards (which i personally like)then this is one of the most thoughtful and mature rpgs you will ever play. I would rank this as one of my top 5 rpgs of all time. A True masterpiece. A word of advice though, play this with an SSD. Youll thank me later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												The Witcher is a great RPG with some pretty big flaws. It makes a great use of the source material (the Witcher books by the Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski) and features a deep story with lots of side quests and many important choices. The main character Geralt and the setting itself are certainly some of the biggest strengths of the game.Unfortunately the game has some pretty big issues too. The game was a hugely ambitious project for a small studio like CD Project Red and it often shows. The heavily modified Aurora Engine (originally developed for Neverwinter Nights by Bioware) was a poor fit for a title with more action-oriented combat and the controls are often extremely clunky as a result.The game is also extremely easy after you get past the prologue and the first chapter. Even on hard most fights are pretty trivial once you get bit further in the game. This is a shame, as I quite enjoyed the early challenging combat that forces you to rely on preparation and consumables.Overall the Witcher is still a great experience just for the story and the characters, as long as you can put up with the flawed combat. It's also the logical entry point into the Witcher game series, as the Witcher 2 picks up soon after the end of this one and some of your decisions will transfer over.I completed the game on hard, picking the Witcher/Neutral path. I was using a couple of graphics and UI mods, but nothing major.The good:- Great main character- Interesting main story and side quests- Lots of choices and consequences- The game deals with some quite mature themes- Interesting crafting system that fits the setting and the main character- Great journal systemThe bad:- Combat is passable but the controls are often very clunky- Way too easy even on Hard difficulty- Romance/Sex is handled in an extremely juvenile manner- The writing and especially the voice-acting are bit uneven- Lots of quests force you to do extensive backtracking, simply padding the length of the game- Inventory managament can be bit of a painThe ugly:- Some quest scripting issues. This is understandable in a game of this complexity, but it's still annoying- Dice poker is a terrible mini-game with cheating opponents and relies way too much on luck- Quicksave always creates a new save, this quickly clogs up the list of save games

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												There's a reason why this game has such great scores everywhere, why people speak well of it, and why I played it for hours and hours, every day.First of all, I have bad news: even though this game is great, don't spend your money if you don't have maturity to play it. I mean, I played it once when I was 14-15, but I could just realise how good this game is by playing it again when I became an adult.The game is full of decisions. Each decision affects the rest of the game. And by the ending of it, you will see that you made some bad decisions - and that allows replayability, which is great. I hardly get interested in the story, but this one is specialThe combat may not respond well sometimes, but considering that the game is a bit old, the flaws are acceptable, and they won't really annoy you.Something I really liked is that you can choose the way you fight: Sword fighting is excelent and strong, using alchemy is highly effective, and magic is awesome. You can fully max one of those, or mix them - both ways are effective too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												This is a marvelous game. The storyline, the twists and turns, the side quests, it is all extraordinarily well done.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you are nothing short of a badass. There are very few games I truly recommend, and even fewer that I am willing to put in the time to review. This game is worth every penny. The combat system is unique, dynamic, and immensely entertaining. The alchemy system is complex, riveting and yet simple enough to understand for even the most casual gamers.The relationships you can build throughout the game are intense, and every bit determined on the paths you choose. The sex scenes are a nice touch, gives it that adult flare without being overtly pornagraphic. The storylines are in-depth, articulate, well organized and progresses the story in a very fluid manner, thoroughly explaining the backstory along the way.The sidequests are entertaining as hell, and get you that much needed relief from the overhwelming sensation of the large monumental tasks that you will have to accomplish to complete the game. The in-game "games" like the dice poker is probably one of my favorite aspects of the game, along with the "fight clubs." You can make quite a few Orens just by freely engaging in combat, or gambling. As it stands, I don't see why everyone shouldn't buy this game. Its not terribly expensive, and you will be engaged for hours.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you ARE a BADASS!That is all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												With rich lore and a compelling narrative, The Witcher delivers a well-exectuted story that has your choices play a significant role in several outcomes. As you explore the world of The Witcher, you will be slaying monsters, fighting the Salamandra scum and choosing whether to help the people (and werewolves) of Vizima. While the controls get a little getting used to. they get the job done with simple timed-clicks and spell executions. Although, selecting what weapon you use via hotkeys can be confusing and clunky in general. Clicking the weapon you want is by far the easier solution.Alchemy is a large element of the game as it can give tempoary buffs to Geralt during combat or by granting the ability to let you see in the dark. You can also brew oils to increase your weapons' effectiveness and you can also craft bombs. But, these buffs come at a cost. Toxicity. When your toxicity bar becomes at least half full, Geralt starts to become intoxicated. The more the bar is filled (the more potions you drink), the more intoxicated Geralt will become resulting in him being slower, potions having a negative affect or he may just die instantly. However, toxicity can be cured by: meditating or by drinking White Honey.Questing in this game consists of having a few main quest branches, a few side quest branches and miscellaneous monster contracts.The structure of the quests can be confusing as let's say, the main objective is to (no spoilers here, just made up) talk to Triss about the enchanted rose. You do that and this piece of text appears under this quest: "Now that Triss knows about the rose, I should come back after I go and see the Druids." That puts this particular quest on hold for now. Then you get a new objective for a different quest that says: "Find the druids and get more information about the rose." You do that and then this quest goes on hold while you go back to Triss....I think you get my point. It's downright confusing! There are activities in the game such as: fist fights & poker. The fist fights are boring once you learn the right tactics (rigging I mean) but if you want to make quick money, go right ahead. However, the poker is well done in this game. The music gets you into the gambling spirit!Overall, I have enjoyed this game a lot. While the gameplay can feel dated sometimes, plus the occasional crashes, the voice acting is great and the story is compelling. I think it's definitely worth a buy if you're a newcomer to the Witcher series! :)  7.5/10

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Personally, I thought this game was amazing and haven't had a game keep me so interested for so long in quite a while. Story was very interesting and was told in a great way - through talking with the characters in the world, reading the many books you will find/purchase and also through the environment itself.I found the combat very enjoyable, using potions, oils, runes and more to improve my weapons based on the creatures I would face in the upcoming area (which can be found out by reading a monster's bestiary entry in your journal) and fighting enemies with the swords. I think that this strategy is the main focus of the combat, along with dodging at the right time and using signs (spells) to your advantage, as the swordplay is comprised of combo-ing enemies by clicking at the correct moment using one of three combat stances.I recommend this game to anyone who wants to invest a lot of time exploring, hunting monsters, completing various side-quests and chasing women.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												This game is worth playing.  The combat system is very wonky but once you get the hang of it, it isn't so bad at all, and the story is very good.  Also the choices you make in this game carry over to 2nd game.Act I, III and IV move along quite well.  Act II, V and Epilogue seem to drag on.  The alchemy system is a bit confusing but the game tells you what you can make so it isn't too bad.  Level up Igni a lot, it is very powerful, maybe a bit too powerful.  To answer the question:  Is it worth playing this game or should I just skip to the 2nd game?  The short answer: Yes, play this game!  The long answer: if you are a roleplaying enthusit you will enjoy the many nuances the game has to offer, also Geralt's sense of humor is amazing!  The game is a long one, I clocked over 50 hours on it.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												The combat is janky, the voice acting stilted and the engine was poorly optimized for computers back in 2007 and is STILL poorly optimized today, but The Witcher remains one of the most magnificent computer role-playing games to emerge in the last decade. It's a slow burn especially by today's standards, and I needed to try this game twice before getting into it completely. Once I did, the adventures of potion-mixing, bomb-tossing, double sword-wielding Geralt the Riv totally snared my imagination, and this game remains one of the few modern titles to remind me of my all time favorite RPG/adventure series of yesteryear, Quest for Glory. Really can't give it a higher recommendation than that.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an extremely immersive game if you let it be. I didn't like it the first time I tried it because I didn't know what I was getting into. The second time however I feel in love. I will note a few things though:The game as a whole is dull until Chapter 2The game focuses on dialog and character development as much if not more than combat. If that turns you off I wouldn't recommend this game.The combat is more repetitive than most games, but tolerable.The game fails to give tutorials on how some mechanics/controls works. For instance: You hold down shift to see your mouse cursor to click on your signs. There I just saved you 5 minutes of google searching.The dialog is really bad in the first chapter, but significantly raises in quality after that.Closing Thoughts: If you like RPG's that are character driven this is the game for you. It may not have the open world of Witcher 3, but it is a very enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Where to begin with the Witcher.The series follows one Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, through his journeys as a monster slayer, if you've read any of the novels it's based off of you'd know such that the tales are oft delicate. There's not one sure defined answer but it'll be the one that Geralt decides to go with. He's a complex character that does just about whatever he wants to meet his goals, which is why he's fun to play as or hear about. The world this Witcher inhabits is riddled with politics, greed, murder, racism, lust, and whatever other humanly attributes you can think of. Racism is one card I've found interesting in this universe as it's something most other fantasy will stray from. More to the point it is a key driving cause in the present world that Geralt inhabits which causes conflict between the humans and the non-humans. Ingame this conflict is presented throught he Order of the Eternal Flame and the Scoia'tael.I had tried years past playing through this game and struggling to make ground, the controls all felt off and it felt like there was no possible way I would ever make it through. This time I tried again with more patience to learn everything, and I felt that it paid off very well. The game is more of a Strategy RPG than anything else, you essentially click and wait until you've done the 'cutscene' attack and then click again in time to proceed through the attacks, these attacks have to be selected for the opponent in question with strong/quick/group attack variations. You can easily break this element by simply clicking the mouse fast enough and overwhelm your opponent. So the gameplay falls apart quite quick in my opinion. But if you choose to not break the game like I've mentioned, it's still pretty satisfying. The game allows you enough skill points (if you level enough) to acquire nearly EVERYTHING in the game. So regardless of how you do your build you'll still wind up broken at the end of the game. There are a couple of different "builds" you can do but in my opinion the Igni build trumps everything else.Gameplay doesn't end there as most quests require investigations either by reading books with lore to perform tasks like extracting herbs/ingredients from monsters. Potions are also a large part of the game and help out LOADS when it comes to combat.I thought the economy was worthless in this game as money means nothing in the end, spend it all on books or things to progress. You get best weapons and armor free of charge if you make correct decisions.So now let's do spoilers.=================================================================The choices in the game felt all wrong, only an hour or two into the sequel (W2:Assassins of Kings), it had already outdone any of the decisions in the first game where I had to sit and think extraordinarily hard about how I should proceed (referencing: In the Claws of Madness). The Scoia'tael never give a convincing reason to join them, in fact they never explain anything aside from Yaevinn stating a slippery slope fallacy in that: Geralt as a nonhuman will one day change his mind like Yaevinn had. It's unreasonable to blindly join the Scoia'tael (a terrorist group) to give me insight to understand them. Yaevinn had his chance to give a valid argument and gave a faulty one. While preaching about fighting for rights, it's apparent that the Scoia'tael would give humans the same treatment in a reversed situation.The order was far more reasonable but then suddenly decided that they needed to be unreasonable at the end. They just start slaughtering non-humans because the Grand Master said to. Throughout the game we're led to believe they're racist or oppressing the non-humans but the player never witnesses any of this until the massacre shenanigans which felt offputting.So both sides suck equally, however player decisions are even worse.Allow the Scoia'tael to steal crates? Y/NScoia'tael jump the Order and kill some people. Which side do you fight for?The Scoia'tael are performing bank robbery, want to join? Y/NOrder decides to purge non-humans, Scoia'tael fight back - in the marshes the Order plan on killing the Scoia'tael unit even if they surrender. At the same time the Scoia'tael have killed some hostages already.Which side do you join? The other will be massacred.Horrendous right? It's hard to pick a side when both were being unreasonable. Yes there are other decisions in the game but these are supposed to be the 'main ones' that affect the story. And despite the story claiming that staying neutral is impossible, there's actually a neutral side where you tell both groups to ♥♥♥♥ off. It just felt like there was always one blatantly right choice to pick throughout the game. (Minus the Triss/Shani decision for Alvin which is a romance decision.)Other problems I had with this game-Geralt was never defined as a character even at the end of the game, his history is left untouched which leaves a lot to be desired. It feels misleading to have quests in the game that act like we'll uncover who Geralt is but never do so.-The main plot of the game until the epilogue is "Azar Javed steals Witcher secrets for ???". It makes it hard to hate Azar Javed in any sense. The professor was easier to dislike (as he kills a friendly Witcher) but he never had any real motivations besides being the lackey to the other guy. -The final boss was a damn good concept but he should have had some role in an earlier chapter of the game. While we got to affect who he became, it's not the same as having him nearby only to find out he betrays you right at the end. We care so little about the Grand Master that when he's defeated, we only care who he was not what he became. I think the ending could've been even more powerful if we cared about the Grand Master to begin with and understood where he was coming from, not understanding him after we've killed him. It's putting the cart before the horse (i.e. priorities are all backways).-The game rewards the player for exploring however by doing this you can also mess up the quest order (affecting other quests) and Geralt will make explanations on things the player hasn't learned yet. -Game allows NPCs to just kinda disappear and involve them somewhere else, it's annoying because you can have a quest to turn in but because "blank" is happening, they're somewhere else from where the quest marker has them. Some quests will get bugged out from proceeding through the main story and you can never turn them in anyways.-The length of the game: Many people complain the game is too long to get rebuttled with "you don't like longer games?", to phrase a more correct complaint: It's too damn repetitive.Much of the game consists of walking from one place to another, the worst chapter and contender for that title is EASILY Chapter IV. Chapter I and II are great in that there feels like no unneeded content, everything is situated nicely and compact. Chapter III is essentially all of Chapter II with some added areas and repeated quests (go kill NEW monsters that didn't spawn earlier), but is overall repeated content. Chapter IV is awful for quests like "buy bread and come back" or "go to the village repair a mirror and come back". Nearly 90% of the map could be cut out with no negative consequences. Then Chapter V opens to even worse maps of four(?)-ish caves, a map that's 90% swamp, and burning Vizima which also could've been cut since you're there for all ten minutes before leaving to the swamp map. The Epilogue was just a hallway, but it was also meant to end the game which gives it a free pass I suppose.=================================================================

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Initially, this was a slow burner for me. At times, the sheer complexity of the available choices you have can be daunting. I played this casually on and off through the first chapter. After getting used to the battle system, and the usefulness of alchemy, I actually really started to get drawn in by the story and the choices that you can make. The size and scope of this game is impressive. Towards the end, I found myself really becoming a fan, and I was looking forward to the ending. Minor gripes are that it can become very tedious completing secondary quests, mainly because travel can take a while across multiple maps. Also, little things like waiting for the transition between battle and explore mode in order to pick up items, etc. can really eat into time when you just want to see what happens next, or fight another monster.Overall though, I was extremely glad to have finished the game, and I'm excited about playing 2 and 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												It is probably helpful for the reader if I compare The Witcher to Skyrim:While Skyrim 'feels' like a computer game, a role playing game, and maybe could be described as having a slight theatrical vibe, playing The Witcher feels like reading a good book. It is very character- and story-focused. Geralt of Rivia is a very down-to-earth and likeable character and the game doesn't try to glorify or overly dramatize things. Those subtleties make the game feel even more believable and realistic than the medieval setting already does.I was worried that because of this, the game might be overly gruesome, but it's not. It has a certain charme.I actually like that the game world is relatively limited and that you revisit places a lot, which change every now and then. It gives the whole setting more depth. I also can more easily relate to the various quests, see them as part of a whole. At times the game makes it difficult to stop, because, as I said, it's like reading a good book where you're always at some interesting point.The combat isn't overly detailed, which makes it more fun to play around with the various combat stances and alchemical helpers and just watch and enjoy the action. I also like the very limited selection of weapons and armor. It would just be unnecessary complication. I personally don't like stuff that much, and the alchemy is still tolerable to me, because when you play on medium difficulty, you don't have to dive deep into that. A few potions here and there and it'll be fine.I like very much how the game doesn't put too much time pressure on you. Many of the temporarily active helpers are long-lasting (e.g. a blade sharpening that lasts a full day of in-game time), and the in-game time progresses slowly enough that you don't end up hurrying around before the 'wrong time of day' sets in.It's easy for me to overlook the various small flaws of the game. They're not too immersion-breaking, and the UI has some minor complications that aren't too bothersome. (Among the things that bother me most is that in some free range areas there are artificial fences, requiring you to walk all the way around. But it's just a minor inconvenience.)The decisions you make in various situations don't feel like dummies that pretend to have an effect, but there are (some) consequences, so you actually feel like playing a role.I sometimes would have wished for more flexibility in dialogues when decision-making is involved, but again: Not a big deal.The Witcher is just so different from that 'typical game experience'. A very good translation of a book series to a computer game. Again... It's almost as if you're 'playing a novel', but totally not like an interactive novel, and also not like those modern games that linearly push you from scene to scene, but a proper, mature computer game with focus on story and character interaction. You're wandering around in a story.In fact, what makes this game great reminds me a bit of the Half-Life series, but with less action and less linearity. At least the first game was based on the work of a real horror story author.Specific things that bothered me significantly:- No access to storage in chapter 5 - you have to work with what you have and can't restock from your storage. Even worse, at the beginning of the chapter you are allowed access, but shortly after, you are barred from it.- Voice dialogues contain many instances of wrong emphasis due to the VA not knowing the context of the line.- Geralt keeps sheathing his weapon after a few seconds against my intention to not do that.- Drawing the sword (except in strong stance) makes Geralt move faster, so basically for fast travel always draw your sword. I wish there was a better way to travel quickly than this obvious workaround.- Fist fight is very weird. There are skills for various moves, but not enough tutorial to explain how they work, so my fist fighting ended up very simplistic. Situation-dependent combos rarely ever worked properly.- Geralt of Review

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Overall a great game.GRAPHICS - Lack of diverse character models.  Many quest givers all have the exact same face, making distinction difficult.GAMEPLAY - Fun mechanics.  Rather than clicking rapidly, you are forced to play with more finesse, clicking only at the right times to continue/complete combos.It is best to understand the gameplay mechanics before deciding you hate it - a few simple, crucial tips will make all the difference between loving and hating this game (and seeing it through to the end):1. MONEY - Pick up EVERYTHING.  Sell any secondary weapons you find (you'll never use them, and they are worth a lot). Sell all LOW and MEDIUM strength alcohol (keep strong alcohol for alchemy).2. TALENT POINTS - Look through the GOLD point talents and decide on THREE main areas you want to focus on and dump all your talent points into those areas before diversifying.  This will dictate your combat style heavily, but make you much stronger overall. Spreading out your points with a "balanced build" will inherently make you weaker overall and good at nothing. Seriously, decide how you want to kill things and stick with it.3. ALCHEMY - Always have WHITE HONEY (removes toxicity) and WIVE'S TEARS (removes drunkeness) on hand.  Brew a stack of WHITE GULL (a base for other potions) and store all other strong alcohol until you need more WHITE GULL.  Bombs and Blade oils are specific to the Intelligence tree.  If you don't plan on going down that tree, you can sell all bases for them (powder and grease/tallow, respectively).4.  EXPLORATION/QUESTS - Explore all areas of the map at all times of day (namely noon and midnight).  Certain monsters only come out at certain times, and it's the only way to find/kill them for quests.  Do as many side quests as possible for extra xp/levels/talents.  You only get gold talents at higher levels, and they sure are strong.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												This game is tricky to review. The story is fairly enjoyable, but the pacing and execution leaves much to be desired. Game mechanics-wise, the Witcher is a game riddled with bugs. I only regret not recording some of them, as they were incredibly amusing. The graphics are fairly good for their time, and improved upon more in the enhanced edition of the game. The art direction is pretty solid, and the music presentation is above average. If you can find the courage to take this game on despite its glaring flaws, it's worth a play. If not, I'd recommend a summary or a Let's Play series somewhere on YouTube to watch instead. That said, I'm still going to finish this game and prepare myself for the Witcher 2, which I've heard is infinitely better. 6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												★ ★ ★ ★ ☆ The Witcher is a gigantic, engrossing RPG that will suck you into the world for hours on end, but it may be slightly overambitious. The universe of The Witcher originates from the mind of Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. This particular entry takes place some time after the final book in the series,  The Lady of the Lake.  Fortunately, you won't need to have prior knowledge of these books to enjoy the story CD PROJEKT RED has presented. The story is centered around Geralt of Rivia -- a witcher -- also known as "The White Wolf", who is suffering from amnesia when we first encounter him. This sets Geralt up as a blank slate in which it is up to the player to build up his identity from there. Our tale begins in a keep known as Kaer Morhen where witchers -- mutant monster slayers for hire -- were once trained. Geralt, still slowly recovering from recent injuries, finds himself and his companions under attack by a strange organization known as Salamandra. This criminal group slashes their way through the old keep and steals vital secrets of the witchers. And thus, the amnesiac Geralt and his band of withcers set out across the lands in search of the abducted witcher's mysteries. Your quest has the semblance of simplicity, but as your journey progresses you will come to realize that there is more to your mission than what meets the eye. With what started as a recovery mission soon evolves into fight for what's "right," thrusting Geralt in the middle of politics, a war on equality, and even love affairs. Your decisions matter in The Witcher, with consequences resulting from each choice. While you may not see the result of your actions immediately, each choice you make will come back to haunt you later on. The game offers many paths providing players with a huge amount of replayability to discover what would happen if you chose one person over the other, the elves or the Order, or just staying neutral as all hell. The characters you encounter throughout your journey are each exceptionally written with real depth and their own, realistic motivations. While the voice acting for the characters is far from superb, they get the job done and convey their ideals effectively.  The aesthetic of The Witcher is beautiful and fully realized. The soundtrack is epic and fits each situation perfectly. Whether you are engaging in a battle to the death, wandering the city streets, plundering a cave, or drunkenly meandering throughout the halls of an inn, the soundtrack compliments each situation. Speaking of which, the environments are all immersive, incredibly entertaining and quite detailed. You will lose yourself in this world for hours. Entire days will disappear playing dice poker with local gamblers, reading books, slaying monsters, or just wandering the town. While the story and the world jam-packed with lore are all extremely captivating, the combat is something to be desired. There are three different fighting styles which players must choose depending on the types of enemies one is facing at that time. The strong style deals heavy damage in exhange for slow speed; the quick style allows for fast hits with less-damaging attacks; and the group style which is useful when Geralt is surrounded by enemies. The player can switch between these styles on the fly with the various hotkeys or by taking time to press the combat pause button (the space bar by default) and assessing the battle you are faced with before heading face first into the fray. Witchers are equiped with two main swords -- a steel and silver -- and both have very different styles of combat compared to the rest of his weapons. Both blades serve a distinct purpose: where the steel blade is used to dispatch human enemies and the silver is more effective when battling monsters and beasts.Throughout your journey, you will encounter "Signs", which are essentially spells which can be cast upon your foes, or a shield to cast upon yourself. Each provide new, interesting ways to dispatch of your foes. The problem with the combat stems from it feeling clunky and dated. Controlling Geralt while in combat mode becomes finicky, making certain movements while attempting to maneuver around the enemies just plain awkward. Granted, most enemies are fairly easy to dispatch with a few combos. This problem typically rears its ugly head when fighting tougher, bigger monsters and bosses (lookin' at you,  Jacques de Aldersberg  ). With that said, another essential part of the gameplay involves alchemy. Creating potions is fundamental to your journey, whether you create health regeneration, endurance, or combat potions, each will provide Geralt with assistance. However, using too many potions at one time will build up your toxicity meter. Once this meter completely fills up, Geralt will die. To reduce toxicity, one must craft a special potion or rest at an inn or fireplace. Geralt can gather alchemical ingredients from plants you find in the fields, purchasing from merchants, and harvesting items from monsters. However, you must have knowledge of these monsters and plants before given the ability to harvest said ingredients. One can obtain this knowledge from various books or stories told by random NPCs. While I understand the conceit of Geralt researching the intricacies and ins and outs (literally) of the creatures, it is very irksome when a quest wishes for specific ingredients and you have to scour your current area for a merchant who sells the bestiary entry for your target monster. I do not exactly count this as a knock against the game, because I personally loved researching about the monster's lore, but I must say, it just feels like busy work after awhile.Along with the creation of alchemical potions, you can unlock a tier when leveling which allows for the creation of bombs and oils. The oils augment the damage done by your weapons and bombs can be thrown on the ground during combat, both providing you with an advantage over your foes. During my playthrough, a few technical issues arose. There were a few, inconsistent and unexpected crashes throughout the game: some during combat, and others while moseying through the city streets. Near the end of the game, I experienced a fairly serious crash which completely locked up my computer; I could not even access the Task Manager. Unfortunately, I ended up having to completely restart my computer. Luckily, these issues are few and far between. Be sure to save often just in case. To wrap it all up, The Witcher is a fantastic RPG plagued with minor technical issues and an odd, finicky combat system, but once you get over those humps, underneath is a rich, lively world with an experience one certainly will not forget for quite some time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												First impressions, I love games that have that learn-on-the-job-or-die intro to controls and combat. It really gets that initial thrill of the first few levels of gaming. After reading lots of negative reviews on the combat system and controls, I dunno what they're complaining about: the integrated combat styles, moves and weapons for different enemies gives it more quick thinking when enemies come out of nowhere. The timing of attack combos and chaining is also pretty nifty despite taking abit to work out initially. One downer is that I would have liked that silver sword a little earlier on in the piece, but that's pretty much it. I'm not that far into the game, granted, but another downer is the time it takes to walk/jog everywhere. AND I usually have to wait/meditate until nightfall to actually find something to fight along the way, otherwise it gets painfully boring. BUT! Even set at 'easy' difficulty, it still has that element of supreme power and mettle while in combat if one does it well. Cinematics and dialogue are decent but definitely has room for improvement on the creative side. That said, I've definitely seen worse games in that respect, so it's 'okay'. For what it's worth, price-wise it's okay but it's an old game so if you're after the true Witcher experience, save up and go for Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt or the trilogy for a little extra. Peace.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Witcher 1 is an interesting, captivating and even at times, funny game, that is if you can get past many of the little quirks that are guaranteed to annoy you, just a little bit. The main things that annoyed me is, obviously the combat. It is boring, tedious and doesn't seem very inspired, just click, wait for the mouse cursor to change and click some more, this makes the monster contracts somewhat of a chore instead of "Oh boy! A new creature to slay!" At least for me. Probably not a complaint you'll hear often, but I found the dialogue to be at times very strange, and the characters animations while talking can sometimes be very distracting. Now for some positive things about it; The story is very well done, same with the characters. It's got a dynamic weather system if you're into that type of thing, although for me, it seemed to always rain! Made it a drag sometimes, ha. I really enjoyed the poker dice game, probably a couple hours from that alone. I'd say if you're into RPG's The Witcher is something you should at least give a chance, I know I'm glad I did.

												The Witcher is one of the greatest western RPGs. As you travel along as a Geralt you face many monsters, persons, fights, magic and problems. content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												This game was a great game to play, a challenge even. Though this game is quite challenging at times, that only makes the end even more satisfying. Some parts of the game are quite unfair so preparing for missions takes just as long (or longer) whether that's finding the ingredients for the potion or helping someone out so they trust you, this game isn't just a time-spender, it's a second job (not in a bad way). The story is great and it doesn't just give you all the answers, it might even stop tracking a quest, leaving you with but a hint of what to do, so make sure you're connected to the internet because you'll be looking up answers a lot (if you want to). One of the few downsides of this game is it's hard to progress, I went through the whole game with the starting equipment because by the time you have enough money (without doing bounties and side-quests) you're in another area that doesn't sell the item you save up for! The other big problem is the fight styles, they add a great strategy feel to the game but when you're surrounded by tough enemies, you're dead, the same goes for fast-hitting enemies, because you can't block and you're surrounded, you cant do anything, attack? they interrupt, run? you're surrounded, block? you can't, even more reason to be prepared and upgrade your push spell and bring a few (hundered) health potions. Overall the story will drag you in, you'll die quite a bit on the easiest difficulty, and you'll love every second!      8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												I'm a fan of the Witcher series, ever since this game right here. It's old, the lack of fast travel, the over complicated alchemy, the very small inventory, the simplistic animations, the incredibly overpowered bosses... all this will try your patience.But if you want to know how this The Witcher III: Wild Hunt madness began, it was right here. Very well written with an intrincated story, with some plot twists and an enduring investigation leading up to a final epic confrontation. It will build up to the events of Witcher II, but also to Witcher III. In fact, there's a key moment close to the end where your decisions will make a difference in the third game. Don't play the other two games without having a go with this one. You'll appreciate the evolution of the plot, but also the evolution of CD Projekt RED in making videogames. And you'll love the technological steps taken in the trilogy.Also... it's cheap... no excuses there...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Just completed the game (didn't do all the side quests), and it definitely goes on my top 5 favorite RPG's.  The story and lore of the world created in these games by itself is so immense I felt that captivated by it's story. So captivated in fact that I even started reading the books! The book series story chronologically takes place before the game series begins, and they do a fantastic job making the world created in the books come to life visually! What's even better is that you don't have to read the books to get into the game but it often gives a player whose read them a tip of the hat with settle references to the book series non-readers would miss. I highly recommend reading the book series to really get into this world of The Witcher, but enough about that! Let's get into the pro's and cons! Skip to the recaps at the bottom of each one if you don't feel like reading it allPros: Even though this game is almost a decade old it still holds a lot of core RPG and really compared to today's RPG still feels fresh.It has a story that changes based on your decisions, which leads to my next proThis series allows you to port your saves over from game to game. The decisions you make in Witcher 1 effect Witcher 2's story, and Witcher 2 carries over to Witcher 3. Not only does the decisions carry over, but the rare items I work so hard to aquire carry over too! I have began playing Witcher 2 and I was relieved to see my armor, swords, runes, potions, etc. Were all still with me! Especially since most of the awesome rare items are only available towards the end of Witcher 1, but totally worth getting so you can have them in Witcher 2. Different points of view. Using the F1, F2, F3 you can change from bird's eye view to over the shoulder view! GIving the player the choice to play by their preference. You get to see boooooobs, and lots of them. Geralt (your character) gets some strange!The story is fantastic. Playing as a Witcher, a master of sword, magic, and alchemy set on hunting down a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sums it up BUT there is SO much content and unexpected twists.Recap of pros: Well written story, carry over decisions and items throughout the series(Mass Effect got nothing on Witcher), gettin' some strange. (Seriously, Geralt get's laid in like the first 30 mins of the game)CONS:When doing quest the NPC you need to talk to isn't always at the quest marker. So I'll be tracking it on my map, get there, and the NPC is no where to be found. That's because this game has a constant time cycle and simulates day and night. I simply have to wait (or rest to speed it up) till the certain time period for the NPC to show up again. I get it, it adds realism to the game but dammit I hate having to wait for shop keepers to show up I want to buy my items now dammit. The NPCs are massivley cloned. ALOT of NPC's, other than the important ones, look just like each other. There are a handful of character designs used for townsfolk, gang members, soldiers etc. So it kind of ruins the immerse effect sometimes. I cut Projekt Red a break though, I mean, when this game was developed it's probably the best they could do with the tech we had.  Same with the voice acting too. The special NPC's are their own voice actors throughout the series, but the forementioned NPCs I feel like was 2 or 3 voice actors. All the bandits sound the same. Compared to todays Open world RPG this game's world is small. Super small. I'm sure at the time this game was released it was very cutting edge but now adays it's going to feel like a small sandbox to the average RPG player. Still a great world though.and finally, the combat system. It takes some getting used to. After I figured it out it was very simple but just clicking on an enemy Diablo style won't work. It's click, wait for the icon, click again. Though after powering up combo's it is fun to watch Geralt slash open an enemy. Cons recap: Cloned NPC's, short on voice acting, unexplained missing quest NPCs (until undefined time of day), combat system is wierd compared to today's RPGs. Overall I give this one 8/10 Toast for Twenty's and am definitely looking forward to playing the rest of the sereis, including the books.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game. What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												You're Geralt of Rivia,a professional monster slayer (or witcher,mind you), legendary character and grade-A amnesiac. The whole charm of this game consists in the story,since the combat is.....well it's not "Morrowind: Reloaded" but it's there.So,what is this game about?  Besides stopping the evil organisation known as Salamandra,the real story here is finding out about Geralt's past(and of course,meddling in politics and conflicts,cuz Geralt is a bored witcher and if you read the books or listen to the chats with Zoltan and others you find out he's kinda running out of monsters to slay) and modeling him into what you believe Geralt was(or if you read the books bring him back because Geralt is already perfect <3).All in all,the game is pretty bad in some aspects *cough* combat *cough* but excels in other (I managed to beat a king at Poker Dice,so there's that added to the legendary White Wolf) parts like story telling and character development (of unestablished characters in the books). I also recommend reading the books AFTER playing the first two games,since knowing Geralt's story takes away from the first game. I give it a perfect 5/7 like I gave Fight Club,it's a great game and a must buy!

												This is a damn excellent game. The stat system is not mind-boggling, the action is tight and awesome looking, and the graphics are good. What really makes this stand out is the story. You will make many choices in this game, and very rarely will there be any 'right' or 'wrong' choice - they're all in shades of gray, just like in real life. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2012
												Like Dragonage: Origins? Wish it were more focused on your character, with perhaps a little more premade story? Enter The Witcher, a game adaptation of the short stories by Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a seemingly ordinary wandering warrior like you might have seen in any other adventure-RPG. But what you don't know about Geralt is...well, everything. Why? Suffice it to say this: not even Geralt knows, and it's up to you to help him find out. This is a game worth experiencing every detail as a surprise, and I won't spoil it for you.I rate this game a 10/10 overall, 9/10 in the midst of more recent and up-to-date games. I rate its combat system an 8/10 only for glitch/anomaly reasons, otherwise it would've been 9/10. The game earns a 7/10 for solidity, it has a few annoying "got to reload" glitches. Story: 10/10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's pretty rough around the edges (which is understandable given its age and place in CD Projekt Red's catalogue) but quite enjoyable. It is unlike any other RPG I've played in a while. I love the special agent/PI character that is Geralt, it's quite unique for the genre. As is the combat style. Fights (including boss fights) can be surprisingly easy or incredibly difficult based on how much you've paid attention and done your homework. For players of other series, the game has level design and exploration along the lines of Dragon Age, with a combat style that (oddly) reminds me of the Jedi Knight games.The game has many faults, though. Character assets are reused over and over with only a couple dozen unique characters in the game (surprisingly, though, this didn't irritate me as much as it might sound). Voice acting cutscenes are of a mediocre quality; not terrible but they've been surpassed elsewhere (like the subsequent entries in the series). Combat can be incredibly frustrating sometimes. For example, being stunned repeatedly by four wraiths to the point you cannot move or attack is maddening. It also felt that there were too many elements to the game, some of which can be (and ultimately have to be) ignored in favour of others. For example, I didn't get anywhere near maxing out my character (despite doing every quest) and never touched bombs. I also didn't feel all the signs were as useful as they could be; some easily overshadow others. Combat is generally quite easy (with a few exceptions).I very much enjoyed the claustrophobic, urban setting of the first half of the game. When it changed setting in the second half I was, at first, relieved for a change of scenery but the following areas (while containing enjoyable quests) are overly large and it feels like all you're ever doing is walking from point to point (with, surprisingly - compared to earlier areas - few enemies to worry about). The game also has a somewhat awkward, somewhat rewarding epilogue sequence, a huge twist (if you're paying attention) and a cliffhanger ending.Overall, I'd recommend it if you really want to play the entire trilogy. But if you're not that fussed, I'd probably suggest just reading up on what happens in the first game (and about its characters) and moving on to The Witcher 2 (where things improve and change drastically).

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												After 44 hours, I must bid farewell to the first game in the Witcher series. Let’s get straight to point: I know that most people start playing and leave the game aside after playing for a few minutes. This is mainly because of the combat system which, at first, may seem complicated and hard to get used to. We've all been there, but trust me, a few hours later into the game and you'll be enjoying both the silver/steel and rock/paper/scissors mechanic, as well as the "well-timed clicking" combat system. You'll get used to it in no time! The only complaints I have regarding the game is that it crashed about 6 o 7 times (in 44 hours, which is not that bad at all) and also that the battle against the Hellhound is the hardest one in the whole game. Yes, I know, I should have improved my Aard sign (a "spell" that fus-ro-dahs enemies) but how was I supposed to know that in the first chapter? Once you get pass this battle, you'll just get better and better and no one will stand a chance against you and your Igni sign (a fire spell), basically the best one in the whole game. In fact, I never really had any reason to use any of the spells besides Igni and Aard, even when playing on the hardest difficulty. I also never used bombs or the additional weapons that Geralt can carry. I’m not even sure what they were for, to be honest. However, I really like how they implemented the alchemy system, and how you really need to make use of it to survive. The fact that potions and food aren't consumed "during menus" but in real time is also a good idea that helps you immerse yourself in the game. I love that it’s often necessary to prepare yourself BEFORE battle if you don’t want to die… but the truth is that you’ll only use the same potions again and again, even though there are a bunch of different ones. Yeah, that reminds me of my eternal search for rebis, the basic ingredient for the regeneration potion (swallow). And well, the story is okay. In my opinion it is definitely not a masterpiece as many would say. I heard so many good things about it that I was already expecting a Mass Effect type of story, but it doesn't even come close to that, yet it's also good in it's own right. Maybe it's just... the way in which it’s told, I don't know. To me, most characters felt kind of bland, and I sometimes just read quickly through the dialogues. The fact that both the translation and voice acting were not the best did not help much either. However, I like how detailed the index is and the music is also worth mentioning, as it was always very fitting and unique. Overall, I enjoyed playing The Witcher and I feel that this is a great classic RPG. You can tell how much effort and dedication the developers have put in making this game. And apart from all this, the Enhanced Edition includes a ton of features like the soundtrack, a comic, wallpapers, making-of videos and keys for a non-DRM copy of the game. I say go for it and give it a try. Just put up with the first hours and you’ll be in for quite a ride. Don’t forget that some decisions, equipment and weapons carry over to the Witcher 2, so you’ll definitely should play this before starting the second if you don’t want to miss anything. Have fun!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Witcher 1 is an interesting, captivating and even at times, funny game, that is if you can get past many of the little quirks that are guaranteed to annoy you, just a little bit. The main things that annoyed me is, obviously the combat. It is boring, tedious and doesn't seem very inspired, just click, wait for the mouse cursor to change and click some more, this makes the monster contracts somewhat of a chore instead of "Oh boy! A new creature to slay!" At least for me. Probably not a complaint you'll hear often, but I found the dialogue to be at times very strange, and the characters animations while talking can sometimes be very distracting. Now for some positive things about it; The story is very well done, same with the characters. It's got a dynamic weather system if you're into that type of thing, although for me, it seemed to always rain! Made it a drag sometimes, ha. I really enjoyed the poker dice game, probably a couple hours from that alone. I'd say if you're into RPG's The Witcher is something you should at least give a chance, I know I'm glad I did.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Finish witcher 1, get P.H.D in alchemy Jokes aside, game is very well done, it takes some skill and common sense to get things done. Story is rich, combat's very easy to learn and alchemy may be needed to survive when overwhelmed The game has five chapters, including a prologue and an epilogue chapter, simple. You have main quests, secondary quests(contracts and leisure quests), The main missions includes hunting the salamandra clan, leaded by a zerrikanian sorcerer Azar Javed.  -Throughout the chapters you will be faced to chosing a side, the nonhuman's side or the Order's side. If you do not like either of those choices's outcomes, you could go neutral as well.The secondary quests are there to complete some bits of the story. -The contracts are what the name suggests, : You are hired to kill some monsters, recover lost items or even kill bad guys in exchange of orens. -The leisure activities consist of boxing in taverns, for example, playing dice poker with random people, from the lower level to the most advanced, even play with king Foltest. Last , but not least good is, the romance. Some women you will meet in the game will give you the option to give her a gift , if you give her the gift she wanted you will have insta sex with her. Example : in Vizima's temple guard area, you'll come across a 'Gossip' , you can ask her about a witcher in town, she'll talk about Geralt and blah blah, you will have to choose the right dialogue option and you could bring her a pair of gloves and she'll open her legs for you xD. This game will offer you AT LEAST 50 hours of adventure, perhaps even more. This is a game meant to be enjoyed, made a good job

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game. What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.

												I don't know, I have conflicted feelings on this game. First, I kinda sorta loved the main character Gerald since he has my style sense of humour. (Well, they are a bit better than that ^^') and the unique way that Gerald makes potions according to the recipies he follows, gather the necessary ingredients in order to brew the potions is really satisfactory. YETCombat sucks. Guys, I am not joking. It basically relies on how good you click on your mouse. Annoying. Yet since it is a story fueled game, I don't think it is that necessary to have a complicated combat option in the game. It would have been nice of course but hey, this is the very first game of the series and as I understand the firm was not a professional one back then. You are excused staff, be better next time you hear? (They must have since I hear the following games ARE amazing in every aspect.) Well, I enjoyed the game so far and I think I will keep enjoying it on my one and only off day. I hope you find my commentary helpful. Chicka kisses. ^.^

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Lets start with the....NEGATIVES:- The Lack of Fast Travel Hurts my Brainnn!! - Hard to find places to Meditate sometimes.- Most of the times the Mini-map doesn't work- Once any NPC is dead they come back to life after a while (I guess with the age of the game it's alright)?- Convos with NPC's can take a while to begin no ability to skip them with clicking.- Graphics a bit dated (only a bit)POSITIVES:- Amazing Lore (I Love it) - Combat easy to get into once you find out how to play (takes a while)- Really Easy at Medium (Could be a negative; I don't know about hard). This is just a bit too easy but I guess alright at the same time doesn't take out the level of fun it offers.- Great Inventory System. Helps me keep Organized the way I want. Like many RPG's you have to scan through the one thing you want. In this just organize it yourself with a huge pinboard option.- The Game assists you very well, tells you what you can sell or not.- NPC's react very well to environmental changes. Smart NPC's. - The monsters and characters all really fun to interact with.- Autosave is in my opinion NOT broken. Autosaves perfectly even saved my♥♥♥♥♥a couple of time XDOverall: Play this to begin your adventure into the Witcher world. I started by Witcher 2 and stopped as Soon as I saw this was on sale (never play Witcher 2 much anyway just like 2 hours in). My decision to buy this was worth it. I Love Geralt of Rivia now Thankx to this game. I've never read any of the books, However this game tempts me. This Game takes a time to get used to but once you get used to the Gameplay its really addicting. Other than that it does just shut off in the middle if played for long times. Idk if its my computer but yeah. You will absolutely adore it if you are fan of Fantasy RPG Elements.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The graphics are terrible by today's standards, the narration is very unemotional, the combat is ok, and there was a mass of crashing issues, but I could not stop playing this masterpiece. This was CDPR's first game ever, I even heard that they didn't know how to make a game when they decided to start this process, but somehow they nailed almost every aspect of the game. This game will probably seem crappy to those who came here from The Witcher 3, but as many have said, over the course of this franchise, the games have improved in almost every aspect. There is plenty of stuff to do in this game. You are introduced to new sections of the world after you complete a chapter, but sadly you cannot go back during the next chapter of the game. I thought I would just slash away like in Skyrim, but CDPR made combat very smart and it requires thinking. You have potions, bombs, armor, signs, and many weapons to get you through the story. The main and side quests dont feel like the 'go here and kill this for some $$$' type of quests they have stories and rewards and they are engaging. I wasn't distracted by the graphics because the atmosphere of the game was so great. You are a witcher and people hate you, but they will pay you to do their bidding. The standards have been raised a lot since this game was released 9 years ago, but if you can, play this masterpiece before the Witcher 2 and 3, and you will love it.(if you go to the game location, you can find all the soundtracks, vlogs of making the movie world maps, etc)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												This is a marvelous game. The storyline, the twists and turns, the side quests, it is all extraordinarily well done.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you are nothing short of a badass. There are very few games I truly recommend, and even fewer that I am willing to put in the time to review. This game is worth every penny. The combat system is unique, dynamic, and immensely entertaining. The alchemy system is complex, riveting and yet simple enough to understand for even the most casual gamers.The relationships you can build throughout the game are intense, and every bit determined on the paths you choose. The sex scenes are a nice touch, gives it that adult flare without being overtly pornagraphic. The storylines are in-depth, articulate, well organized and progresses the story in a very fluid manner, thoroughly explaining the backstory along the way.The sidequests are entertaining as hell, and get you that much needed relief from the overhwelming sensation of the large monumental tasks that you will have to accomplish to complete the game. The in-game "games" like the dice poker is probably one of my favorite aspects of the game, along with the "fight clubs." You can make quite a few Orens just by freely engaging in combat, or gambling. As it stands, I don't see why everyone shouldn't buy this game. Its not terribly expensive, and you will be engaged for hours.You are Geralt of Rivia, and you ARE a BADASS!That is all.

												The combat is janky, the voice acting stilted and the engine was poorly optimized for computers back in 2007 and is STILL poorly optimized today, but The Witcher remains one of the most magnificent computer role-playing games to emerge in the last decade. It's a slow burn especially by today's standards, and I needed to try this game twice before getting into it completely. Once I did, the adventures of potion-mixing, bomb-tossing, double sword-wielding Geralt the Riv totally snared my imagination, and this game remains one of the few modern titles to remind me of my all time favorite RPG/adventure series of yesteryear, Quest for Glory. Really can't give it a higher recommendation than that.

It has a pretty slow beginning and there is a lot to learn in terms of all the mechanics of the game. Combat can be clunky but I thought it was okay.For me what made this game so great was how immersive it was, not in the sense of awesome graphics, but just how deep and complex the world is, I loved reading all of the background material and the story has lots of twists and turns which for me is what helped keep me hooked and drive me forward. There are some interesting moral choices and I love that none of your choices are "the right choice" everything is morally grey and its up to you.It has its flaws but its worth it for a glimpse into the dark and mysterious world of the Witcher with plenty of unforgettable characters along the way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Witcher is a great rpg based on a series of novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. Although some of the gameplay feels a bit clunky and dated, all the rpg elements around it are top notch. The Witcher has a fantastic storyline, great world building, interesting characters, deep lore, and some difficult moral choices.The graphics are great for a 2007 game. It's not the best looking game today but is quite serviceable. The music fits the mood of the game perfectly, feeling very folksy and at home in the Witcher's medieval Europe style world.Gameplay involves questing in each of the 5 chapters. There are many varied quests throughout the game. You'll be slaying monsters, chatting up politicians, romancing ladies, gathering herbs, playing poker, bare knuckle boxing, and more!The game is long, easily over 40 hours long on a first playthrough. If you do absolutely everything it might take you much closer to 80 hours. There's definitely not a lack of content in this game.All in all, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a meaty rpg with a strong emphasis on story and setting. Also from what I hear you can import your Witcher 1 saved game into the sequel, the Witcher 2, which is reportedly also fantastic. The Witcher 3 is due out next year and looks absolutely beautiful from the screenshots and trailers. Definitely recommend starting with the first one and playing through the entire epic trilogy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												One of the finest RPGs, with a distinctly European feel. Geralt is a classic hero, a humane man trying to do his best in a conflicted situation. He has no need for cartoon brooding or snappy one-liners. Geralt's sex life has drawn so much attention that it must be mentioned here too. It is true that Geralt has sex for fun and to relieve stress, but he is not an addict by any means. One of my favorite scenes sees Geralt developing serious feelings towards his love interest. Like any reasonable man, he gets completely drunk with his friends to think things through. The world feels believable as well, with many memorable characters, both well-written and well-voiced. The story has an epic sweep, but is much closer to normal fantasy RPGs than many other things. Combat system is a bit counter-intuitive but can be overcome. Witcher 2 surpasses this but does not make it redundant, at all. I would actually recommend buying the GOG.com version instead, since the Steam version forces you to install many gigabytes of Collectors Edition bonuses.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Absolutely recommend this game. Graphics, music and gameplay were great. The camera views worked well with the style of game and fighting. Very detailed story line with many optional quests and "treasures" to find.  Your actions affect you directly, not so much like a "Fable 1" kind of way but the story changes depending on your choices.  What really pleased me about the changing story line was that some of the decisions affect you all the way throughout the game, while some are more sudden.  The AI are like real people, often going to work at the same time everyday or randomly go out shopping, so if you are looking for someone you may have to actually go look.  The spells, potions and fighting styles were all very key to the game. Has a lot of replay value because you can always go back and make a new choice in many different ortions of the game.One thing I didn't like was that they don't give you a lot of need to use/pick up any new weapons you find. Some of those weapons are great but just impracticle to use when fighting. Most of the time I stuck to the two main weapons and disregarded the others.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												The Witcher delivers a mature role-playing experience with a deep and rich lore filled with decisions and consequences. The story and writing is absolutely top of the line, and no wonder considering it's based on the Witcher novels. This is not your average hack and slash game that you will smash buttons throughout the game, instead you need to plan and time your moves. The game offers a unique combat experience that will seem complicated and hard at first but with time will have you master its techniques. But being a professional monster slayer your combat techniques won't be everything. You need to research about the different monsters that you will face and find their weaknesses to be able to defeat them and you must utilize alchemy to brew potions that will aid you.The graphics is great considering it's a game from 2008 and offers one of the best soundtracks ever composed for a video game. The voice acting is great as well.The only downside is its long loading times and inventory system.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												the Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a great role-playing game. Developer CD Projekt has corrected almost all of the problems that made the original something of a flawed gem. Butchered English dialogue has been rewritten and expanded upon, removing the nonsensical lines that made the plot something of a guessing game last year. Engine performance has been dramatically improved across the board, so the game runs smoother on moderate systems, and you no longer have time to read a magazine while waiting for levels to load. Character models have been dramatically enhanced, removing a fair number of the unrealistic features that made the original game come off as somewhat cartoonish in spots. A pair of new stand-alone adventures has been added to bulk up gameplay outside of the main storyline. by 8.5 out 10 its a great to play!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4
												Just finished playing this game, and it was quite a journey. I got gifted Witcher III as a Christmas present from my friends, but I felt I should play the first two iterations before doing so and so far I don't regret it.While the game has aged, it's not ugly looking in my opinion and although I had some issues with the game crashing and freezing occassionally, I think it might've been due to something on my end.As a master of getting distracted from the main quests and losing myself in side quests, I was quite happy to see that there was plenty of those. Some of them were kind of mundane (fetch me 10 of these and I'll pay you kind of quests), but since I'm always a greedy hoarder when playing these types of games, I was quite happy to do as many as possible.Things that got tedious after a while was all the running around. I really wanted a horse or some sort of transportation means that didn't mean having to run from point A to B. You could teleport between some areas, but not as many as I had wished for. Oh well, I'm lazy.I felt that the battle mechanics and the potions/blade coatings and magic opened up for some interesting fighting possibilties. However, since I am me, I just ran in circles and threw fireballs at everything and then wacked them in the head with the appropriate (sometimes) sword. It worked out quite fine in the end.A lot of interesting moral choices had to be made while playing this game. Some of these choices caused some NPCs to stop talking to you, while others berated you but was still willing to do business with you. It was intersting that not everything was black or white and that it could be quite tricky to figure out which choice might be the "best". Just to be clear, there are no best choice, just less bad ones.In conclusion, I feel that is was a good game and one that I would recommend to anyone interested in the Witcher's series to play. Yes, it's old so the graphics aren't up to snuff, the fighting mechanics felt a bit clunky at times, and there were some parts I had to play over as things didn't always work as they should (if this should happen to you - Google is your friend). I did like the story though and I look forward to playing The Witcher II now (although I've heard it's not as good as the first one, we'll see).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												The graphics are terrible by today's standards, the narration is very unemotional, the combat is ok, and there was a mass of crashing issues, but I could not stop playing this masterpiece. This was CDPR's first game ever, I even heard that they didn't know how to make a game when they decided to start this process, but somehow they nailed almost every aspect of the game. This game will probably seem crappy to those who came here from The Witcher 3, but as many have said, over the course of this franchise, the games have improved in almost every aspect. There is plenty of stuff to do in this game. You are introduced to new sections of the world after you complete a chapter, but sadly you cannot go back during the next chapter of the game. I thought I would just slash away like in Skyrim, but CDPR made combat very smart and it requires thinking. You have potions, bombs, armor, signs, and many weapons to get you through the story. The main and side quests dont feel like the 'go here and kill this for some $$$' type of quests they have stories and rewards and they are engaging. I wasn't distracted by the graphics because the atmosphere of the game was so great. You are a witcher and people hate you, but they will pay you to do their bidding. The standards have been raised a lot since this game was released 9 years ago, but if you can, play this masterpiece before the Witcher 2 and 3, and you will love it.(if you go to the game location, you can find all the soundtracks, vlogs of making the movie world maps, etc)

												Lets start with the....NEGATIVES:- The Lack of Fast Travel Hurts my Brainnn!! - Hard to find places to Meditate sometimes.- Most of the times the Mini-map doesn't work- Once any NPC is dead they come back to life after a while (I guess with the age of the game it's alright)?- Convos with NPC's can take a while to begin no ability to skip them with clicking.- Graphics a bit dated (only a bit)POSITIVES:- Amazing Lore (I Love it) - Combat easy to get into once you find out how to play (takes a while)- Really Easy at Medium (Could be a negative; I don't know about hard). This Game takes a time to get used to but once you get used to the Gameplay its really addicting. Other than that it does just shut off in the middle if played for long times. Idk if its my computer but yeah. You will absolutely adore it if you are fan of Fantasy RPG Elements.
