content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Finish witcher 1, get P.H.D in alchemy Jokes aside, game is very well done, it takes some skill and common sense to get things done. Story is rich, combat's very easy to learn and alchemy may be needed to survive when overwhelmed The game has five chapters, including a prologue and an epilogue chapter, simple. You have main quests, secondary quests(contracts and leisure quests), The main missions includes hunting the salamandra clan, leaded by a zerrikanian sorcerer Azar Javed.  -Throughout the chapters you will be faced to chosing a side, the nonhuman's side or the Order's side. If you do not like either of those choices's outcomes, you could go neutral as well.The secondary quests are there to complete some bits of the story. -The contracts are what the name suggests, : You are hired to kill some monsters, recover lost items or even kill bad guys in exchange of orens. -The leisure activities consist of boxing in taverns, for example, playing dice poker with random people, from the lower level to the most advanced, even play with king Foltest. Last , but not least good is, the romance. Some women you will meet in the game will give you the option to give her a gift , if you give her the gift she wanted you will have insta sex with her. Example : in Vizima's temple guard area, you'll come across a 'Gossip' , you can ask her about a witcher in town, she'll talk about Geralt and blah blah, you will have to choose the right dialogue option and you could bring her a pair of gloves and she'll open her legs for you xD. This game will offer you AT LEAST 50 hours of adventure, perhaps even more. This is a game meant to be enjoyed, made a good job

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												I'll make this short and compact:Pros: -good story-good characters-not too much stupid miniquests that have nothing to do with the plot-awesome skill trees-runs perfectly and has a lot of options-not too hard to understand-good gameplay-good franchise- sex. lots of sex.Cons:- being the first game of the franchise, it has A LOT and I mean I LOT of issues- main issue: the combat system. It feels strange, it is strange, it is VERY random and has rarely anything to do with actual skill gameplay. Ok I lied. It is COMPLETELY random and the weapons only differ in their damage (effects). That's it.-a lot of on foot backtracking and annoying enemy encounters that can't be avoided because they sprint after you faster than Usain Bolt- some quests are stupidely hard ( example: escort that 1 chick from a village to another, she dies from 2 enemy dog attacks and it's IMPOSSIBLE to keep her protected the entire time because at least 1 dog always attacks her, therefore losing the mission and forcing you to restart, bringing me to my next point)-the save system is non existant basically, as the game only ( if ever) saves every half an houri and believe me, if you forget to save yourself 5 times in 2 minutes, backtracking half an hour in this game will basically make you so mad and annoyed that you stop playing the game, like I did after multiple times where I just can't focus saving every 2 minutes because I have other important stuff to mind about in the game already.-hunky npc interaction, basically there is rarely any clue if your recent dialog helped you gain any useful information for a quest, except if you start a new one- I have yet to find out ( if I ever start playing again) if the skilltrees are actually effecting my game in any ways, because as I said above, I feel like I skill up but gain nothing from it.- inventory management is purely a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥because you never get any hints if the stuff u have in an inventory will help u later in a quest, therefore you keep them and if you drop an item and DO need it later on, you can backtrack half an hour, which kills the entire fun in this game.Conclussion: I would personally skip this game if I had a chance, but since I bought it for only 2 euros, I can't complain since this game convinced me to play the other Witcher games, which I have heard have improved a lot from the first one. I do not directly regret the Witcher 1 purchase, but would recommend skipping this one and buying the second one directly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												tl;dr 8/10 Good game, Very good story, Confusing mechanics but you will learn to love it. Pro+ awesome story+ awesome quests+ awesome world+ awesome sex with hot babeCon- game mechanics- combat gameplay- lot of walking around Full review  First game in The Witcher series from CD project red. You will play as Garelt, an amnesia-return-from-the-dead-witcher. who try to regain his memory while on his quest to get the bad guy.As a witcher you are a monster slayer, a human who train since a child with drug use until become a superhuman to slay monster (and laid girls). Too bad Geralt get amnesia and forget all his fighting skill, magic and knowledge.The witcher is RPG game with lot of things to do and learn,Story is so good it’s a pure sex, literally.Every quest have story in it.You will have to make a choice, take side, spare or kill which will impact the story later on.There is also many interesting things to do. Play dice poker, Fist fight, Hunt monster, Help random people and collect romance cards AKA getting laid. You want to have threesome with nurse? Orgy with vempires? Passionate love with sorcerer? This game have it all!!Graphic is quite good, for old game. The atmosphere and graphic fit the wolrd of witcher nicely. Music are very good too especially boss fight.Gameplay is fun. Combat? Not so much. When you attack Garelt will perform one set of sword move. When the move end cursor will change and you have to click attack again to make combo. If you click attack before or too late the move will stop. It's not that bad actually after you get used to and quite fun later in the game when you are strong but overall combat feel clunky, unresponsive and can be frustrated.Gameplay is fun and addictive but you will found yourself walking around the map doing quest. Go there, do that kinda thing. No fast travel in this game too. While I find myself enjoy the world and love exploring it. Walking around across the map many times can be boring.Game mechanics take awhile to get used to. Especially alchemy and crafting.There is a steel sword for fight human and silver sword to fight monster. There is 3 different fighting style for different enemies. There is potions, blade oils, bombs with different effect which you can make and use if you get ingredients. You will have to buy books or find information about each monster and herb to be able to collect it. And many other little thing.It will feel annoying at first but it will be a lot of fun after you get used to it. Too bad that I start to feel fun in the last chapters of the game.The witcher may have boring start with it gameplay and story especially if you have play other witcher games before. Give it a try for a few hour first before you decide to uninstaling it. Conclusion  The Witcher overall is a very fun RPG. Rich in story and charecter. Combat might not be the best and game mechanics might be confusing but worth to play and I'm sure you won't regret it.If you interesting in the witcher series from CDPR DO NOT skip this one.ps: sorry for my english.

												Having played this game multiple times through, I can 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in the Witcher story.It should be noted that anyone looking to purchase and play this game must understand that it differs immensely from its successors in many ways. The voice acting, character animations, and combat can be a little rough for some, but ultimately the game itself presents an excellent story and really pulls you in to assume the role of a witcher. You'll memorize what combat styles and Signs are useful for each monsters, learn the appearance and usage of herbs throughout the world, and you'll read and learn the lore of the Witcher.The game presents choices throughout the game, some of which affect the story later. It is up to you decide whether Geralt will take sides or maintain his neutrality as a witcher.Ultimately, if you intend to play the Witcher 2 or Witcher 3, I recommend you play the full trilogy for the full experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												TLDR: Fantastic game; Combat is not very good but story is absolutely amazing. Graphics great for 2007, obviously lackluster for 2015. Not open world. Play on hardest difficulty, because after chapter 1 game is a cakewalk. Although not needed, (really at all) the story in this game serves to clarify references in the later games and creates a bigger sense of immersion in the game world. 8.5/10 because of combat and lack of challenge.This is my Witcher story. I bought Witcher 3 because I wanted a new RPG to play; it was absolutely amazing. I only got through the first chapter and realized that I didn't want the experience to end so quickly so I decided to buy the first one and work my way through that and once done with that play through the second and then eventually move on to finish the third. That's how good this series is, if you're a fan of action RPG's with good stories like me, get the trilogy pack instead of this because if you can bear the combat/graphics (both of which are not THAT bad) of Witcher 1 you will definitely want to play the second and third. You will also enjoy them moreso because you have the background info of the first one. So I loaded up Witcher 1 for the low cost of $9.99. First thing I noticed when I started playing the Witcher was the graphics, although extraordinary for 2007, after overclocking my GPU to play the third I was a little disappointed, but you can't ask for much when you backtrack to a game that came out 8 years ago!The next thing I noticed was that this game's story is awesome. Cheesily enough, you start off with amnesia. However Geralt's lack of memory serves to push the story forward; Alongside the main conflict in the story, you are trying to find out about Geralt's past through quests and former friends. The best part about the story is that you actually can't wait to find out what happens next. This is the only rpg where I actually read the extra books and lore things you find in the game world because they serve the story so well.  Where most RPG's push for progression by enticing you with new pieces of armor or weapons down the road, the Witcher puts you in a position where you actually want to find out what happens next and you don't really care about much else. However, at times, much of the story is told just by running back and forth and talking to various npcs - there gets to be a point when you want to just go out and smash some monster face. That leads me into one of the only two fair cons to find in this game (because you can't count the graphics of this game as a real con due to its age.) My problems with this game are the combat and the lack of challenge. The fights remind me of "Test Your Might" challenges from Mortal Kombat. You just wait until your sword turns yellow and then click, thats it. The whole combat system is click, wait a second or two, click, repeat. there's no real challenge or engagement to it. If you can't kill a monster you just reload and drink more buff potions. When I say there is no challenge to this game, I mean it. I always play games on their hardest difficulty just to feel like I really did beat the game. Even on the most difficult setting, I only had a few times where I struggled at all, and only one time I actually had any real difficulty. Chapter 1's boss fight is the only time I ever found myself struggling. Other than the boring combat and lack of challenge I don't have anything else to really gripe about. I mean the inventory system could have been better and there could have been more applications for alchemy but all in all this is a fantastic game. Sorry for the long winded review.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Brilliant game, okay so some of the voice acting is a little ropey, but that doesn't mean the gameplay, or the storyline is bad, in fact it's probably one of the best single player RPG's I have played in a long time.  Surprisingly long quests, main story just keeps you coming back to complete it, potions are not bought, so no simple go to a store and buy everything you can find routine; you have to craft your potions, and prepare for anything that might happen.Combat is interesting, different styles, and different swords, depending on what enemy you may face (extremely satisfying to take out 5-7 enemies in group combat, once you have got to a certain level and enhanced certain abilities), and defensive spells you can perform, from simply stunning/pushing the enemy away (and you can perform finishing moves, on stunned or knocked down enemies), induce fear and panic, turn an enemy into an ally, or simply setting enemies on fire, or casting a shield on yourself.An overlooked game, that deserves to be in your list.

												After finishing the game, I decided to rewrite the review. So, I didn't know about the game until fairly recently, that is last year, when I played The Witcher 2. I Loved the Witcher 3 as well and have played it multiple times. I decided to play this game as well to complete the trilogy. I bought it on a steam sale for 1.5$. A steal for sure. However, I do recommend buying it for the gull price, which is 10$. About the game. It's old. The graphics don't look particularly impressive. The animations look ridiculous. Some older games have better looking graphics and animations, like Half-Life 2 (but I feel comparing this to that game is unfair since Valve was already big that time and that Half-Life 2 was a game way ahead of its time, but I digress), the combat is system isn't that great either. So, why would you want this game? The story. The storytelling. The quest design. Attention to details. If you like RPGs like I do, if you like your choices to matter, if you want a great story, this game is for you. I put 50 hours in it, completing almost every quest the game had. It's very addictive, like a good book. Play it. For the story. Also. Make sure to read the books too. They're amazing. There are many refrences to the books in this game and you'd miss them if you don't read the book. And if you finally decided to play this game, make sure to get "Rise of The White Wolf" Mod. Makes the interface much better.Very recommended, specially for Witcher fans.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												The Witcher is a Rpg where you play as Geralt of Rivia; a witcher (professional monster slayer for hire). The game has a grim atmosphere and you soon find yourself being pulled deeper into its world and lore which is only fitting for a game that is based on a series of books. Throughout the game you will encounter a variety of interesting characters whom you interact with. It is those interactions that drive the game forward. Your choices affect the outcome of the story going forward. While Witchers typically try to remain neutral you will find the game trying to push you a little bit to choose a side later in the game. And as the events unfold you are soon caught up in political intrigue. Do you side with the order of the flaming rose? (Knights). Or do you side with the Scoiatel; a band of nonhumans? Or are you able to remain neutral?As this is a mature rated game expect some mature themes and language. Yes that also means you can engage in romancing various women throughout the game to get a card featuring a risque picture of that character. The game's combat system does show its age but thankfully has been improved in the enhanced edition. It still feels a bit clunky but once you master the different stances you will find it much easier going. You use your silver sword for monsters; your steel sword for humans. There are various stances or schools for each. These allow for strong attacks, fast attacks or large sweeping attacks that hit multiple enemies. Its using these stances and the proper weapon effectively that makes the combat deeper than it looks on the surface. You can further augment your weapons using oils, or stones to increase their damage. Spectre oil for instance does increased damage against spectres. You also can brew potions from various herbs you can collect. These can provide buffs that aid you in combat or in exploration. One such potion allows you to see in dark places. Swallow increases your health regeneration. And on top of that? You have the use of various spells called signs to also aid you. Igni can light things on fire. Quen shoots a telekinetic blast that stuns enemies letting you deliver a coupe de' grace. As with most RPG's the Witcher features character progression where you gain talents or points that you can then assign to various stats to enhance your abilities. Visually the Witcher still looks decent though it does show its age. Most notably are the recycled models. Even some more important characters share models with other NPC's. There is a lot to do and the quests are generally engaging though the game does seem to have some issues with pacing. But it is amazing that a game that came out in 2007 gave players such a level of choice and presence. The Witcher is a great game and will reward you if you look past its somewhat dated systems and aesthetics. Note: Your save can be imported to Witcher 2 which can then be imported to Witcher 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												This game is definitely worth a try for folks that want a good story, a good RPG, or are really into The Witcher series.  It's a bit buggy and unrefined, but the story and characters made my journey through the game worth it.Story (minor spoilers): The game begins with an amnesic Geralt of Rivia being found and taken to Kaer Morhen, the stronghold of the School of the Wolf, where he had trained to be a witcher as a lad.  Relatively soon after, a group of bandits/mercenaries siege Kaer Morhen and steal the witchers' secrets to their famed mutagens, ingredients crucial to giving witchers their superhuman abilities.  Embolden by revenge, Geralt of Rivia sets out on a quest for answers as he struggles to regain his memory and locate the prime conspirator behind the attack.  He meets old and new acquaintances along the way, and must decide where he stands regarding several moral and political issues in Temeria.  The story is easily one of the best things about this game.  It kept me on the edge of my seat, and I appreciated the weight of most of the decisions I made throughout the game.  I felt very invested in the adventures of Geralt of Rivia and the dilemmas he faced along the way.Rating: excellentGameplay: As far as the story goes, the game is divided into "chapters," with each adding and/or barring player access to certain areas within the game's world.  The game has its fair share of combat, experience griding, and potion crafting.  Weapon and armor upgrades are precious, and your new character will spend a great deal of time without better equipment.  The combat and movement can be clunky at times, and may take some getting used to.  During dialogue with NPCs, the player has some choice regarding dialogue with NPCs, and certain choices may increase/decrease NPC disposition towards you (or, in the worst case, sign your character's death warrant), secure access to certain items, or otherwise follow through with side-questing.  There are even some humorous additions to banter and extra lore you can go through on your own time.  The game is a time sink, especially since there is essentially no "fast-travel" until Chapter 3...enjoy it while it lasts.Many folks might find the gameplay tedious after a while.Rating: fairGraphics: To be honest, they were only decent for the game's time, but they're not the reason I play this game.  Don't expect to be impressed.Rating: fairSound: The music imparts different "personalities" to each area, and there are creepy areas where the music REALLY puts me on the edge of my seat.  The soundtrack is one of the best things about this game.  The voiceacting is alright, but there are some areas where the acting is really bland...and I mean bland.Rating: fairOverall: It's an alright game, but expect to dedicate MANY hours to each playthrough.  Nonetheless, I found it to be a wonderful addition to my game library.  The story and weight of each decision I made encourages me to go back and play again just to see the different outcomes.  The sequels greatly improve on this installment.

												One of the finest RPG's I've ever played to hold a complex and compelling story, competing with the Mass Effect games. Great graphics for a 2007 release. I wasn't exactly a fan of the fighting gameplay, but I got used to it.Geralt is a badass, and his story is a wild one. Awoken and found with amnesia, Geralt doesn't try to find out his past, but rather works without it to fight for the future. Like any other RPG, there are substantial amounts of choices that could effect the game. And in The Witcher, the choices are sometimes difficult. There are sides you can take, or you can take no sides. Either way, the path to ending the game is long, so prepare for quite a wild journey.8.8/10

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												EDIT: I have over 100 hours in this game but for some reason steam didn't record themPros:-EXCELLENT Characters/Story-Great Atmosphere/Mood (NPCS's comment on the weather and run for cover when its raining)-Day and Night cycle (Lots of Monsters come out at night and disappear in the day)-Impactful choices to be made in the story that will not be made apparant at first but will hit you later on-Lots of optional quests and activites (Gambling/Fist-Fighting/Romancing the local wh*re)-VERY mature game with lots of nudity and foul-language which gives the world a refreshingly grim backdrop for a Fantasy RPG-Greatly detailed Quests/Books in the Journal-Fantastic Soundtrack-Good ending that will leave you satisfied and curious at the same timeCons:-Graphics have not aged very well-Sound is mediocre-Fighting is the worst part of this game and will keep most people from playing but I urge you play on (I will give a detailed example of what fighting is like below)-Glitchy. NPC's will many times block your path while trying to get through a small corridor and bug out while talking to characters standing in the dreaded "T" pose. (This didn't happen all that often but it happened just enough I thought it would be disingenuous to leave it out)-I Also experienced 3-4 crashes throughout the entire playthrough (Though not terrble I thought I'd mention it)-The Skill tree is dull and boring. You get points to spend each time you level but the skills  really dont offer any fun change so there is not much excitment when leveling.How fighting works in the Witcher:I will try to keep this as brief as possible. You have 3 ways of fighting enemies with 2 of them being pretty much the same. You have a Sword for Humans and you have a Sword for Beasts as well as Magic. For both Swords you have the same three styles: Strong, Fast and Group.Scenario fighting with swords:You see an enemyIs it a Human or a Beast?Ok its a BeastSelect your Beast SwordAre there more than 2?Ok there is 1 Does it look big or small?Ok its big select Strong StyleThis will be the most decision making that goes into fighting with Swords because from there you simply click the enemy with your cursor and your character will run up to the enemy and start autoattacking. After that there is a simple combo that can be done. Everytime your cursor lights up you left click and it will start the next combo with increasing damage until the 3rd or 4th combo when it will reset. This is fighting with swords in The WitcherNow things do get a tad better with Magic(Signs) and the Skill Tree upgrades but all in all its not very exciting. With that being said I still do very much recommend this game and I guarantee if you can stomach the combat for the first hour you will get sucked into the story, especially if you are coming from Witcher 3 and want to relive Geralts early days.Overall a good game with an amazing story that will make you over look the subpar combat and glitches.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I'll start out by saying that this game falls only a little short of a 10/10. The story is good. The characters, dialogue, and voiceacting are good. The graphics are good, even though some of the animations are ever-so-slightly off. The combat is "different" - whether "different" equates to "bad" depends on what you want out of the game. You're also forced to make choices about allegiance, romance, that sort of thing - regardless of how much you care about all that.What makes The Witcher special is that it's not like other RPGs, which are often more like "You-PGs". You don't get to decide whether you're a beautiful elven assassin or a hulking orc mercenary, and then live out some secret medieval fantasy you've always had. You are Geralt of Rivia: a freak of nature, maybe, but stinkin' good at your job nonetheless. Any game that can make you feel like you're actually somebody else, somebody with their own interests and issues, is okay in my book. It's immersive because the world and people feel real, even while the animations and controls remind you that it's not.8/10 for being a solid start to a solid series.

content:
Posted: January 11
												I just finished the game and loved it utterly. It took me approximately 72 hours of gameplay, but I like to do all secondary quests I can, so I'm sure it could be done much faster. I just want to recommend this game to all RPG fans out there. Unbelievable as it seems, I bought the game for 1,19 Euros at a sale. This is simply the most value I have ever got for my money EVER. The world has several different environments, and despite the aged game engine I found it very immersive to navigate the landscape. There is an enormous variety of creatures, potions, bombs, alchemical ingredients and NPCs to meet (and romance) and the depth and richness of Sapkowski's world shows through the ever growing entries in the in-game journal (with sections about characters, alchemical formulas, monsters, a glossary and, of course, quests). This is a fascinating, complex world in which hard decisions must be made, leading to different outcomes, but never being based in a simplistic "good vs evil" outlook. If you choose one given side, you will be making enemies on the other, even if you actually like both and understand their causes.The graphics are a bit aged and the combat system is rather clunky, but it is nevertheless a lot of fun. Geralt's skills evolve through a very diverse set of trees in which you can spend your gained experience after levelling, allowing for different builds and a lot of replay value.The music is also very good, and contributes strongly to the immersion.I definitely, without a doubt, recommend this game. This is a great RPG, a classic beyond any doubt, and a great introduction to the latter installments of the franchise. Unfortunately my laptop´s specs do not allow me to play the Witcher 2, but I already bought the Witcher 3 Game of the Year Edition on PS4 (TW2 was an XBox exclusive...) and I immediately felt at home, immediately encontering familiar characters, monsters and potions.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Tl;Dr Honestly hard to recommend; definitely not 2 or 3, but I enjoyed my time with it.This game is something else. It's 8 years old, and it shows its age. The combat is almost non-interactive, and is not a free roam RPG. But it really kicks off the series, and is somewhat enjoyable on it's own. It's nice to see a game where your choices matter but isn't all bioware or david cage about it. Doing different things with different paths makes for nice replayability. Making choices in this game and then seeing how you effected future events into the next games really is cool to see. The combat sucks but makes up for it for really interesting combat prep with gaining mosnter knowledge, making bombs and potions, and other ways to try and get the high ground with enemies. Running around and questing is fun. Even if the age makes it hard to get immersed in the world, it's still enjoyable to see everything.I'm definitly gonna play this again someday. Mostly so I can play the different paths and replay the entire series with different choices. But still, it's worth a visit.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Witcher 1 is a great game. However, with that stated, it should also be said it is dated. While the game's story is great and so is the Witcher universe, it does fall short of gamplay mechanics.That should be expected given the age of the game. Combat:The combat of Witcher 1 is my only true complaint. Combat is rather clunky and odd. It's built on an entire timing system where you essentially click over and over in a rhythm (depending on the fighting style). The more successful clicks at the right time, the more your combo and damage build. This simple combat system does start to get rather dull after the first two chapters. With that said, I would fully recommend this game. It's a fantastic introductory to the Witcher franchise and sets up significantly for the following Witcher games.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Alright, so this game is pretty relevant right now with the release of the Witcher 3 and whatnot. It's $10 on it's own, and on sale, it's as cheap as $1.50. I got it for that price last year and believe me, it was WORTH it. It has such a great atmosphere and takes place in a well-created fantasy world- did you know that the games were based on a book series? Now you do. The soundtrack is beautiful, too, and you get it free with the enhanced edition. Playing it really is a wonderful experience. Even if you're confused at first- heck, I was- you'll soon grow attached to it. You play a witcher, a genetically modified monster hunter, who doesn't remember his life before he, well, died. Obviously he's alive now so, what happened there? He wants to know as much as you, and in the process of searching for that and fulfilling the main plot, you have to make choices redefining his character. Choices are actually important in this game- there are three main endings, I believe, and along the way some of the decisions will have repercussions and change parts of the game.Would recommend immensely. Well worth it, offers many hours of gameplay for a single playthrough, and serves as a gateway into the Witcher series. It's $1.50 right now! You've got nothing to lose! Except, y'know, $1.50. The only real con I can think of is that it'll take you a while to adjust to the fighting mechanics. I enjoyed them once I understood them, though. And that is all. Buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												This game is full of rich content, and is thriving with life. Most of the time. Lets start with the good. It feels like an old timey RPG, with very simplistic, but addictive gameplay models. While the combat may not be supremely engaging, it can be very difficult at times, making preparation before a battle vital to surviving. All you need to do is master the almost, but not quite quicktime attack combat. The animations become more complex, and faster while requiring more timing and clicking with each improvement, making you feel like your moves are getting better and you feel all the more better. Some potions are easy to make, some are not. Some are very helpful, some not so much. But each one can save your life in a dire situation. You can make a variety of bombs, potions, and oils/weapon enhancements. Some potions even make your character more powerful in general, giving him different abilities and ways to unlock special skills.Time to talk about the negatives.The negatives of this game are few, but can really screw with you. My system is very up-to-date and has been updated to keep with the times. However, I have experienced several blue screens through my playtime. I found this extremely odd and angering since no other game has done such a thing to me in the past. Glitches are slightly prevelant, but shouldn't cause too much trouble, and sometimes, the combat can be, at some times, meh. Sometimes, grinding is a factor you might have to use, going through a dangerous swamp to find a single herb for a swallow. In conclusion, this is a great game, while rough around the edges, is very well made, and has fairly good graphics considering it was made in 2008. I strongly recommend this game, and remember, don't play the other witchers without starting from the beginning. Otherwise, nothing will make much sense in the long run.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Well Chaper 1 is terrible. The rest of the game is a pretty good old fashion RPG of the point and click combat type. Remember this is an old game and uses a highly modified 2003 game engine. It was originally intended to be a top down point and click game like Never Winter Nights. Five years later they had to up their game and they did a pretty good job considering. The game has an artistic cell shaded look to it I like.The engine mods however resulted in a less stable game engine and if I play for more than an hour at a time it will crash on game exit. Also there is an insane level of save games generated.Writing is decent fantasy type and the grapics are better than average if you ignore Chap 1.There are some irritating Adventure elements to it. By that I mean you have to figure things out like what time to be there, meditation and lots of trapsing back and forth across the map. Not really and open world but it gets more so as you go into the game. Not totally linear in that you are allowed to be good or bad or in between. Also pretty funny a lot of the times.I tend to be a completionist but I don't have to play every side quest but I generally do.It's just good enough to keep you playing if you can ignore the warts.Also there is a guide hidden in the steam game directory: WitcherEE Guide US.pdf.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												I'm writing this shortly after entering Chapter V. The reason I'm doing it now, is that the game's so intense and its world so prone to change that I fear I might not be able to have a clear mind on what I went through in the first 4 chapters after what is likely going to be a groundbreaking final chapter.I think few would disagree with the following statement: You'll both love and hate this game. At times you'll find yourself half asleep with your finger passively laying on the W key, and the only enthusiasm you might have left will be barely enough to head to the main menu and quit the game. Why is that? Because like Geralt loves saying, the game's "so full of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;.  Back-and-forth is going to take almost all of your gametime from amidst chapter 1 until the end of chapter 4, although it will progressively decrease from the beginning of chapter III onwards. I'd want to invest more time to let all my frustration for Chapter II and III out, but it would make the following considerations futile to the reader.Another thing worth mentioning is the combat. It is odd, and you'll nourish a deep hatred against it, but you'll eventually end up liking it - for the most part. I think the stances, the various disarm/stun/pain bonuses and the talents related to them are really interesting. So, regardless how bad and unfamiliar the combat moves myl feel, understanding how it works actually makes it better than click-spamming like a dumbass to strike enemies without reasoning (no reference to Assassins of Kings of course!). This pretty much sums up the game mechanics. "Wow, really? What's your rationale for recommending the game then? You basically said it's all about walking and getting over the clunky combat system." I recommend it because the story is truly fascinating and if you managed to read this boring review on its entirety you'll likely get past the hours of tedious walking and enjoy the amazing plot this game has to offer. I wish I'd played the first game before AoK, to some extent. Come back to this review and leave a comment, if you've managed to finish the Witcher without falling in love with its characters, its twists, its grey morality and the amazing narration from Geralt. Frankly, there's one thing I didn't find immersive at all: the landscapes. Because of the constant walking you'll probably start hating many of the places this game includes, one at a time.Lastly, we all refrain from being over-emotional when it comes to fictional stuff, but the first Witcher really gifted me with some good memories - sort as if it was a book - hence I guess the developers really inspired themselves to Sapkowski's work.11,06,15 EDITI've finally completed the game, and I feel I must give a few advices: don't rush it avoiding all secondary quests, unless you've picked the easy difficulty. Besides that, remember to spend some time doing alchemy: gather ingredients, read the scrolls you collect during the story. Lastly, go get the Raven's armour even if you don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about it. I'm saying this, because you'll find it really hard to beat the bosses in chapter V and the epilogue (except for a couple which can be defeated through some exploits in the stupid AI). Taking down the Zeugl was exceptionally frustrating, and I had to load a savefile from 4-5 hours back in order to gather all the necessary to take it down.Ideally, you should enter the Old Manor at level 27 or above. If you want a further challenge without going hard mode ignore this, but I fathom you might have a bit of save reloading to get along with.What is a bit ridiculous is that whilst the Zeugl and the Koshchey, that are neither mentioned nor relevant during the story, are somewhat hard to beat; bosses like Javed and the true arch enemy (which I won't mention for your own sake) are relatively easy to kill.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2013
												 The Witcher is based on bookk series of author Andrzej Sapkowski. The game provides you the story of Geralt of Rivia, the beast slayer, deep into the medieval dark fantasy, discover the Salamander plan, conflict between species. Every moments and quest plots are really polished and reasonable decisions. With strong and complex RPG elements and point-and-click combat style (Combat styles, parry, dodge, signs, and alchemy), it reminded your old school feeling and very enjoyable. As enhanced edition, most of scripts and plots are rearranged to be more outstanding. In addition, the soundtracks are really great and well-fit.The clipping issue during combat which cause Garalt's animation to be delayed and some glitch of inventory and quest tracker annoy me a little. However, they're just minor issues that I had encountered along the game, compared to overall execution. I have no doubt to say it's one of my RPG masterpiece all the time :)

												This game is full of rich content, and is thriving with life. Most of the time. Lets start with the good. It feels like an old timey RPG, with very simplistic, but addictive gameplay models. While the combat may not be supremely engaging, it can be very difficult at times, making preparation before a battle vital to surviving. All you need to do is master the almost, but not quite quicktime attack combat. The animations become more complex, and faster while requiring more timing and clicking with each improvement, making you feel like your moves are getting better and you feel all the more better. Some potions are easy to make, some are not. Some are very helpful, some not so much. But each one can save your life in a dire situation. You can make a variety of bombs, potions, and oils/weapon enhancements. Some potions even make your character more powerful in general, giving him different abilities and ways to unlock special skills.Time to talk about the negatives.The negatives of this game are few, but can really screw with you. My system is very up-to-date and has been updated to keep with the times. However, I have experienced several blue screens through my playtime. I found this extremely odd and angering since no other game has done such a thing to me in the past. Glitches are slightly prevelant, but shouldn't cause too much trouble, and sometimes, the combat can be, at some times, meh. Sometimes, grinding is a factor you might have to use, going through a dangerous swamp to find a single herb for a swallow. In conclusion, this is a great game, while rough around the edges, is very well made, and has fairly good graphics considering it was made in 2008. I strongly recommend this game, and remember, don't play the other witchers without starting from the beginning. Otherwise, nothing will make much sense in the long run.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The Witcher is not the best rpg you will play, nor is it the worst. This game is the first in the Witcher game series and since this the games have come a long way. The game was developed by a small Polish game studio called CD PROJEKT RED  back in 2007. This small team of developers did a fantastic job with this game in terms of story, dialogue and characters. The graphics are not the best you will ever see but can get pretty good on some ocassions. The story is pretty good, memorable, and well written, where every decision you make has it's consequences. The dialogue is really well done, even though i spotted a few minor mistakes in the dialogue it's nothing serious. Voice acting is not the greatest but it is ok. The characters in the game are nicely done and well written, you will meet many during this game. Some will be friends, some will be enemies and it is up to you to decide who is your friend and who is your enemy. The combat is clunky, not like a typical action RPG, here you have to click in the right time to execute your attack and with precise timing you can link your attacks into combos. The movement is bad, moving forward is the only way to go. The gameplay is quite possibly the weakest point in this game, and is so because the developer didn't really know how to make games back then, after all it is their first game but have improved much since this game. This is not a huge open world where you can do all sorts of things, but it is still fun and there are side activities and things to do like dice poker, fistfights, and contracts. Overall a solid start to the franchise that has won many over, especially with The Witcher 3. I would recommend starting with this one if you haven't played any of them, but if you have played 3 or 2 it might feel weird, unpolished, clunky and bad but once you get going you wont stop. Totally recommend it. Now go and play this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												EDIT: I have over 100 hours in this game but for some reason steam didn't record themPros:-EXCELLENT Characters/Story-Great Atmosphere/Mood (NPCS's comment on the weather and run for cover when its raining)-Day and Night cycle (Lots of Monsters come out at night and disappear in the day)-Impactful choices to be made in the story that will not be made apparant at first but will hit you later on-Lots of optional quests and activites (Gambling/Fist-Fighting/Romancing the local wh*re)-VERY mature game with lots of nudity and foul-language which gives the world a refreshingly grim backdrop for a Fantasy RPG-Greatly detailed Quests/Books in the Journal-Fantastic Soundtrack-Good ending that will leave you satisfied and curious at the same timeCons:-Graphics have not aged very well-Sound is mediocre-Fighting is the worst part of this game and will keep most people from playing but I urge you play on (I will give a detailed example of what fighting is like below)-Glitchy. NPC's will many times block your path while trying to get through a small corridor and bug out while talking to characters standing in the dreaded "T" pose. (This didn't happen all that often but it happened just enough I thought it would be disingenuous to leave it out)-I Also experienced 3-4 crashes throughout the entire playthrough (Though not terrble I thought I'd mention it)-The Skill tree is dull and boring. You get points to spend each time you level but the skills  really dont offer any fun change so there is not much excitment when leveling.How fighting works in the Witcher:I will try to keep this as brief as possible. You have 3 ways of fighting enemies with 2 of them being pretty much the same. You have a Sword for Humans and you have a Sword for Beasts as well as Magic. For both Swords you have the same three styles: Strong, Fast and Group.Scenario fighting with swords:You see an enemyIs it a Human or a Beast?Ok its a BeastSelect your Beast SwordAre there more than 2?Ok there is 1 Does it look big or small?Ok its big select Strong StyleThis will be the most decision making that goes into fighting with Swords because from there you simply click the enemy with your cursor and your character will run up to the enemy and start autoattacking. After that there is a simple combo that can be done. Everytime your cursor lights up you left click and it will start the next combo with increasing damage until the 3rd or 4th combo when it will reset. This is fighting with swords in The WitcherNow things do get a tad better with Magic(Signs) and the Skill Tree upgrades but all in all its not very exciting. With that being said I still do very much recommend this game and I guarantee if you can stomach the combat for the first hour you will get sucked into the story, especially if you are coming from Witcher 3 and want to relive Geralts early days.Overall a good game with an amazing story that will make you over look the subpar combat and glitches.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
 Wondering whether to play the first Witcher before embarking on an adventure of  Witcher 3: Wild Hunt ? Wonder no longer and go for it!Now I was there once as well. Wondering whether or not to venture back in time to explore the very first game that started this extraordinary triology. I've played Witcher 2 before and I was HYPED about Witcher 3, obviously. But there was the Witcher 1, old game that was created 10 years ago and that just seemed everything but not as fantastic looking and fast paced as the other games.  No romance scenes, only romance cards? Are you kidding me?!  And the graphics... Then there were all the complaints about how the combat system works. But I knew I just have to go for it, because it is the game that started it all. And I had to get it from the beginning.  BOY, WAS I NOT DISAPPOINTED! This game is old, yes, but it teems with an incredible life! CD Projekt Red showed their huge potential right in their first game and even if it did felt sometimes clanky and unpolished (especially the combat mechanics and the way the characters moved sometimes) it delivered absolutely amazing adventure that I played in one breath from start to finish. Witcher 1 actually has something that so many new games miss. Something truely important. A SOUL! Awesome and original characters (perfectly voiceovered - with some tiny exceptions - and with great lines delivered in the script), intriguing quests that leave you wondering and thinking about them even long after you finish them, decisions that actually seem to have quite an impact on the story, very enjoyable music and last but not least, very engaging main story that won't leave you bored in the middle of the game.Romances, although lacking the juicy cutscenes of the next two titles were enjoyable and the romance cards given as reward were actually pretty exciting! :-D (Note: My Geralt was very faithful - I romanced just with Triss without ANY exception. And when I romanced incidentally, I've reloaded the last save... Yes, I know I am crazy. :-D)And honestly? The graphics and the combat mechanics? They didn't bothered me at all! I was a bit annoyed by the way the combat worked at the start, but I quickly got use to it and after few hours even started to enjoy it! And the graphics totally enchanted me. I didn't care about low poly models and generic secondary characters. The game delivered such a great fun that I started to admire the nice little details that were hidden in the visual aspect of the game and I now say that the graphics are honestly fantastic for a game from 2007!So folks, this game... Was an ABSOLUTE PLEASURE to play and I just cannot wait to play Witcher 3 - because if the very first game was so good... Damn, I cannot even think about it without not having my hands sweaty and my knees shaking. :-D Hats down to CD Projekt Red! Thank you for delivering such an incredible title that still ignites sparkles of excitement and fun even after ten years!And now, off to play Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings for the second time. And this time, with Raven's armor on my handsome witcher body and lore knowledge that even Kalkstein would admire. :-D

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												After finishing the game, I decided to rewrite the review. So, I didn't know about the game until fairly recently, that is last year, when I played The Witcher 2. I Loved the Witcher 3 as well and have played it multiple times. I decided to play this game as well to complete the trilogy. I bought it on a steam sale for 1.5$. A steal for sure. However, I do recommend buying it for the gull price, which is 10$. About the game. It's old. The graphics don't look particularly impressive. The animations look ridiculous. Some older games have better looking graphics and animations, like Half-Life 2 (but I feel comparing this to that game is unfair since Valve was already big that time and that Half-Life 2 was a game way ahead of its time, but I digress), the combat is system isn't that great either. So, why would you want this game? The story. The storytelling. The quest design. Attention to details. If you like RPGs like I do, if you like your choices to matter, if you want a great story, this game is for you. I put 50 hours in it, completing almost every quest the game had. It's very addictive, like a good book. Play it. For the story. Also. Make sure to read the books too. They're amazing. There are many refrences to the books in this game and you'd miss them if you don't read the book. And if you finally decided to play this game, make sure to get "Rise of The White Wolf" Mod. Makes the interface much better.Very recommended, specially for Witcher fans.

There are sides you can take, or you can take no sides. Either way, the path to ending the game is long, so prepare for quite a wild journey.8.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												This game is definitely worth a try for folks that want a good story, a good RPG, or are really into The Witcher series.  It's a bit buggy and unrefined, but the story and characters made my journey through the game worth it.Story (minor spoilers): The game begins with an amnesic Geralt of Rivia being found and taken to Kaer Morhen, the stronghold of the School of the Wolf, where he had trained to be a witcher as a lad.  Relatively soon after, a group of bandits/mercenaries siege Kaer Morhen and steal the witchers' secrets to their famed mutagens, ingredients crucial to giving witchers their superhuman abilities.  Embolden by revenge, Geralt of Rivia sets out on a quest for answers as he struggles to regain his memory and locate the prime conspirator behind the attack.  He meets old and new acquaintances along the way, and must decide where he stands regarding several moral and political issues in Temeria.  The story is easily one of the best things about this game.  It kept me on the edge of my seat, and I appreciated the weight of most of the decisions I made throughout the game.  I felt very invested in the adventures of Geralt of Rivia and the dilemmas he faced along the way.Rating: excellentGameplay: As far as the story goes, the game is divided into "chapters," with each adding and/or barring player access to certain areas within the game's world.  The game has its fair share of combat, experience griding, and potion crafting.  Weapon and armor upgrades are precious, and your new character will spend a great deal of time without better equipment.  The combat and movement can be clunky at times, and may take some getting used to.  During dialogue with NPCs, the player has some choice regarding dialogue with NPCs, and certain choices may increase/decrease NPC disposition towards you (or, in the worst case, sign your character's death warrant), secure access to certain items, or otherwise follow through with side-questing.  There are even some humorous additions to banter and extra lore you can go through on your own time.  The game is a time sink, especially since there is essentially no "fast-travel" until Chapter 3...enjoy it while it lasts.Many folks might find the gameplay tedious after a while.Rating: fairGraphics: To be honest, they were only decent for the game's time, but they're not the reason I play this game.  Don't expect to be impressed.Rating: fairSound: The music imparts different "personalities" to each area, and there are creepy areas where the music REALLY puts me on the edge of my seat.  The soundtrack is one of the best things about this game.  The voiceacting is alright, but there are some areas where the acting is really bland...and I mean bland.Rating: fairOverall: It's an alright game, but expect to dedicate MANY hours to each playthrough.  Nonetheless, I found it to be a wonderful addition to my game library.  The story and weight of each decision I made encourages me to go back and play again just to see the different outcomes.  The sequels greatly improve on this installment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Alright, so this game is pretty relevant right now with the release of the Witcher 3 and whatnot. It's $10 on it's own, and on sale, it's as cheap as $1.50. I got it for that price last year and believe me, it was WORTH it. It has such a great atmosphere and takes place in a well-created fantasy world- did you know that the games were based on a book series? Now you do. The soundtrack is beautiful, too, and you get it free with the enhanced edition. Playing it really is a wonderful experience. Even if you're confused at first- heck, I was- you'll soon grow attached to it. You play a witcher, a genetically modified monster hunter, who doesn't remember his life before he, well, died. Obviously he's alive now so, what happened there? He wants to know as much as you, and in the process of searching for that and fulfilling the main plot, you have to make choices redefining his character. Choices are actually important in this game- there are three main endings, I believe, and along the way some of the decisions will have repercussions and change parts of the game.Would recommend immensely. Well worth it, offers many hours of gameplay for a single playthrough, and serves as a gateway into the Witcher series. It's $1.50 right now! You've got nothing to lose! Except, y'know, $1.50. The only real con I can think of is that it'll take you a while to adjust to the fighting mechanics. I enjoyed them once I understood them, though. And that is all. Buy it.

												It's a lengthy adventure with a lot of choices to make. Although, the story is straight-forward, it has different elements that make it awesome. The combat mechanics are a bit of a letdown, but you have 3 different fighting styles and 5 powers too, so you can use a combination of that to improve your fighting experience. The alchemy and the universe - lore - are really amazing. Although the graphics are outdated, and some npc's models recycled, the atmosphere is flawless, you can feel like you are Geralt. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												My first Witcher experience was The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt. After my first 60 hours in what is the finest masterpiece of a game I have ever played, I realized I wanted to stop and go back to the beginning of the series. The Witcher 1 is still a great game in 2016. The graphics have aged nicely. The voice acting hasn't, so be prepared to laugh at some of the characters' dialogue (I think Kalkenstein must have escaped some pocket of hell to possess an ape that then dressed as a human and lost weight).The combat is fun after you understand it. It requires semi-precise timing, patience, and does what I think the devs set out to do; give the feel of a real witcher in combat. Geralt dances around his enemies, changes between two swords, three combat styles for each sword, and delivers a cycle of blows to keep them from hitting him. The rhythm to the combat controls adds to the "dance" feel of the combat. Geralt also must prepare potions manually, and earn gold by completing side quests. At several points I found myself a few hundered orens short of an item that I NEEDED to purchase for the main quest. I can't recall many games that did this. Most games give you the items that are required for quests, and give you gold to optionally upgrade your stats. Instead, the Witcher is a true role playing experience. You will need to earn gold to progress at certain points, which is part of the lore of being a Witcher; they are monster hunters FOR HIRE. This is their job, and they need to make a living.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I am not sure how to review a game like this. I enjoyed it, but it has flaws. Reminds me a lot of STALKER in that way. Good story, and level design made me play this game to the end, but quite a few of mechanics are not polished. I am hoping the sequels address these issues.For me, the highlights of this game are characters, environment, story and music. I thoroughly enjoyed the setting, and the music is perfect. For those alone, this game deserves to be played. It is a true classic in my opinion, right up there with Deus Ex. I have not played any of the other games in the series yet, but this game has set an excellent platform for future games.The world is fairly well built. The game involves you revisiting some locations, after they have transformed quite a bit, and I think the art team has done a great job showing this transformation. There are certain levels I did not like, but that's a personal perference.The story is well told, and they do a good job of keeping the player invested. I was genuinely interested in knowing how my choices are going to impact the end game.I am now going to talk about the things I did not like about this game. Controls takes some getting used to. This game is somewhat like Mass Effect; there is no jump, or crouch, but unlike Mass Effect, the movement is very stiff. I never felt I had full control over the character actions. During combat this lack of control will get you killed a few times, especially because Geralt puts his sword away at the beginning of most cutscenes before battle, and as soon as the cutscene is over, a number of enemies will jump at you, and the delay in drawing out the sword will drain some precious health. Who thought this was a good idea? They had to have done this intentionally. One wonders what their rationale was for a silly mechanic like this.Boss battles can be extremely annoying. Just about every boss battle follows the same formula. A cutscene, followed by some dialogue and then combat begins by trapping you in the area in some manner. This may not sound bad, but considering it is not possible to save the game when you are in combat, dying would mean having to go through all the cutscene and dialogue each time. The lack of quick save and quick load only adds to the pain. This is bad game design in my opinion.Health system is needlessly convoluted. As I understand it, health regenerates automatically at a very slow rate. Eating food should accelerate the rate of regeneration, but its hardly helpful in a combat situation. Geralt has to stop in his tracks and consume food, and this will most likely get you killed. Same goes for health potions. Why the character cannot be in motion while consuming food or potions, I do not know.The dialogue and voice acting can range from excellent to goofy. Same character models are used all over the game, to the point where, you can have four NPC characters talking to each other that look identical.Alchemy is another mechanic that was not fully fleshed out. It is possible to craft a lot of potions, but the ones I used most frequently are for regenerating health faster, and then a potion to reduce the toxicity caused by using these health potions. This never made any sense to me. Why would health potions have toxic properties? Either way, I felt like Alchemy was a wasted opportunity in terms of affecting gameplay. The fact that all potions increase toxicity, meant that I had no real to use them, unless absolutely necessary.I still maintain that this game, in-spite of its flaws, is a lot of fun and it is worth playing. I am contemplating installing Witcher 2 right now to pick up where I left off.Verdict - Must play

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I'll start out by saying that this game falls only a little short of a 10/10. The story is good. The characters, dialogue, and voiceacting are good. The graphics are good, even though some of the animations are ever-so-slightly off. The combat is "different" - whether "different" equates to "bad" depends on what you want out of the game. You're also forced to make choices about allegiance, romance, that sort of thing - regardless of how much you care about all that.What makes The Witcher special is that it's not like other RPGs, which are often more like "You-PGs". You don't get to decide whether you're a beautiful elven assassin or a hulking orc mercenary, and then live out some secret medieval fantasy you've always had. You are Geralt of Rivia: a freak of nature, maybe, but stinkin' good at your job nonetheless. Any game that can make you feel like you're actually somebody else, somebody with their own interests and issues, is okay in my book. It's immersive because the world and people feel real, even while the animations and controls remind you that it's not.8/10 for being a solid start to a solid series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Ahhh The Witcher. The first in the legendary RPG series, The Witcher 1 has no shortage of adventure, victory, women, spirits, and bugs. My time with this game had been one of pleasure, with frequent splashes of annoyance mixed in. Don't get me wrong, the story and environment is masterful, but the execution of gameplay had its flaws. Being from 2008, I gladly looked past the glitches and bumps the game slid my way, and thankfully so, as this game is a must play for any RPG lover. Let me expand on just a few of my bad experiences, I will try to keep it short. If you want to see the good, try the game for yourself!First off let me say I am no strategic genius when it comes to these kinds of games. The story itself should be enough to wheel me in, with the combat and actual gameplay being a bonus. The Witcher is by no means an easy, breeze - through game. Many times I found myself stuck in an endless loop of stuns, sitting helpless as I watch Geralt's health plunge, or stuck at a part in the questline with absolutely no idea how to progress. The autosave feature works, but I find that it autosaves too far in between. There were several instances where I fought for 20+ minutes through a cave, or up a mountain, only to get pain-locked at the end and die a horribly painful death and weap as I realize my last save was at the entrance.Act II and the swamp might've been the most annoying part of any game I have ever played. Going back and forth between swamp and Vizima was a huge pain in my♥♥♥♥♥ The swamp itself had invisible walls (I know it was deep water but damn the pathing was dumb), annoying enemies, and the environment was ugly. The investigation questline in the city wasn't particularly difficult, but I did find myself walking around for quite a while mindlessly as I had no idea what to do.The combat isn't as bad as most people make it out to be. Mostly. There are many times when my attacks didn't chain properly despite being a clean hit (no parry/dodge), Geralt moved strangely and stopped attacking altogether, or my enemies simply took no damage whatsoever. All this being said, I did enjoy the combat for most of the game, and as you climb the skill ladder, the animations for swordplay becomes so much more interesting. Alchemy, regardless of the difficulty you chose, is almost a neccesity for some of the game.The graphics are bad, but considering this game is getting so old, it's only fair to look past them. Graphics rarely make or break a game, but here you can definately tell how outdated this game is.Overall, the PROS largely outweigh the CONS, and I truly believe that this game is a must - play for all RPG fans out there. With a crisp storyline, decent gameplay and likeable dynamic characters, this game will remain a fond memory of mine for years to come.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I am primarily writing this review to those who are already fans of the franchise and have played TW2/TW3:I enjoy older RPGs, but this is the only one I've played that actually feels dated. I'm a huge fan of the Witcher series, I've read the novels, and played through TW2 & TW3 countless times. Do not expect the quality of this game's sequels, as it is just not there. This game feels like a dumbed down version of KOTOR, assumedly because it runs on a dumbed down version of the engine BioWare used to use. Combat is rather boring, and the only time it engages me is when it doesn't work right and annoys me.Many will say that in the Game's defense, the story and quests are very well written. To that i say hogwash. Many of the quests are very poorly written, shoehorn in sex, or just have boring premises. The main quest writing is decent, and there are a few characters that are interesting and fun (Siegfred, to name one). Now, while A LOT of the quests are very bad, the quests that ARE done right are actually entertaining. These are few and far between, and the things that do make them entertaining are usually the charcters or the choices that the game provides. A few questlines have segments that require a major decision, and a thing I love about the game is how it really remains gray. It is not clear what is right or wrong, and you must decide which is the lesser evil. Many other games claim this feature, but usually after you make said decision the truth will be revealed through a conversation or a scene showing you were wrong and fell for the bad choice. Not The Witcher. You truly have to think about the decisions you make, and the parties that you will affect through your choices. Many of these quests are very obvious rip offs from the series of books this franchise is based on, but are entertaining nonetheless. I recommend this game, but ONLY to fans of the Witcher franchise. It contains a few interestng segments, and it's story and characters are referenced throught the next two games, but is overall boring and mundane with a few highlighted segments. If you're new to the franchise, you'd be better off picking up TW2. For the most part, this feels like a game that had a good team behind it and had a good vision of what they wanted this game to be, but didn't quite know how to implement it (this WAS their first game, and they did not recieve much funding) resultng in a barely average product.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												My first Witcher experience was The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt. After my first 60 hours in what is the finest masterpiece of a game I have ever played, I realized I wanted to stop and go back to the beginning of the series. The Witcher 1 is still a great game in 2016. The graphics have aged nicely. The voice acting hasn't, so be prepared to laugh at some of the characters' dialogue (I think Kalkenstein must have escaped some pocket of hell to possess an ape that then dressed as a human and lost weight).The combat is fun after you understand it. It requires semi-precise timing, patience, and does what I think the devs set out to do; give the feel of a real witcher in combat. Geralt dances around his enemies, changes between two swords, three combat styles for each sword, and delivers a cycle of blows to keep them from hitting him. The rhythm to the combat controls adds to the "dance" feel of the combat. Geralt also must prepare potions manually, and earn gold by completing side quests. At several points I found myself a few hundered orens short of an item that I NEEDED to purchase for the main quest. I can't recall many games that did this. Most games give you the items that are required for quests, and give you gold to optionally upgrade your stats. Instead, the Witcher is a true role playing experience. You will need to earn gold to progress at certain points, which is part of the lore of being a Witcher; they are monster hunters FOR HIRE. This is their job, and they need to make a living.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Definitely not perfect, this game focuses on good storytelling and interesting lore to entertain the player. The combat in The Witcher is pretty abysmal, though not totally unplayable. It is repetitive, though the storytelling and roleplaying aspect of the game compensates for this. However, despite its flaws, The Witcher is an amazing game. It has real consequences for your decisions, and their impacts are usually not revealed until later in the game. This makes the world feel more believable, as you feel real regret for some of your decisions. The world itself is also unforgiving, as it properly portrays the way society operated during the dark ages. Plague, monsters, and men terrorize and instill fear in many. The world isn't a pretty place, but that makes it all the better when you're able to rise above your greed, and help better the world you live. Or you can take the opposite approach and take advantage of the people's problems, becoming rich and powerful. Ultimately, this is a great RPG, though the gameplay may suffer from dated technology. The Witcher is a great game to pick up, especially if you plan on playing the later installments of the series.edit: Don't play on hard! The end of the game is just so frustrating that you may end up either getting cheats, or quitting. There's no way to change difficulty once you've started!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												The Witcher  has an awesome story and likeable characters. When I was playing this game it felt  like I was reading a page turning novel with all the twists that were occurring. This game forces you to make difficult decisions that are not black and white. The consequences of your choices are not shown until much later in the chapters of the game therefore deterring any loading of previous save files. Not enough games seem to follow this form of decision making but I appreciate The Witcher for not following the norm.  I like this because it forces you to actually learn to live with the consequences unlike other games where you can reload and change your choice in a millisecond.  The difficulty is challenging and I must stress on preparation if you wish to succeed in The Witcher  It is a hard game and the main way to succeed is to prepare ahead of time. This means you have to stock up on potions and oils. This game is very hard and it will not hold your hand if you are having difficulties.  Unfortunately, this game has a lot of faults like crashes and  npcs not showing up to begin side quests. I also had constant graphical glitches. For instance, beard and hair would glitch out making them flap constantly. A big issue was that I could not graphically optimize the game for my PC. I know my rig could handle it but the game would only allow me to run it on medium settings. If I ran it on higher settings the game would stutter or crash. The New Adventures mode I found to be fun but only two stories are voice acted and the rest is silent. It also can be very glitchy such as constantly dodging enemies.. However, with all these faults, I can still  recommend this game because of the awesome and intense story. The Witcher makes you feel like a monster hunter and I promise that you will not be disappointed. If you love a game with a great story and enjoy challenging gameplay then I would say to add this game to your library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
 A FLAWED CLASSIC This is an adult, fantasy story full of beauty, darkness and complexity. There is a lot of European mythology, lots of political subjects and lots of magic. There is a ton of lore within the game, so it's wise to read the books, talk to the NPC's and go through the game a second time to get every bit out of this game. One thing this game does very well is make you question every choice you made in the game because it's never clear that you are fighting for the better cause. To put it short: I did my best throughout my playthrough to be a good person. This game does a great job at investing you within it's story and world.  PROS  Beautiful world to explore with tones of lore Story is amazing Soundtrack fits this game perfectly  Graphics are great and the FPS is smooth Choices matter and make you think Great ending CONS  The voice acting can be god awful at times Not the easiest game for anyone to get into Tons of fetch quests Combat is clunky Clumsy interface Most of the items you collect are pointless unless you play it on hard BRO POINTS  You can have sex with women to collect cards like Pokemon! Geralt is a BOSS! An adult game! FINAL THOUGHTS It has a lot of short comings, but the story and setting is so rich that it overcomes all of that and then some.This a game for true RPG fans. If you already played through your favorite RPG's and are looking for a new series to get lost into.. This is the one. Like any great gaming trilogy.. Play the first one to truely get the real enjoyment out of it.Plus it's ALWAYS on SALE!!! No excuse to miss out.9/10

												This game is absolutely amazing. I can't believe how much fun I had with this game, it really holds up to today's standards in my opinion. 												 The Witcher is based on bookk series of author Andrzej Sapkowski. The game provides you the story of Geralt of Rivia, the beast slayer, deep into the medieval dark fantasy, discover the Salamander plan, conflict between species. Every moments and quest plots are really polished and reasonable decisions. With strong and complex RPG elements and point-and-click combat style (Combat styles, parry, dodge, signs, and alchemy), it reminded your old school feeling and very enjoyable. As enhanced edition, most of scripts and plots are rearranged to be more outstanding. In addition, the soundtracks are really great and well-fit.The clipping issue during combat which cause Garalt's animation to be delayed and some glitch of inventory and quest tracker annoy me a little. However, they're just minor issues that I had encountered along the game, compared to overall execution. I have no doubt to say it's one of my RPG masterpiece all the time :)

content:
Posted: January 30
												So, I just finished this game after spending 86 hours. I like it very much and I recommend it to everyone looking to pick up an RPG game.Pros:- Story is very good. There's a lot of lore that you can explore.- Lots of quests that you can do so you will never get bored. Personally, I even did many side quests which is why I took so long to finish this game and yet, I still missed some of them.- There are three types of fighting styles you can use. You can choose whether you want to exclusively use sword skills (easiest) or signs (hardest) to fight enemies throughout the entire game or you can also use a combination of both sword skills and signs (balanced)- This is a "choice matters" game which means every choice you make throughout the game affects the story. There are three story paths you can take: the Order (Knights/Humans), the Scoia'tael (Elves/Non-Humans), or Neutral (Witcher).- Due to this game having three story paths, it has a pretty decent replay value.- SEX. Many girls that you can sleep with. You get a card showing all their goods after sex scenes (there are no actual sex scenes). Cons:- The game game gives you an error that says you don't meet the minimumum specs when you first launch it requireing you to use the"-dontforceminreqs" launch command even though you have the hardware to run this game. Many people complain about this even to this day.- Due to using the "-dontforceminreqs" command, texture quality is set to low and is disabled in-game making graphics look ugly. This requires you to download a mod (search the discussions section of this game for said mod or use Google).- The game has crashed multiple times on me. Usually this isn't a problem for me but when multiple crashes happen one after the other, then it becomes a problem. Not to mention that on some crashes the game stays on a black screen with audio still playing but I can't alt-tab out of the game which requires me to switch to another user account and end the game process on that account. Luckily, I've made it a habit to save often in games where you can create manual saves or I would have lost plenty of progress throughout my playthrough. - No native controller support. Given that this game is pretty old, I can't really complain about this. It would be nice if this game had controller support though. Yes, I am aware that there are programs out there that I can use to map keyboard keys to controller buttons but that requires a lot of work.- Combat system seems a bit slow. Also, sometimes, Geralt attacks another enemy when I am clicking on another enemy.- This is a linear game so exploring is limited. Speaking of which, if you pick up quest, make sure you finish that quest on the chapter you picked it up at because you may not be able to access the area or talk to the people you need to complete said quest due to being relocated to another place when you progress to the next chapter.Overall: Despite this game's flaws, it's still a pretty solid game. If you're looking for a game you can sink many hours into, then this game is for you. It has lots of content and the story is very good. I highly recommend this game. Rating:Story; 9/10Graphics: 8/10Gameplay: 7.5/10Enjoyment: 9/10
