content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												While the game's graphics are a bit unappealing, the English voices are emotionless and combat system might not be for everyone, the world presented in the first part of the Witcher trilogy is truely rich and wonderful and I, without a doubt, can recommend playing through this game despite the issues brought up above. The world of Witcher is deep and pretty damn interesting, running off several books released by a Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski many years prior to this game. Despite that, knowledge of the books is not required, as the main character suffers from amnesia (someone who didn't read the books might call it immersive, even?).For fans of the oh so popular Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, this is a 'must play'.Also, make sure to play with Polish voices if you'd like to hear more emotion in them! They are vastly superior to non-Polish ones and you can keep your subtitles set to English (or other) language at the same time. Plus it's a good way to learn languages.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												I'm writing this shortly after entering Chapter V. The reason I'm doing it now, is that the game's so intense and its world so prone to change that I fear I might not be able to have a clear mind on what I went through in the first 4 chapters after what is likely going to be a groundbreaking final chapter.I think few would disagree with the following statement: You'll both love and hate this game. At times you'll find yourself half asleep with your finger passively laying on the W key, and the only enthusiasm you might have left will be barely enough to head to the main menu and quit the game. Why is that? Because like Geralt loves saying, the game's "so full of♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;.  Back-and-forth is going to take almost all of your gametime from amidst chapter 1 until the end of chapter 4, although it will progressively decrease from the beginning of chapter III onwards. I'd want to invest more time to let all my frustration for Chapter II and III out, but it would make the following considerations futile to the reader.Another thing worth mentioning is the combat. It is odd, and you'll nourish a deep hatred against it, but you'll eventually end up liking it - for the most part. I think the stances, the various disarm/stun/pain bonuses and the talents related to them are really interesting. So, regardless how bad and unfamiliar the combat moves myl feel, understanding how it works actually makes it better than click-spamming like a dumbass to strike enemies without reasoning (no reference to Assassins of Kings of course!). This pretty much sums up the game mechanics. "Wow, really? What's your rationale for recommending the game then? You basically said it's all about walking and getting over the clunky combat system." I recommend it because the story is truly fascinating and if you managed to read this boring review on its entirety you'll likely get past the hours of tedious walking and enjoy the amazing plot this game has to offer. I wish I'd played the first game before AoK, to some extent. Come back to this review and leave a comment, if you've managed to finish the Witcher without falling in love with its characters, its twists, its grey morality and the amazing narration from Geralt. Frankly, there's one thing I didn't find immersive at all: the landscapes. Because of the constant walking you'll probably start hating many of the places this game includes, one at a time.Lastly, we all refrain from being over-emotional when it comes to fictional stuff, but the first Witcher really gifted me with some good memories - sort as if it was a book - hence I guess the developers really inspired themselves to Sapkowski's work.11,06,15 EDITI've finally completed the game, and I feel I must give a few advices: don't rush it avoiding all secondary quests, unless you've picked the easy difficulty. Besides that, remember to spend some time doing alchemy: gather ingredients, read the scrolls you collect during the story. Lastly, go get the Raven's armour even if you don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about it. I'm saying this, because you'll find it really hard to beat the bosses in chapter V and the epilogue (except for a couple which can be defeated through some exploits in the stupid AI). Taking down the Zeugl was exceptionally frustrating, and I had to load a savefile from 4-5 hours back in order to gather all the necessary to take it down.Ideally, you should enter the Old Manor at level 27 or above. If you want a further challenge without going hard mode ignore this, but I fathom you might have a bit of save reloading to get along with.What is a bit ridiculous is that whilst the Zeugl and the Koshchey, that are neither mentioned nor relevant during the story, are somewhat hard to beat; bosses like Javed and the true arch enemy (which I won't mention for your own sake) are relatively easy to kill.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
 A FLAWED CLASSIC This is an adult, fantasy story full of beauty, darkness and complexity. There is a lot of European mythology, lots of political subjects and lots of magic. There is a ton of lore within the game, so it's wise to read the books, talk to the NPC's and go through the game a second time to get every bit out of this game. One thing this game does very well is make you question every choice you made in the game because it's never clear that you are fighting for the better cause. To put it short: I did my best throughout my playthrough to be a good person. This game does a great job at investing you within it's story and world.  PROS  Beautiful world to explore with tones of lore Story is amazing Soundtrack fits this game perfectly  Graphics are great and the FPS is smooth Choices matter and make you think Great ending CONS  The voice acting can be god awful at times Not the easiest game for anyone to get into Tons of fetch quests Combat is clunky Clumsy interface Most of the items you collect are pointless unless you play it on hard BRO POINTS  You can have sex with women to collect cards like Pokemon! Geralt is a BOSS! An adult game! FINAL THOUGHTS It has a lot of short comings, but the story and setting is so rich that it overcomes all of that and then some.This a game for true RPG fans. If you already played through your favorite RPG's and are looking for a new series to get lost into.. This is the one. Like any great gaming trilogy.. Play the first one to truely get the real enjoyment out of it.Plus it's ALWAYS on SALE!!! No excuse to miss out.9/10

content:
Posted: April 22
												Fairly good RPG game with a weird timing-based combat system, but it really shines when you play the other witcher games.First off, the game hasn't aged very well, I think this is the thing people are usually critical about when talking about the original Witcher game (that and the weird combat). This game suffers from what i'll refer to as ''the corridor syndrome'' : Almost every area has it's specific path (meaning you can see a location from above/below, but are unable to cut through to reach it, having to go all the way around instead), which withers the open world-ish concept it goes for. Also can't jump in this game (or in the 2nd for that matter.) The game also comes with a set of extra stories you can play which add to the universe and lore.The story is where the game shines. While it's definitely not the best scenario in this kind of game, but it is complete enough and gives you enough information on the characters and the lore that you will not regret having played it once you play the other 2 games. It starts where the witcher book series ended, when Geralt of Rivia dies. He wakes up in Kaer Morhen, having lost his memory but surrounded by friends, so he has a place to start searching for a cure for his amnesia.  Overall, this is a great experience for people interrested in Witcher lore and wish to learn more about Geralt. It's especially good if you've played W3, as it sets up plenty of the plot points and characters from that game.

												I really want to play The Witcher 3 but I felt the need to play The Witcher 1 and 2 first. I am about 30 hours into The Witcher 1 but I have completely lost my self in this game! I can't get enough of it. The decisions you have to make in the game are hard ones. I find myself stressing about what sides to take. I feel like a lot of people dislike the combat that is in the game, and at first I wasn't a fan. But you will be doing more role playing then fighting in this game, and after the first chapter I really found that I was starting to enjoy the combat. This game is definitely old, and you definitely have to get over that to play it. I installed some mods when I first started playing but I found playing with out them was more enjoyable. I would say I enjoy The Witcher 1 more then any AAA game that I have played in the past 3 years. Play The Witcher 1 you'll probably enjoy The Witcher 2 and 3 more if you do.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Many poeple complaints about the combat system of Witcher 1, but i think the most oustanding part of this game is the combat system and its relevant supporting system -  portions and the dialogue of monsters. The game requies you "think' and change the attack mode rapidly to deal with diiferent emenies - humans and monsters.Two swords and three attack  modes; strong, quick and group mode, you have to chose which attack mode is the most suitable for the foes and the situation. Different emeny may requires you using different strategy to deal with. Somtimes you have to use different potions  on your sword to enhance the damage to particular type of emeny. And sometimes you have to fortify your resistance or mana and health regeneration. Before each mission, you have to prepare certain potions to  unforeseen situation later. You also have to gather the books  of the monster (which gives you weakness of the monster) and the formula of the potions in the game to preparation. All the above mentioned featues make the combat system unique, complex and really worth spend time in the exploration. Althoug the story may not be so epic for me and certain main quest requires you travel  forward and backward of same road many times (it really♥♥♥♥♥♥off me), if you want to learn more about the story of Geralt and Triss, I think this game give you quite amount of information and worth you to play.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												What is both sad and funny is that people who pick up this game get disappointed by its clunky controls and lack of active block/dodge/parry, as in there's no button to press to block, dodge or parry, also double-tapping a direction might show you dodging or sidestepping but it gives no invisibility frames whatsoever, in the way Dark Souls games do.The reason why this fact is sad and funny is because by design the Witcher is meant to be played in an isometric camera view, using mouse clicks to move around and mouse clicks to attack. Hell, spacebar is even used for active pause, something that games like Neverwinter Nights, Divinity: Original Sin, Pillars of Eternity and Baldur's gate have. Another hint that indicates that this game is meant to be enjoyed as a traditional isometric Western RPG instead of the Dark Souls experience people expected to get.Don't get me wrong, I love Dark Souls games, and Witcher 3. This isn't a criticism against character RPG's where people's reactions are rewarded. This is a criticism towards people who approach Witcher 1 as if it should behave like Dark Souls or even Witcher 2 and 3. Share of the blame goes to CD Projekt's decision to put Over-the-shoulder camera as an option, something that adds spice to pure 1vs1 encounters.The moment I decided to give a go to the isometric camera my opinion on this game shifted. If you're into traditional isometric games you're in for a treat with Witcher 1, assuming you don't know that already. And also try to use a mod called Full Combat Rebalance 1.6 on either easy-easy difficulty or easy-normal. It makes things a lot closer to how the books are. Apparently the person who made the FCR mods got hired by CD Projekt and the mod itself is included in the Platinum retail versions of the game.Further proof that Witcher 1 is meant to be enjoyed as an isometric RPG is the fact that they used Aurora Engine to make it. Guess what other games use it http://www.giantbomb.com/aurora-engine/3015-1468/games/.So tl;dr treat Witcher 1 like a standard isometric Western RPG with a predetermined character and a good story and you won't be disappointed. Throw Full Combat Rebalance mod in the mix and you'll find yourselves using the "pause" function frequently to plan your fights on the fly. In case you're not into that you can either treat it as a subpar Dark Souls game or just watch a recap video and jump to either Witcher 2 with Full Combat Rebalance 2 or Witcher 3.P.S.: I play the GOG version of the games so the time played on Steam doesn't reflect my real one.

												Absolutely outstanding. I'm sure I'll get flamed for saying this but I like it better than its sequel. I love both but something about the original just suits me better. Graphics are still very nice maxed out. The story, presentation, quests, weapons, crafting, magic are all excellent. I got it during the sale but it would have been worth it at full price. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												A great action RPG set in an incredibly well crafted world. I was thoroughly drawn in by the lore and fell in love with the franchise within the fist few hours. A great story with an intriguing protagonist with a pretty unique position within the world make for hours of compulsive playing.The Witcher is set in a dark fantasy world where the lines between good and evil are severely blurred and the results of your actions are not always immediately evident. Players navigate through dialogue as they see fit and cannot simply stick to the Paragon/Renegade dialogue options to come out as a saint or a sinner at the end of the game.A personal highlight of The Witcher for me is the Inns and I found myself dashing straight for the nearest drinking hole whenever I hit a new town. These taverns serve as the hub of a town and serve not only as a place to rest and manage your inventory, but contain a variety of interesting characters to give you additional quests for the area and a small selection of mini games. I would recommend The Witcher to anyone one likes to get immersed in a game world and enjoys roleplaying games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
A masterpiece!The Witcher is the result of when a team of doctors work together to develop a video game. I will go on record saying that this is one of the absolute best games ever made. I've done 4 playthroughs total of this game and have not gotten bored. Witcher 1 has one of the most well written storylines of any RPG ever. A lot of RPG games trap themselves with moral decisions by making them purely good or evil choices. There's no black or white extremes in The Witcher though. Almost all characters in the entire world of the game have done good and bad things. It's this important difference that sets The Witcher apart so well. Some of the moral decisions and choices you have to make in the game will really cause you to stop for a moment and reflect on the situation. It's a game that has such powerful choices that it will literally make you reflect on your own morality. When does the means justify the ends? Where does somebody draw the line? Can bad things be jusitfied for a higher cause? These are a few of several questions you will ask yourself by the end of this masterpiece. The characters of the game are also unforgettable. Geralt the protagonist is a badass who you definitely can't help, but be a fan of. NPC's in the game are wonderful too and you can have discussions with them that add more to the world and story of The Witcher. Beyond the story, the gameplay is great too. The combat system is a fun timing based system where you click at the right times to do combo attacks. In addition, you get signs which can knock down enemies, set up instant kills, light enemies on fire or trap them etc. Defeating enemies grants you EXP along with completing quests. You then level up after accumulating enough EXP and can distribute talent points into Geralt's abilities. Witcher's leveling system for increasing Geralt's strength is incredible. The amount of choices and possibilties are wonderful and every playthrough I always found myself trying out different builds. Witcher 1's combat is incredibly fun, but I won't lie it's far from a amazing combat system or one that will appeal to everyone. Some may just not like the timing nature of the combat system. It's not for everyone and you have been warned about this. Also, I mentioned quests. Witcher does have them.They are found in the main story and sidequests. You can track quests to figure out where to go and it works very well. Witcher's sidequests are excellent though and a standard that RPG's should look up to. Almost every sidequest has a great story to it that upon completing it allows you to learn more about characters, the world and the story of the game itself. A sign of a well made sidequest is when the player doesn't just do it for a great reward in the game, but also for the content of the quest itself. That's another aspect Witcher excels in. There's as I mentioned a main story consisting of a prologue, epilogue and 5 chapters inbetween those two. Each chapter you go through in the game is drastically different. In one you explore a village and help the residents there, but come to learn of some of the atrocities the residents have committed there. It ultimately reaches a climax where you must judge the villagers and decide their fates. In another chapter you go to meetings with nobles and powerful polticians where you form strong alliances with powerful people. Then there's a chapter in the game where you have to cooperate with a detective to figure out who committed a murder. The chapter has several different outcomes depending on the choices you make. Different events, dialogue and fights happen all depending on what choices you make. Ultimately, the game's story reaches it's climax in the epilogue and final chapter of the game Chapter 5. Chapter 5 is one of the most epic parts I've ever played in a RPG. Afterward, in the epilogue you confront the final antagonist of the game whom makes references to all the decisions you made throughout the game. Even me doing a sidequest in Chapter 1 was mentioned in the final confrontation of the game. Talk about a game truly changing even by doing small things. The replay value is immense.In Witcher 1 there are three paths through the game. I won't spoil the three sides, but each one has different scenes, dialogues, locations and fights you experience in them. I'm no fanboy either though and will admit the game doesn't drastically change depending on your decisions. It does change a little, but you're not gonna see half of the entire game change because you aligned yourself with a different side in a future playthrough of the game. Still, the replay value is great and it's the choices making these little changes that make this wonderful game all the more satisfiying to play through. Last, the music.The music of Witcher 1 is excellent. I'm not much of a fan of orchestrated music, but The Witcher really caught my attention with it's jaw droppingly good soundtrack. Some of the songs in the game such as The River of Life or several others really impressed me. In terms of voice acting, the game can be a mixed bag. Some voice acting is good, but some are not so good. Overall though, The Witcher is a masterpiece and one of my all time favorite games. I think that the world and story of the game are among the very best in any game ever. Beyond that, the combat is very fun, but admittedly is not going to be for everyone and is far from one of the most amazing battle systems ever. Last, the game has a great soundtrack and immense replay value with how choices impact the game. Any RPG fan owes it to themselves to experience this masterpiece of a game. I've finished 4 playthroughs of it and I will definitely play it more times through.TLDR Version:Pros:+One of the best stories and worlds in any RPG ever.+Great characters who are incredibly well developed.+Choices that affect how the game plays. Three main sides to choose from in the game each one giving the player a different experience.+Fun combat system that while not amazing or super great is still awesome.+Incredible amount of customization upon leveling.+Excellent soundtrack.+Extremely well done sidequests that players will want to do because the content of the sidequests adds more to the world and story of the game.+The developers CD Projeckt Red are a role model in a industry that screws gamers over. They give out DLC free and all updates or changes they make to their games are free. Also, they make all their games DRM free.Cons:-Outdated graphics even for the time.-Reused character models for NPC's.-Combat system isn't absolutely incredible and won't appeal to everyone, but it's a lot better then most games out there.-Main plot goes in too many directions and some of the directions it goes in are left as loose ends and never wrapped up by the end of the game. In other words, a little too ambitious for it's own good at times.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												So, the question: Should you buy The Witcher: Enhanced Edition? Well, if you had put off playing The Witcher, there's no better time to start. For the price, the TW:EE pack has a tremendous amount of value and the sort of extras usually only found in a Collector's Edition. It's still a marvelous game, and everything included fixes most of the nagging flaws that were initially present. If, on the other hand, you do have The Witcher, then don't bother — not because it isn't worth it, but because absolutely every part of TW:EE is free to download online from the official Web site. All of it: the guide, the map, the making-of videos, the adventures and the new translation. If you don't have a speedy, unlimited Internet connection, or if you want physical copies, then you may of course wish to purchase the boxed version, but it's fantastic for fans of the game that they've been rewarded in such a way.If you didn't buy The Witcher before, then you've got little excuse now. And if you did, then The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is the perfect opportunity for a second playthrough

It took me 45 minutes to kill Stone Golem with Igni and sword, because I didn't realize that I should use fraking stones to fry that ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Also died 15 times against Spider Queen (she kills in one shot) until I realised that I can kill her with crushing ceiling on her head. Awesome game. Quests are different than other RPG games. Ofcourse there are those typical quests: kill some enemies, bring that etc. but there are some awesome quests. For example, one side quest: You have to find sister of some knight. You find out that she became vampire and you have two choices: 1. Kill all vampires or 2. have sex with 3 vampires and leave girl there (my choice ). I won't tell the outcomes of both decisions. This is just unimportant side quest. There are lots of other side and main quests that are unique (get drunk with friends and then try to steal grandmas diary, trust me, it isn't that easy, granny is pain in the a*s :D)9/10

DO IT!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Based on Andrzej Sapkowski's character and world, The Witcher is a finely crafted Dark (with a capital D) fantasy adventure that any fan of RPG's should play. Be aware though that this game is very mature and should not be played by kids. Sure there's the sex scenes but more importantly, it deals with mature themes that require a little world experience to fully comprehend and thus, I only recommend this game for adults.The game features a Witcher, Geralt of Rivia, who travels to the city of Vizima to investigate an attack on The Witcher's home castle. Witchers are a dying race of humans subjected to experiments and magic in order to make them into the perfect monster hunters. Despite being necessary in their monster-infested world, Witchers are treated with disdain by most people and tolerated only by those requiring their services. Geralt of Rivia has had many adventures already throughout Sapkowski's five novels and numerous short stories featuring the character. Unfortunately for us foreigners, the books were never translated until after this game was released. Because of this, the game utilizes an amensia story that, while never fully realized, is a huge help to those of us who are just now being introduced to the character. There are some references to the stories that are undoubtedly more meaningful to those who've read them but I never felt lost despite having no prior knowledge of the series.While the combat is fun and requires a unique sense of timing and preperation to master, the storyline is really the biggest draw to this game. Many previous games have attempted to capture the meaningful sense of choice and impact upon the storyline but few are as successful as The Witcher, primarily because it isn't about good versus evil. Some choices will clearly have a moral facet to them but even those aren't clear cut, even if you usually play games a certain way. A decision that you will need to make throughout the game involves the conflict between the Scoia'tel and the humans in charge. It's clear from the beginning that non-humans are consistently abused and oppressed by the human-dominated society and the Scoia'tel want to change this through violence not always targeting their direct aggressors. Most players will sympathise with the non-human's plight but it is hard to get behind the murders they commonly commit. While their tactics may be reprehensible, are you really willing to side with the religious extremists who want to wipe the non-humans out completely?Choices like this permeate the game and your decisions will always come back to you later. At the time, almost all are about choosing the lesser of two evils. Sometimes, these choices can come back to help you later but most don't ever allow you the satisfaction of knowing you made the right choice. Instead, it's simply about making choices and living with the consequences. In the dark world of The Witcher, these choices make for some memorable experiences.The gameplay is based on a heavily edited version of the Aurora engine used by BioWare so RPG elements should be readily familiar to most fans. The combat is rather unique though in that success is based on preparation and proper timing. Geralt is equipped with two blades, the silver blade and the steel blade. Silver is for monsters, steel is for humans. Each blade has three fighting stances: strong, fast and group. Fighting enemies means being able to switch, on the fly, to adapt to whatever situation you find yourself in. If you are fighting a group of wraiths, you should use Silver Group, but some situations involve you fighting more ambiguous groups of enemies, such as humans aided by mutant dogs. Figuring out the best option is key but you must always keep your cool. Attacks are done by simply clicking the left mouse button but to keep a combo going, you must click in rhythm with Geralts attacks. Clicking too soon or too late will leave you open to attack.You also have several magic abilities to assist you but they are not your typical options. More often than not, your magic will be supplementary, requiring strategy to actually help you in any way. For example, you can stick with Igni, your fire spells, to cause some direct damage to your enemies but it may be better to Hex a strong foe and have them fight on your behalf against the rest of the enemies, wiping out the party completely without you needing to get your hands dirty. This strategy plays into the preperation aspect of the game as well. If you play on easy, you won't need to worry about potions and oils but if you plan on playing at a higher level, mastering alchemy and predicting what enemies you will be facing off against is key to your success. Potions will help boost your abilities and oils will help you target specific types of enemies and can make the difference between death and success, even against basic encounters. This focus on strategy may turn off gamers more interested in fast paced hacking and slashing but for those of you looking for a more strategic level in your RPG's, look no further.The game isn't perfect, however, as glitches often muddy your experience. While I never had the game crash completely on me, graphical glitches were common and sometimes NPC's did some very strange things. At one point, I had a cow that would appear by my side whenever I traveled to a new area or meditated at a camp. Otherwise, it would stay perfectly still. While it was exciting to see my cow companion backing me up in conversations, it didn't do much for the atmosphere. The game can get bogged down by filler quests too. Act II is a problem offender and will likely be where most players quit playing the game. I urge you to power through this section of the game as the rest of the game sets a much higher bar.For those of us who haven't been introduced to the world of Geralt of Rivia yet, The Witcher is a masterpiece of dark fantasy fiction. While it's not as outwardly gory as, say, Game of Thrones, it deals with many of the same mature themes. If you appreciate a little philosophical soul-searching in your RPG's, The Witcher is one of the best games you'll find.

Unfortunately for us foreigners, the books were never translated until after this game was released. Because of this, the game utilizes an amensia story that, while never fully realized, is a huge help to those of us who are just now being introduced to the character. There are some references to the stories that are undoubtedly more meaningful to those who've read them but I never felt lost despite having no prior knowledge of the series.While the combat is fun and requires a unique sense of timing and preperation to master, the storyline is really the biggest draw to this game. Many previous games have attempted to capture the meaningful sense of choice and impact upon the storyline but few are as successful as The Witcher, primarily because it isn't about good versus evil. Some choices will clearly have a moral facet to them but even those aren't clear cut, even if you usually play games a certain way. A decision that you will need to make throughout the game involves the conflict between the Scoia'tel and the humans in charge. It's clear from the beginning that non-humans are consistently abused and oppressed by the human-dominated society and the Scoia'tel want to change this through violence not always targeting their direct aggressors. Most players will sympathise with the non-human's plight but it is hard to get behind the murders they commonly commit. While their tactics may be reprehensible, are you really willing to side with the religious extremists who want to wipe the non-humans out completely?Choices like this permeate the game and your decisions will always come back to you later. At the time, almost all are about choosing the lesser of two evils. Sometimes, these choices can come back to help you later but most don't ever allow you the satisfaction of knowing you made the right choice. Instead, it's simply about making choices and living with the consequences. In the dark world of The Witcher, these choices make for some memorable experiences.The gameplay is based on a heavily edited version of the Aurora engine used by BioWare so RPG elements should be readily familiar to most fans. The combat is rather unique though in that success is based on preparation and proper timing. Geralt is equipped with two blades, the silver blade and the steel blade. Silver is for monsters, steel is for humans. Each blade has three fighting stances: strong, fast and group. Fighting enemies means being able to switch, on the fly, to adapt to whatever situation you find yourself in. If you are fighting a group of wraiths, you should use Silver Group, but some situations involve you fighting more ambiguous groups of enemies, such as humans aided by mutant dogs. Figuring out the best option is key but you must always keep your cool. Attacks are done by simply clicking the left mouse button but to keep a combo going, you must click in rhythm with Geralts attacks. Clicking too soon or too late will leave you open to attack.You also have several magic abilities to assist you but they are not your typical options. More often than not, your magic will be supplementary, requiring strategy to actually help you in any way. For example, you can stick with Igni, your fire spells, to cause some direct damage to your enemies but it may be better to Hex a strong foe and have them fight on your behalf against the rest of the enemies, wiping out the party completely without you needing to get your hands dirty. This strategy plays into the preperation aspect of the game as well. If you play on easy, you won't need to worry about potions and oils but if you plan on playing at a higher level, mastering alchemy and predicting what enemies you will be facing off against is key to your success. Potions will help boost your abilities and oils will help you target specific types of enemies and can make the difference between death and success, even against basic encounters. This focus on strategy may turn off gamers more interested in fast paced hacking and slashing but for those of you looking for a more strategic level in your RPG's, look no further.The game isn't perfect, however, as glitches often muddy your experience. While I never had the game crash completely on me, graphical glitches were common and sometimes NPC's did some very strange things. At one point, I had a cow that would appear by my side whenever I traveled to a new area or meditated at a camp. Otherwise, it would stay perfectly still. While it was exciting to see my cow companion backing me up in conversations, it didn't do much for the atmosphere. The game can get bogged down by filler quests too. Act II is a problem offender and will likely be where most players quit playing the game. I urge you to power through this section of the game as the rest of the game sets a much higher bar.For those of us who haven't been introduced to the world of Geralt of Rivia yet, The Witcher is a masterpiece of dark fantasy fiction. While it's not as outwardly gory as, say, Game of Thrones, it deals with many of the same mature themes. If you appreciate a little philosophical soul-searching in your RPG's, The Witcher is one of the best games you'll find.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												Based on Andrzej Sapkowski's character and world, The Witcher is a finely crafted Dark (with a capital D) fantasy adventure that any fan of RPG's should play. Be aware though that this game is very mature and should not be played by kids. Sure there's the sex scenes but more importantly, it deals with mature themes that require a little world experience to fully comprehend and thus, I only recommend this game for adults.The game features a Witcher, Geralt of Rivia, who travels to the city of Vizima to investigate an attack on The Witcher's home castle. Witchers are a dying race of humans subjected to experiments and magic in order to make them into the perfect monster hunters. Despite being necessary in their monster-infested world, Witchers are treated with disdain by most people and tolerated only by those requiring their services. Geralt of Rivia has had many adventures already throughout Sapkowski's five novels and numerous short stories featuring the character. Unfortunately for us foreigners, the books were never translated until after this game was released. Because of this, the game utilizes an amensia story that, while never fully realized, is a huge help to those of us who are just now being introduced to the character. Fighting enemies means being able to switch, on the fly, to adapt to whatever situation you find yourself in. If you are fighting a group of wraiths, you should use Silver Group, but some situations involve you fighting more ambiguous groups of enemies, such as humans aided by mutant dogs. Figuring out the best option is key but you must always keep your cool. Clicking too soon or too late will leave you open to attack.You also have several magic abilities to assist you but they are not your typical options. This strategy plays into the preperation aspect of the game as well. This focus on strategy may turn off gamers more interested in fast paced hacking and slashing but for those of you looking for a more strategic level in your RPG's, look no further.The game isn't perfect, however, as glitches often muddy your experience. At one point, I had a cow that would appear by my side whenever I traveled to a new area or meditated at a camp. Otherwise, it would stay perfectly still. While it was exciting to see my cow companion backing me up in conversations, it didn't do much for the atmosphere. The game can get bogged down by filler quests too. Act II is a problem offender and will likely be where most players quit playing the game. I urge you to power through this section of the game as the rest of the game sets a much higher bar.For those of us who haven't been introduced to the world of Geralt of Rivia yet, The Witcher is a masterpiece of dark fantasy fiction. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												What is both sad and funny is that people who pick up this game get disappointed by its clunky controls and lack of active block/dodge/parry, as in there's no button to press to block, dodge or parry, also double-tapping a direction might show you dodging or sidestepping but it gives no invisibility frames whatsoever, in the way Dark Souls games do.The reason why this fact is sad and funny is because by design the Witcher is meant to be played in an isometric camera view, using mouse clicks to move around and mouse clicks to attack. Hell, spacebar is even used for active pause, something that games like Neverwinter Nights, Divinity: Original Sin, Pillars of Eternity and Baldur's gate have. Another hint that indicates that this game is meant to be enjoyed as a traditional isometric Western RPG instead of the Dark Souls experience people expected to get.Don't get me wrong, I love Dark Souls games, and Witcher 3. This isn't a criticism against character RPG's where people's reactions are rewarded. This is a criticism towards people who approach Witcher 1 as if it should behave like Dark Souls or even Witcher 2 and 3. Share of the blame goes to CD Projekt's decision to put Over-the-shoulder camera as an option, something that adds spice to pure 1vs1 encounters.The moment I decided to give a go to the isometric camera my opinion on this game shifted. If you're into traditional isometric games you're in for a treat with Witcher 1, assuming you don't know that already. And also try to use a mod called Full Combat Rebalance 1.6 on either easy-easy difficulty or easy-normal. It makes things a lot closer to how the books are. Apparently the person who made the FCR mods got hired by CD Projekt and the mod itself is included in the Platinum retail versions of the game.Further proof that Witcher 1 is meant to be enjoyed as an isometric RPG is the fact that they used Aurora Engine to make it. Guess what other games use it http://www.giantbomb.com/aurora-engine/3015-1468/games/.So tl;dr treat Witcher 1 like a standard isometric Western RPG with a predetermined character and a good story and you won't be disappointed. Throw Full Combat Rebalance mod in the mix and you'll find yourselves using the "pause" function frequently to plan your fights on the fly. In case you're not into that you can either treat it as a subpar Dark Souls game or just watch a recap video and jump to either Witcher 2 with Full Combat Rebalance 2 or Witcher 3.P.S.: I play the GOG version of the games so the time played on Steam doesn't reflect my real one.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												THERE.. IT'S DONE.. FINALLY...GOD!!That being said, the game is worth every bang for it's buck if purely for the time that will be spend playing it.. I don't even remember when I bought it but has been alot of years playing on and off to finish it. I would spend several hours playing it and sometimes redoing sectiongs because I forgot to same the game :/.It is a fun game which has a very good story to it and a whole world of lore surrounding it. The voice acting is great and the characters are great. The player can also determine the whitchers personality a bit with dialouge options. Your choices can sometimes effect wheather you have allies to help you in battles.The gamplay is a bit akward I admit. It was probably trying to compensate for being a Diablo style clickfest by having you only click attack to connect combos together. I can understand why they moved away from that but apparently they changed it back In Whitcher 2.It does have RPG elements that allow you to improve your character as you gain levels. Certain abilites aren't accessible until you get past the 10th level and even other until you get pace 20. There are also some abilites can can only be unlocked with mutagens that you can make after beating a boss. There wasn't really a clear way to see how upgrades wehre improving your characters ther wasn't exactly a character sheet to look at.I really liked the potion making aspect of the game as it relied on you making the most of your eviroment to keep your character stocked with items. You could't really buy potions from stores and had to make it yourself. Reading books about herbalism help to expand your characters knowledges so they can use more types of plants and monsters guts. Just be careful how much and how often you use potions as high toxicity levels can slow or kill your character.So, at some point I will play witcher 2 since I bought both of these games as a pack. Once PC is upgraded, whitcher 3. Should be fun.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												This is a fantastic game, but I feel there a a couple of aspects which lets it down and stops it being a game of true excellence. Story and delivery is great. Not huge depth in characters that you meet, but you get a chance to chose your own type of person you want to play, and notice the responses to the story he gives due to these. There seems to be so much in the ending that was dependant on the choices that I made that I really want to go for another playthrough to see if they were just clever in their delivery so it was belivable or somethign entirely different may happen. I like the lack of item management needed, for once in a RPG I wasnt half the time looking my inventory and swapping around items. For the year it was released I think this must have been a great achivement to deliver a game like this which is a few years ahead of its time.So bringing it down from the company of some of the greatest games ever: The combat is dull, clicking to perform one set of moves wasn't the most stimulating. Bugs; multiple crashes in playthrough, graphical glitches (hair and beards especially), some cutscenes I felt were played out of order (either that or where poorly placed in story so I had no idea what was going on/been teleported throught ime and space). Number one though is the maps you run around on, constantly back and forward to different parts (of fairly unambitious maps) unless you have to forsight to see the location os where every quest will take you to next to optimise your travelling, and always having to run the long way round to miss monsters/follow streets. They're gloomy places as well, not pretty enough for you to appreciate the trips. Really enjoyed my time playing it. As I tend to rate of the games I play: this was a good use of my time.

Posted: March 25, 2016
												The enhanced edition is a realy beatiful game. It is an isometric game but in 3D i.e. you can freely rotate the camera around the 'witcher'. It uses the Bioware Aurora engine and the graphics are gorgeous. The game is huge and reminds me a bit of the old Bioware games. I play it on easy. It has lot of story and you can collect ingredients, read books and create various potions. That is to say the game gives you a lot of freedom. You can walk the streets or go in the sewers (depending on the location of course) and travel to other areas.Minigames are dice poker and fist fights.I think that if you like games such as Baldur's Gate/Dragon Age etc. for their story, you are going to like this.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Confession: when I first played this game, I dropped it after the Prologue because I found the combat tedious and lacking. However, I wanted to play this game before the other witchers, so I decided to try it one more time with an open mind. I'm glad I did because after the first chapter, my Geralt realized the joys of snuu snuu and gambling, and became part of an endless cycle of: getting laid -> losing all myMoney -> gambling to make ends meet -> losing everything -> sadness -> repeat. I have no regretsIn all seriousness, this game is phenomenal. -Combat is tedious, but once you get the hang of it, it actually becomes quite enjoyable.-This game excels in how it deals with choices and decisions. When your faced with an important decision, there is no clear right or wrong answer, and they do have lasting consequences-The story is engrossing, and while the pacing may be quite inconsistent, theres never a dull moment! Overall I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a immersive RPG, and a well thought out story.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The Witcher is undoubtedly one of the best RPG Adventure games ever published.  At the time of its release, it was very innovative and presented one of the first RPG games where your decisions actually had an impact on the rest of the game.  Coupled with the stunning graphics, for that time, the unashamed presentation of a realistic world, and the pure story telling, The Witcher is in my opinion the best overall RPG game ever produced for the computer.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I bought all three Witchers on sale.  With some effort, I limited myself to starting this, the first one.  I tend to like games that let you play as less human characters- lizzard men, dragons, cat folk and the like are great examples, honestly, even though Geralt, the main player character is a mutant, he is still very humanoid in appearance.  Have to like his slitted eyes and silver hair though. That aside, this game is deep, I'm getting addicted and I've barely scratched the surface of the first one.  The game supports Nvidia's DSR mode very well, giving edges a nice crisp look, though the textures are often blurred even at the games highest setting.  Considering this is an older game now, that's not suprising.  Story plots are pretty deep.  In fact, I'm involved in an investigation right now fit for a sluth.  The game has a time of day system where events happen and people are only presant at locations at certain times of day.  All the mechanics show a lot of consideration.  Witchers potions provide benifits, while have an accumulative poisioning effect that acts as a limiter, preventing you from brewing and downing too many at once.  Monsters tend to show up more at night than during the day.  Conversations with folk should be taken seriously, lest you say something that turns them off from talking to you at all for a while.  Swordplay is impressive, and once you understand the mechanics, is quite enjoyable.All in all, the game is well designed and thought out, and at this point, With all three games, I'm going to be spending several hours with it.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Great game over all! It has an interesting story, awesome characters, and fun gameplay. However, I didn’t write this review just to praise the game, it has a huge issue that I didn’t know about when I bought it. The first time I started the game up I got a message saying I did not have the minimum requirements.  After doing research I figured out that I was not the only one with this issue. What you’re going to want to do is go to your file explorer, then type “The Witcher” in the search bar, a file should pop up titled “The Witcher enhanced edition”. Once you click on that you will need to click on the system folder, after that right click “the witcher” then go to “send to” then “desktop (create shortcut)”. Once you have your shortcut up you will need to right click it and go to “properties”, in the target box go to the end, add a apace and type –dontforceminreqs, then click apply…you will need to use the shortcut to play the game. Hope this helps!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												Gameplay and graphics wise, this game isn't so great, but the graphics do and the gameplay is rather unique. At least, to my knowledge.  The storyline, however, is very interesting and pulled me in quickly.This first game in a great series starts out pretty mysteriously, and soon gets straight into action. You go on a long quest to avenge a death, to recover what was stolen and to find things that were lost to you. Along the way you meet a whole lot of interesting people, some you know, some you don't. You even got two bros. Those guys are great.There are many choices you make that (heavily) impact the game, and it's sequels, so choose wisely what you do.You level up to unlock new abilities, like really cool sword moves, fancy magic and deadly tools.There are many different locations, many people to talk to, lots of quests to complete, and much loot to be had.There's a lot of walking from place to place, unfortunately, so be wary of that.Overall, this game may be outdated in quite a few ways, but the story is still great and I believe it is a must-play if you plan on playing the other two games.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Holds up very well and forever refuses to pay off shallow investments.  It's a complex game with a combat apparatus unfairly rejected by many but the savvy rpg veteran will be handsomely rewarded when meeting the game on it's terms.  Don't be so quick to dismiss the first Witcher game in hopes of fast-tracking your enjoyment of newer ones, especially if time is no constraint.  There are many reasons why you may find it to actually be the best in the series!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My favorite RPG of all time.The storyline is simply amazing and apparently well acclaimed. It is very enjoyable how the storytelling gives a non-rapid tempo as a classic RPG should do, the story sort of unfolds itself and it gets more and more intriguing as it developes. And the choices you make really matter and would lead you to different consequences.The characters are well designed--each of them is full and bold. The graphics is very impressive, back in the days when it was released, it was outstanding. The music is excellent, the sound effect/voice acting is very well done. These combined with the storyline they present a convincing Temerial/fantasy-medieval age atmosphere.The combat system is such a unique success. Once you get the hang of it, the swordfighting in this game might just be the most unforgetable experience. (I strongly recommend the hardcore mode where there's no indicator as long as you find the sword-dancing interesting--some people don't, I understand that totally as well.)There are certain technical issues like random CTDs sometimes, some glitches, map loading when going in and out buildings and spaces could be tedious(especially when you didn't have powerful machine like today's). Certain details are somewhat rough, etc. Yet it doesn't cover the glows.This game is highly replayable due to its multiple endings feature. I've played through three times(twice before I got it on Steam) and spent over 100 hours in the game.One of the most glorious gems.ps: Polish people make good vodka : )

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												Total Score:  75  (B - More Drowners, Please!) Graphics and Art:  7Sound and Music:  7Story and Plot:  8Controls:  7Creativity and Uniqueness:  9Mood and Immersion:  9Length, Content, and Replayability:  8Functionality:  5Character Choice and Customization:  7Challenge:  8Click...wait...wait...wait...click...wait...wait...wait...wait...wait....click, your way to victory!  The Witcher is a game about all of the important things in life:  drinking beer, eating donuts, drinking "potions", having bar fights, drinking wine, fighting monsters and cutting off their monster parts, drinking spirits, and, of course, screwing everything that moves.  Witcher really does have it all!  The front screen might or might not work right, and you'll have a CTD here and there, but it mostly works.  And, sometimes your characters does what you tell him...sometimes, sort of.  I mean, like, you can, in theory dodge in this game, but you never will.  That said, the fighting, though a bit clunky, is fun.  What makes this game good, however, is the story which is grimdark and cynical and is set in a unique world where you'll wonder why anyone even bothers but still keeps you interested.  In fact, the game makes you feel like an idiot for trying to make well-considered mortal choices!  No good dead is left unpunished - just like in real life!  It is a genuinely fun game, and the use of player-crafted potions gives it some depth and gives you some challenges to overcome in the realm of tactics.  Play this game on the hardest mode, by the way, so that you'll actually have to think about what potions to use and when to use them!  Play every game on the hardest mode, actually, except the COD series...screw that noise.  Actually, just don't play the COD series.  Wait, where was I?  Oh, right.  Everyone needs to play the Witcher.  You get collector cards for screwing random chicks.  I mean, that right there basically decides it, right?

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Compelling writting.This is how can I best describe my experience. The Witcher universe was created by one of the best Fantasy writers I know of. So this provided the developers a strong and credible background to work with. Many RPGs have problems with World Building, this is creating a whole reality where the main lore is happening. But not this game, here you can find that the "background" lore is even more interesting than the main one. The amount of posible sequels and prequels based on that is huge. So it is very improbable that this franchise will become the next Assassins Creed (A clear example on weak World Building) or something like that.Contraty to what many say, I loved the combat. You can read about its pros and cons all over the internet but I invite you to ignore all that and try it yourself for at least 3 hours. Of course I will do another playthrough with the Combat Rebalanced Mod soon, since it adds a layer of complexity.Speaking of wich: PLAY THIS GAME ON HARD, NO MATTER HOW BAD YOU ARE FOR VIDEOGAMES, DO IT. Ignore the easy and medium settings. Hard is where this game shines. This gamemode forces you to utilize every element at your disposal and by that, increasing and improving the gameplay. Yes, you will suffer killing the freaking Beast, and you will suffer at the swamp, but after that, the game becomes so easy, once you dominate the art of alchemy. As for graphics, if you feel this game looks too old, there are mods that revamp all the textures and you can inject some DLLs to improve another graphical aspects. If you are new to the franchise, play it on hard mode with vanilla combat and texture mods. After that I bet you will want to read the Witcher books before even starting to play the second game.Buy it no matter the price, it is worth it.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												This game has been in my steam library for over 5 years. I've attempted to play it numerous times, barely making it to the first chapter before exiting because I just could not get into it.I really wanted to play the sequels but I'm a perferctionist, so I decided to give it another chance, booted it up, and finished it in a week, not being able to put it down.Why? Because I went into it with an open mind. Yes it's almost 10 years old, and the graphics might not be of today's standard, but hey, this is made using the same graphics engine as the first Neverwinter Nights game from 2002. Go and compare the two games and you'll see how impressive The Witcher looks.The combat, whilst using the click-timing mechanic, gets better. It reminds me of the Gothic games, where, as you put more exp points in to it, you get more fluid combos and animations. By the time you're half way through the game, Geralt's swinging his sword round like a GOT Water Dancer; it's fantastic!The over-arching plot, whilst basic, has a few twists in it, which I like, and there are difficult choices to make, when choosing which faction is in the right. I managed to complete almost everything within 50 hours and I might even go back and make the opposite choices, just to see the changes.Now that I'm playing the second game, I love that you can import your save, hearing NPCs react and talk about some of your choices in the first game really adds to the immersion.Seriously, if like me, you've had trouble getting into this game, but really want to play the trilogy (especially when CD Project Red have said they're not doing any remasters), go into it with an open mind; It's a great game, and Gothic fans should see some similarities.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
Rank: 7.5/10Recommendation(s): Like old school RPG games and their mechanicsMajor Theme: An old game worth playing for future The Witcher games.Bought at Price: $2.75 (Steam Sale)I promised myself that I would play The Witcher trilogy in order. That went out of the window when The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt came out.Playing in order wasn't a purely a case of wanting to understand the series, but rather to ensure that I could write reasonable reviews and appreciate the games more. I have yet to play the 2nd game, but what is very apparent to me in the series is the fact that there is no good or evil, just choices and their consequences. Going against most games, the consequences may not be immediate. They can take quite some time to manifest themselves.


The Witcher: Enhanced Edition 
A Screenshot of The Witcher: Enhanced Edition
By: DarK_St3alth




I can't really think of another RPG game that does it like The Witcher series. Choosing the "lesser evil" is a fact of life in these games. While the series so far is very well made, I wouldn't be recommending this game to the vast population. Why, you ask? Very simple.Back in this time period, game mechanics worked very differently. Star Wars: The Knights of the Old Republic had live combat, but used a dice roll system for determining hits/misses. Mechanics such as those make games very had to appreciate for modern gaming fans. Further more, you had to really use your brain to solve puzzles. Of course, mentally challenging puzzles such as “whose done it” murder mysteries are kind of defunct with the internet and video sharing sites being vastly popular and well sought after. 


How RPG games work... 
A Screenshot of The Witcher: Enhanced Edition
By: DarK_St3alth




This kind of defeats the challenge of the game, which may or may not make the game less desirable for you. I try not to “cheat” but I did happen to notice that even I had to look up how certain quests were done because other options were not readily apparent as they probably should have been.Don't get me wrong, I hate having the developers walk me through a game. I like to have it so that I felt at least the ending wasn't just given to me (or in the form of QTEs).Not everything about this game is a negative for people. First thing that comes to mind is the Very unique time of day and weather systems that effects NPCs and quests.A quest in quite a few cases may only be done during certain time periods, say at midnight or at dawn. Having weather affect NPC movement adds to the realism of this game. The time of day system wasn't really just slapped on, it is an integral part of the game when you not only consider the quests, but also alchemy the player must come to grips with. Some of the quest parts certainly aren't always clear, and the time of day system can also cause confusion when the quest log isn't perfectly clear.Perhaps I missed something while playing, but certainly the alchemy isn't straight forward, and doesn't really have to be used until near the end of the game. Harder boss fights near the last 5 to 7 hours of the game really require multiple potions and inventory items to allow you to defeat them.While this game certainly doesn't hold up to the graphical quality of modern games (Rise of the Tomb Raider), the graphics prove reasonable enough.I can't compare the "Enhanced Edition" from the regular one, but from the looks of it, I don't think I could have ended up playing the original. In this newish version of the game, it did feel from time to time that you were dragging your face along the ground to get to the end of the title. One of the main reasons for this could be the lack of humor. There's plenty of sex (well at least naked people and innuendo), and the gore department doesn't lack (the finishing moves are quite good). It's just a let down that the humor department didn't get as much attention as it should have. 


I guess this is going to just keep coming up in this game lol 
A Screenshot of The Witcher: Enhanced Edition
By: DarK_St3alth




While being a fan of old school RPGs, this title certainly straddled the fence between being enjoyable and playing just out of the sake of getting to know the series better. Your experience may or may not be like this.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Stunning debut from CD Projekt. It certainly has its flaws, but many of these have been improved by patches or simply by the advancement of hardware since its release. As an achievement of the RPG genre this game remains outstanding.Based on the novels of Andrej Sapkowski (long popular in Poland), The Witcher's strength as an RPG owes much to the excellent source material. Sapkowski combines elements of folklore, medieval history and traditional fantasy to show us a believable world, then turns some of these conventions on their heads in a neat twist. In short, this is a world where Galadriel goes to the toilet and Gandalf goes to the brothel.The crudeness occasionally feels overstated and even sexist, but generally the dark and dirty mood of the game adds character and credibility to the situations and decisions surrounding Geralt, the protagonist. This is clever storytelling with some absolutely brilliant moments. Also, at max settings it still looks pretty great.A real gem of an RPG and a fantastic introduction to The Witcher series. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Geralt of Rivia, the smoothest badass ever created.My friends recommended me this game. I was struggling a lot in the beginning as well as everyone who played The Witcher. I hated this game and at times came very close to uninstalling it. But I always thought "they said its good, there must be more to it" and kept playing. Indeed, after 3-5 hours into the game I understood. Behind a complicated story, totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ talents and combat mechanics there lies one of the best RPG games I've ever played. After you grip the overall gameplay it will stop to irritate you and patterns will start to display. You will be able to enjoy the rich and immersive story, full of intrigues and twists and also those weird combats. The story is the strongest part of the game, it is very mature where decisions are hard with serious consequences and are never good or evil. They just define your political and personal preferences as you progress from an outcast monster killer. The game is also very long. I like to fulfill every quest, check all chests and barrels and enjoy games in general. With such approach, The Witcher took me 65 hours to finish. Every second  was definitely worth it. Do yourself a favor, buy the game and play it. Don't get demotivated by prologue and the first act, keep playing and eventually you will get consumed, I guarantee you that. Last time this happened to me was when I played Fallout 2 few years ago, this game quite reminded me of it and I thank its creators for that.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A mature RPG with really deep story, focused more on the political intrigues of the land and adding a few hints of an impeding doom. Storywise you may get a little lost at the beggining by the amount of data you receive but things get clearer as you play. Graphics are good despite their age and the game will run at max settings with no problems for most but the oldest machines.Sound is good. The voice acting (english version) is very good and puts you in the mood of the story.Gameplay is a bit weird, especially in combat, but you get the hang of it really quickly and the game itself is not very punishing during that phase. There is a crafting system for potions (self buffs), oils (sword buffs), bombs and a few swords, but it's fairly basic compared to other games, although really important especially in higher difficulties.Storywise the game is nothing short of amazing. You won't be saving the world or anything grandiose like that. Although there will be hints of something big coming your way, you'll be faced with more realistic scenarios involving political intrigue, betrayal, clash of ideologies, racism and many others.  In contrast to many other RPGs "The Witcher" handles the power of choice in a more mature way rather than the classical good vs evil. There is no definite good or evil since everything you choose has consequences for certain groups, thus making your choice more idealistic than ethical.A must buy for RPG fans interested in experiencing an amazing story rather than running around in huge worlds aimlessly

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												A mature and deep RPG telling the journey of Geralt of Rivia, a witcher (a monster slayer), through a complex world where conflicts, corruption, politics, love, discrimination, racism, monsters, magic, and various others socials issues are very present. Through the story, based on the Andrzej Sapkowski's series of books, you, as Geralt, will discover the various shades of evil present in the world and decide which evil, Geralt, as a witcher, must fight against. The game forces you to be involved in an intriguing story where you'll be forced to take difficult decisions and endure their possible consequences - there aren't good and bad choices, they're all in a morality scale with various shades of grey. Many sidequests will be present alongside the main plot, and most of them can be useful to better understand the world, the society and its people. You'll meet many interesting characters, with many flaws and qualities, just like Geralt himself. The game has a great economy system where merchants only buy stuff they want, so you'll need to be smart in saving your gold, manage your inventory and find the "right" merchant.  All these characteristics solidify the depth of the setting and writing of the game - it's realistic in a literary sense, something that is many times overlooked in other games which choose a more heroic "save the world" path of storytelling (check MrBtongue's videos on youtube, he definitely helps understanding this quality very well). The game is mature, both in the "maturity" sense and the "sex and blood" one.The tactical combat involves the use of potions, magic, bombs, and sword-fighting, and you'll need to be aware of the enemies' weaknesses and take advantage of those before and during combat. In terms of active mechanics, it is quite simplistic and clunky, however the tactical aspect previously mentioned is definitely its strongest focus.  Alchemy and herbalism will be as essential as the combat during the game, so you need to be  prepared if an harder opponent appears, specially in the first half of the game and in the harder difficulties.The game has some problems, which are normal when we take in consideration that this game was developed by a rookie company at the time. The clunky combat is the major flaw, but there are other minor flaws like the lack of UI options (specially regarging the inventory management), the occasional lack of polish, the sometimes blunt introduction of sex themes, the difficulty scaling of the combat (harder at start, gets very easy in the last chapters), the lack of a "character statistics" information screen to check the result of your talent choices, and the redundant use of the same NPC models. However these problems aren't very detrimental to the overall experience, at least in my case. Alongside the competent graphics, there's the incredible music which will enhance your immersion in this fantasy setting. Also, the game supports modding.The Witcher will require your patience and attention and will not suit you if you want a quick action-focused RPG. However, if you're interested in good writing and storytelling, thought-provoking themes,   mature and serious settings, and games aswell (why else you'd be reading this?), you will definitely like this RPG despite its flaws.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												Me before playing the Witcher: "Hrm, I have Witcher 1, 2, and 3, I should try them. I hear you can skip Witcher 1 though, but I already have it, so might as well give it a try. Maybe I can just blow through it to get to the sequels."5 minutes into the Witcher: "This did not age well."10 minutes in: "Well the voice acting is okay at times, but script is good. And the story seems interesting. The combat and UI is awful, but I'll give it a chance."1 hour: "Okay there's some simple quests but they all have story behind them. And characters, with believable meaning, writing, and purpose. and I can't just 'kill 10 monsters', I have to research them a bit first? Interesting."4 hours: "This is actually pretty cool. I've have good laughs, really interested in the world and lore now, and like a lot of the attention to detail for an older game. Dialogue choices matter, the world is interesting. Alchemy and magic are starting to make some sense, and I kind of feel like a monster hunter."10 hours: "I fscking hate this swamp."20 hours: "I REALLY HATE THIS SWAMP."30 hours: "This is epic as hell in it's own right, and I've got to know how this ends."End: "I'm god dam Geralt of Rivia and no one is stopping me."Simply put,Cons:-Dated graphics and "bad-funny" animations-Lots of recycled NPC models-Busy as heck interface-Very clunky, repetetive combat-Voice acting hit or missPros:-Fantastic characters-Great world and lore representation-Depth to monster hunting and alchemy-Detail to how NPCs react and live in the worldSo basically, if you can stomach the clunky combat, UI, and don't mind the dated appearance, it's a really great ride. I loved it. It did drag on at times, especially in the swamp, but the quests, story, characters, all really made it feel more like an interactive, desicion-based novel at times more than a combat or action-oriented game. I really recommend it. Give it a shot, at least, if you like that kind of thing, and if you don't like it by 1-2 hours in, just skip it. I personally can't wait to start #2.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												First, the bad:This game is fairly old (came out in 2007 on a then-five-year-old engine), still somewhat buggy, and the graphics, while decent on my Mac, are still not great.  The voice acting in the English (US) version is inconsistent at best, and a lot of the dialogue comes off as lackluster too.  The sex cards.... I'm glad they were optional, for the most part, but it's possible to trigger some of them without the dialogue choices making clear that that's where you're headed.  I get that Geralt is supposed to be a ladies' man, but that doesn't mean he would necessarily be okay with women throwing themselves at him.  The romance part of the plot came off feeling very contrived, although perhaps it would have felt less so had I read the books that inspired this game series.  And then there's the fact that you're limited to playing a single, specific character from a book series, who despite his amnesia still seems to have his basic personality intact.  For me as an RPG player, this was actually the main reason I hesitated to try this game.The good?What I initially feared would be the game's biggest limitation for me - being forced to play a character with a preset (if largely forgotten by him) backstory and personality - actually turned out to be one of its biggest strengths.  Instead of just playing as Geralt of Rivia, I began to see the game's world through his eyes.  And for someone like me (daughter of a medieval/early Renaissance scholar, longstanding interest in Celtic and Norse/Teutonic mythology)... what a world!  I loved the extent to which the game draws on the various cultures, beliefs, problems and conflicts that existed in Europe, and particularly in northeastern Europe, during our Middle Ages.  Geralt of Rivia is a man who does not remember his own past, who is an outcast and a mutant, trying to figure out what his role is in a world that seems to be spinning out of control.  By limiting me to playing from his point of view, the game thrust me full tilt into its world, and I quickly fell into the trap of becoming emotionally involved.  (Minor spoiler alert: If this happens to you, you may very well end up feeling like you got sucker punched in the gut at least once per chapter.)  The decisions you make can have far-reaching consequences, and just like in real life, what seemed like a good idea at the time may turn out in retrospect to be the worst of all possible choices you could have made.I likewise grew to appreciate the combat system.  I know that for some people it ends up feeling clunky (I've seen it described as "rock-paper-scissors" in at least one other review), but I like the concept of using different styles for different types and numbers of enemies.  And I loved the lore element of making most monsters resistant to steel and susceptible to silver.  I also enjoyed the alchemy system, although by the end of the game I had way more potions, oils and bombs than I needed, and I did have to do a lot of running around to gather necessary ingredients.The so-so:There are a certain number of MMO-style fetch quests in this game.  I personally don't mind fetch quests, because they're useful experience, (mostly) easy money, and I'm the kind of player who likes to explore as much of a map as the game will let me before moving on.  However, the inventory system is somewhat clunky even with modding, and finding ways to store excess items requires a lot of running back and forth, so this merits a caveat.A bigger caveat, though, is the way this game handles gender and racial politics.  I will say that, from my personal perspective and given that the game appears to be set during the equivalent of our Middle Ages, that although many of the gender and racial stereotypes shown in this game may be offensive to us in the 21st century, they are also (unfortunately) based on how women and minorities were often viewed in medieval Europe.  This was a time when women were typically viewed as the property of their nearest male relative and when anyone who didn't fit in, for whatever reason, was treated with extreme suspicion if not outright hostility.  I, personally, feel that - for the most part - the way this game handles such things adds to the sense of authenticity it provides.  HOWEVER, having said that, I still take issue with some of the game's dialogue that relates to relationships between men and women.  I won't go into details, because main plot quests are involved, but chapter 3 is particularly bad in this regard.  The gender politics do seem to get marginally better towards the end of the game, with women taking up leadership positions in various factions and courts, so at least there's that to be said for it.  And the game does feature some very strong female NPCs with minds of their own and agendas which can differ markedly from Geralt's, so it does have that going for it, at least. Whether or not the racial politics improve depends mostly on choices you as Geralt made throughout the game, so it will vary from playthrough to playthrough.  I just finished my first (neutral) playthrough, and I ended up with a stronger sense of who the leaders of the "human" faction were as people than I did of who the leaders of the "nonhuman" faction were as people, although I suppose that that makes some sense given the plot.In summary:This is an older game, with noticeable flaws in its design and execution.  It is also set in a sort of fantasy version of our Middle Ages, with associated gender and ethnic stereotypes of the sort that, quite frankly, can be disturbing from a 21st-century perspective.  However, it also features a world steeped in the lore of our own, a flawed protagonist who struggles with questions of identity, purpose and loyalty, and a rich cast of supporting characters with their own distinct agendas.  It's definitely not a game for everyone, and its shortcomings are significant enough for me that I can only give it a 7.5 out of 10, but I honestly didn't expect to find it as enjoyable as I have, and overall I'm glad I bought it.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Summary: The Witcher combines spectacular and visually stunning action with deep and intriguing storyline. The game is set in a world created by best-selling Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. The world shares many common features with other fantasy lands, but there are also some distinguishing elements setting it apart from others. The game features the player as a "Witcher", a warrior who has been trained to fight since childhood, subjected to mutations and trials that transformed him. He earns his living killing monsters and is a member of a brotherhood founded long ago to protect people from werewolves, the undead, and a host of other beasts. It's an action oriented, visually stunning, easy to use, single player RPG, with a deep and intriguing storyline.  9/10
