content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Well, I did it, I played through The Witcher: Enhanced Edition after beating W3: blood & Wine,  in the year of our lord, 2016, and honestly, I thought it held up pretty well!  Setting aside the massive improvements the series has made since its humble beginnings, there's still a lot of good story content here.  There's a surprisingly high amount of set up to things in W2 and W3.  A lot of care was taken to create this world.  If you're interested to see where the series came from, it's worth a playthrough.WARNING:The first act is still a very painful one, and there's a lot of running, and a lot of quests that boil down to 'collect x thing' although those are optional.  If you're looking to get into the series, please start with W3.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												Trying to enjoy this game is a chore. Pros:- The game does a good job of setting up a morally grey world, with tough choices, hidden agendas and unexpected consequences to your actions- Environments look nice for 2007- Will appeal to hardcore PC gamers who enjoy esoteric and complex games that explain next to nothing to the playerCons:- Unresponsive, repetitive, simplistic, boring combat- Endless running between the same few locations over and over again- Boring, uninspired environments- Overdesigned UI: the inventory is a mess, and it's hard to make out what element does something and what doesn't- Clumsily delivered, aimless story with characters popping in left and right without any introduction- Mercilessly drawn out and repetitive quests: go to location A, talk to character B, go to location C, get X for character B, go back to location A to give X to character B, rinse and repeat- Quest tracking shows the general vicinity, not the exact location of where you need to be, leading to running around in circles- The game puts emphasis on preparation before combat, except there's hardly ever any forewarning when it happens, or indication that it even warrants preparation- The game autosaves only when transitioning between areas, and not when you level up or reach certain vital quest pointsOverall the game has merit, but the tedium and repetition far outweigh the moments of enjoyment. Only recommended if you want to play through the whole trilogy.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												- Actually played 37 hours, had to play in offline mode once. I have finished the story and all the side quests (on hard). -I really liked this game, it has once of the most interesting stories and lores I've encountered in a long time. You will find the weirdest characters of whom some have great character development. The story line was definitely what kept me into the game, and you should experience it for yourself! +++Something which was bad to okay was the combat. Altough they try to mix things up by you having to choose 3 styles ( strong, fast and group) it was definitely the weakest part of the game in my opinion. It involved clicking on your left and right mouse button once in a while and drinking a few potions. The weapons and armour they provide is very weak. They almost all look the same (just have different bonusses, like damage +30%). It felt quite odd that in a world this big, there was so little to actually loot. I also only needed a few potions: I've never even brew the lionshare.The boss battles were quite dull and easy (I played on hard difficulty) with the exception of the first one. Especially the last one was dissapointing. I expected something really epic after 37 hours of chasing this person, instead of killing it with a few shots of my fire spell (I didn't even touch him with my sword). ---Your own character plays as someone with Amnesia who wants to find his memory back. I didn't really felt like most of the choices I made in the game (apart from 1) made a big inpact on what had happend. Also some things weren't clear to me, but I might find out more about that in ''The Witcher 2'' (altough I heard the story was almost entirely different). -The quests. The main ones were really interesting, but the side quest overall were a bit dull. It was basically walk to that place (there is very limited quick travel, nothing at all early game and late game) and get this item or kill a few of these monsters. I still give it a plus because of the earlier called main quest though. +Last but not least I want to talk about how I felt connected with the world (apart from the storyline and such). This world is (altough they destrict you to go to wherever you want) really diverse and complicated. I enjoyed encountering so many new monsters, so many new places and so many new people. There's a very diverse set of scrolls and books you can read, which I personally (altough many would find it boring) I really enjoyed. I spend my money on books in this game, over armour! +++So overall, is ''The Witcher'' a good game? Depends, do you like lore and story, definitely yes! Do you like diverse combat and no restrictions to where you can go? Then no. Do you like both of them? Then give this game a chance, I don't think you will regret it.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												What an amazing game. I've had it in my library for a long time, but never given it a chance. However, with all of the hype surrounding The Witcher 3 (and what the amazing devs at CDProjekt Red has done for the game and the community) I decided to try it out. The game is a bit dated, however, it has aged very well. I installed the mod ''The Rise of the White Wolf'' from nexusmods.com, and started playing the game.The first thing I noticed was a weird bug. My cutscenes were stuck. Two minutes of googling and I'd found a fix. Because I'm playing on a 21:9 monitor in 2560x1080, the cutscenes would get messed up. All I had to do was to put the lightning-quality down to low (and didn't notice a difference at all doing so). This game has me hooked. It's huge, there's so much detail, and it's fun.I'd heard from a huge amount of people (YouTube comments, reddit, reviews etc) that the combat was horrible, and that put a lot of people off from the game. However, when I started playing, I quickly realised that the combat was not messed up at all. I really enjoy the combat. 10/10. I'm currently only in chapter II. The game is very complex (and very rewarding!), and I reccommend this game to everyone. Can't wait until I've finished this so I can jump onto The Witcher 2!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2010
												Fair warning: this is an adults-only game and nobody under the age of 17 (according to the ESRB) or 18 (according to PEGI) should play it. Period.The Witcher is a very strange game. Its combat system feels action-oriented, but the game's not an action-RPG. Instead, it's a very deep roleplaying experience where there is no good or evil, but rather simply choices and consequences. Choices made early on could have dire ramifications later in a complex, excellently-written story set in a world as close to real medieval Europe as possible whilst still being a fantasy RPG. Truly a unique experience that can't be passed up.

content:
Posted: March 3
Tldr; this game has way too much filler in its medicore story and gameplay. You should either read about it, watch a playthrough or play a different old RPG (like Knights of the Old Republic). The writing of the Witcher seems to get an overwhelming amount praise, and it can be justified with the story’s twists, turns, and unique elements found throughout, however it is a shame that these interesting moments will be extremely brief highlights, in a large, slow slog of a game. I love RPGs and I played this game purely for the story. Unfortunately, I found the story to be mostly mediocre, even for its time, (with only 2-3 relevant scenes of the main plot occurring in each of the game’s 7 chapters), but what drove me to hate this game was in the way it delivered its story. The basic breakdown of my time in this game, including both story and side quests, can be summed up with this:1)	Go to point A, where you will usually talk to an NPC for a few minutes and initiate some quest or scene.2)	Spend around 5 minutes walking to point B if you do not fight any enemies (which for most time there will be none).  3)	Once you arrive at B, do the quest task or talk to another NPC.4)	If it is a multi-part quest spend another 5 minutes walking to point C, D, ect.  5)	Return to point A, where you will either repeat the whole process over again or finish your quest.After doing this cycle for a bit I came to the realization that for every bit of story that this game provides, I would have to spend at least ten minutes of just walking just to get it. Now it is easy to argue that many games and RPGs revolve around this formula. However, the Witcher fails because it uses large maps for each chapter, where the all the starting points A, and their respective points B, C, Ect., are all randomly scattered throughout the maps. Therefore, you must constantly back track to each area of the map for each quest, and since all the starting points A are found throughout the map, optimizing your path becomes far too difficult.  Couple all this with a story that loves to stall, (seriously, the plot of chapters one, two, three all revolve around trying to find the villain, who at the end of the chapter escapes, leading you to chase after him again) and you have yourself and extremely maddening and boring game on your hands. If I could recommend anything about experiencing this game, I would say to skim through a walkthrough of the game, that way you can cut out all the filler, and experience the few hours of enjoyment. Better yet, get Witcher 3 (if you haven't) that game is amazing.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												To put this review in perspective, I haven't played it much.  Generally I would prefer to play a game for at least 10-20 hours before writing a review but for me, this game is really just that bad.  I cannot even bring myself to play it for another hour.  I was very surprised at how poorly this game actually functions considering the rave reviews from it's release and up to this very day.From a graphical standpoint this game is dated-- but that's ok.  Most of the games I play are indie titles anyway and few of them are graphical wonders-- I knew this going in and that isn't the issue.  Somehow this game was billed as "a great story, compelling gameplay,  and dynamic immersion" into the Witcher universe.  After about 30 minutes I thought I had descended to gamer hell.  The mechanics in this game are not just poor, they are absolutely freaking terrible.  Everything from the combat system to the magic, to the movement, to the healing, to the interaction with the environment is so terrible that I sincerely wonder how anyone every gave this company money to publish their title.  As for the story, EVERYTHING you do in this game breaks up the immersion of the story.  Constant cutscenes, menu changes, loading screens-- pauses in combat to do what....???? CHANGE MY FRICKING FIGHTING STYLE?  ARE YOU F-ing KIDDING ME?  This game is horrible.  Unfortunately I bought the second one so I suppose at some point I will have to waste another few hours of my life just to arrive at the same conclusion as I did with this one.  Even at $4.00 this is a complete waste of money and time.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												In fine,In this story of rich conspiracy, you're taking the role of an enigmatic figure called Geralt of Rivia. As you venture into the world of The Witchers where you're left alone without any of your recent memories. You have to make one choice after another to define the fate of the society and the people around you. There will be no right or wrong, all you will encounters in this intriguing tale is indeed "intriguing choices". It's not a matter of survival, you just need to keep walking as the world around you struggle to resist your devastating influences. Yes, you will survive indeed, the problem is.. will you allow the world to survive?With beautifully drawn artworks and surprisingly time-tested graphic, The Witcher is one of few games that actually delivered this strong feeling of being entangled with all of the aspects that makes this game an unmissable masterpiece.--------------------------------------------------------------------------PERSONAL COMMENTARY--------------------------------------------------------------------------Okay, I've played this game, so what?The first time you run The Witcher is like doing a labor you normally don't do for the sake of civilized society. What I mean with "society" is everyone around you, the norm you live by, especially if you're from the exact same country as I am..But as soon as you drawn yourself into this story-driven game (character-driven too), you will certainly forget about all of that unnecessary feelings of hesitation. The game will eventually says: "It's okay, I may have these naughty dilly dally.. But, I also have this well-thought and complex storyline that will makes you think of me differently."What I like the most about this game is the artwork, not "that kind of artwork" actually.. but rather the one that -for example- shows Garalt and Seigfried fighting together against this YianKutKu-like monster. Accompanied by this "what if" question that makes you wonder about the "other outcome" if you decide to chose different path .I will not talk about the gameplay in general. Because you've already know that there is actually two types of gamer, the one that .... (you know the rest)... Basically this game is well worth your time if you're into a rather serious and well-made story and is okay with some unnecessary -I don't think it's entirely true- dilly dally.

												The gameplay can be frustratingly broken, and you will find yourself looking for workarounds and glitches to solve some of the more stupid things programmed into the game.Example:There are 4 men waiting to jump you behind a door.You ready your sword and sign, and enter the door.Geralt has now decided he wants to put his sword on his back, so you must watch the entire animation of Geralt holstering his sword while 4 dudes beat the shiat out of him. You go from 100% to 50% hp by the time you manage to get your sword back out.Whew, still alive, quickly cast aard! Nope. The game gives you no way to go back and get basic things like bases for pots and oil after a certain point. Golden age of gaming maybe, but I'm glad developers have gotten past doing garbage things like this.

Christ though, I have a hard time imaginig this title ever getting off the ground without it's surplus of♥♥♥♥♥♥and "omgeez it's so real and growed up"♥♥♥♥♥♥and-ball jokes.  When I found out that I still have another 4 or 5 chapters to go, I quit.  I was only playing to pick up the story for the later titles, and the story is so lightly-peppered in amongst the fetch/errand quests, that I'd rather spend eight minutes reading it on a wiki.Basically, The Witcher plays like the Barrens in WoW eight years ago - if you made a solo game out of that nightmare.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I played The Witcher 2 first.  The Witcher 2 is a fantastic game, full of political intrigue, tight combat, and enough moral gray areas to satisfy the gothiest of goths or the fenciest of fence-sitters.  The setting was a fresh step away from the usual dragons and dungeons, brought to life by beautiful visuals of countrysides, crypts, and city-scapes.  And then I played The Witcher.Fair story and pretty awesome main character in Geralt, the White Wolf.  Upgrades in weapons feel heavy- your main weapons change once in each of the four chapters.  If you want a Diablo loot lottery (lootery?), keep looking.  I have gotten new armor once in 60 hours of play, and that was because I started with no armor.  This game makes you feel like you're working for your upgrades, and there's a lot to be said for that these days.  Geralt of Rivia is one of the best characters that I've come across in a lot of years of playing video games.  His voice acting leaves much to be desired, but his methods, motives, and skills are pretty incredible to play.  By the end of the game, just like with the equipment, Geralt feels like a cross between Wolverine, Scott Hamilton, and a long-time alcoholic.  Potions play a big part in game strategy, and Geralt learns to handle his liquor over the course of the game- turning him into a one-man army with just a few swigs.  His swordplay is pretty beautiful to watch by the end of the game, with many acrobatic twists and appropriately-heavy chops to keep you entertained while mindlessly clicking that mouse.  Which brings me to my next point...Unfortunately, this game falls down on three points- combat, travel, and questing.  Combat is a click-on-beat affair, which makes combat incredibly mind numbing.  I'm fighting a group? Let me switch to Group Combat Style and click.  Oh, most of the group is dead?  Let me switch to Heavy Style and click.  Lather, rinse, and repeat for 3 days worth of time.  There is no fast travel in this game (or I didn't find it), which is pretty awful considering Baldur's Gate and Diablo got this right in the 90's.   And because of the last fact, the questing turns this game into "5k Simulator 2010".  I never realized how much I don't like staring at the back of an albino's head for hours.  Anyways:Try this one out if...- you like real heavy choice in your games- you need an R-rated break from D&D- you ABSOLUTELY need to know the backstory for The Witcher: Assassin of Kings- you like to work for one of the best ending cutscenes around

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Replayed the game a lot of times and now that I finished Witcher 3 too, I can finally honestly say, that this is the best game of the Witcher series. Ofc the graphics are what they are since the game is old, but if you can get over it, it´s perfect. There are some other shortcomings too, such as if you are fan of great combat systems, this game does not have it. However, there are things that Witcher 1 is superior to other medieval/fantasy games. For example atmosphere. The game describes the dark middle age just perfectly, goes deeply into human hatred and fear of unknown. Of all the games I´ve played, I like the monsters in this one the most. Behind almost all of them, there is a backstory of their creation, or rather how they were brought into the world. And since I do not want to spoil you out what you can read and get some goosebumps I´m just gonna cut it right here. With the great soundtrack on top of all this, both game´s atmosphere and goosebumps are gonna intensify :D Another great thing I´d like to point our is that the quest in the game are not all that easy. Since there is no marker to where should you find your quest object or NPC, you are gonna have to search for some of them pretty hard. Also the quests feel kinda logical and its not the usual stereotype of go there, fetch this, bring it there, kill him, oh that sh*** f***** up so you have to do 5 more things and stuff. At the end of this review I would like to thanks everyone for reading it. If you´ll buy this game I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did, and still do. Remember that you might have different opinion on some of these things and that´s completely fine. P.S.: There are some custom stories that you can play too, but most of them without voice actors.Here are some pros and cons:Pros:- atmosphere- great story- nice background- perfect soundtrack- good quest system- interesting mini game- sex cards :D Cons:- dull combat system- some of the spells are rather useless- cannot continue exploring after you finish the game- low variety of equipment

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I'm going to start by saying one thing: this game has the slowest progression I've ever seen in any game; period. I have 31 hours into this game and I did not finish it. It takes that long. The reason why I'm making this review before I've finished is because my hard drive recently fried and according to Steam there is no cloud save and I do not plan on another 30+ hours just to see the end (as much as it pains me since I know the saves transfer over like Mass Effect). That's about the only negative thing I have to say about this game. The difference is really big between The Witcher and The Witcher 2 in basically every aspect. Combat is linear in this game in the sense that you can only focus on on enemy at a time. However, as a Witcher you are skilled in combat thus giving you the ability to do hard and strong, fast and group attacks. The graphics aren't bad but there's a clear difference like I said. The story, like I said in my first paragraph,  basically drones on. I am not saying that it is bad; this game is worth the buy for the story but you need a lot of patience. I really hope I don't sound like I'm saying 'meh' because that is not what I am trying to imply as confusing as it may be to you readers (sorry about that). So I'll narrow it down.The Witcher: Enhanced Edition Director's Cut is one of the most unique games on the market; and the series itself as a whole as well. You won't find another game like this one with its take on combat and lore; and while the story progresses slower than one would like it an enriching tale and does keep you hooked with side quests and getting to know the characters (some in different ways -cough-). Projekt Red made some honest mistakes with their first fan made series but not any that meant any irritation to the player. I didn't encounter any bugs other than the game freezing a couple of times. Make sure that if you do play you save regularly. And if anyone would like to tell me how it ends feel free unless I'm wrong and it'll still have my safe file. In that case, PLEASE let me know.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mess. I'm so happy I completed it, so I don't have to play it anymore.That being said, the production value is pretty great. The visuals are impressive for a game based on the outdated Aurora engine. The textures and environment were really top notch. The soundtrack is also incredibly good: atmospheric with a lot of Slavic flavour. Fits the game brilliantly.As for the shortcomings: the gameplay is straight up nightmarish. Especially combat. Our character is unresponsive, get's caught in invisble terrain and we often don't know what the hell is even happening. The camera angles also don't help, because we can't see any enemies behind our character.The story is also pretty messed up. It's full of inconsistencies, deus ex-machina devices and cliche villains. The worst thing though, is that while we try to weave our character into the story, we have absolutely no clue as to what consequences our actions may have. Pairing it up with completely unintuitive reactions from NPCs makes for a wild ride. An example: kid says his caretaker won't give him any candy, because it's unhealthy. If you tell him his caretaker is right, he scoffs at you and says he's going to complain to his caretaker that you're being mean to him (what?). Then you go to the caretaker and she tells you, you should be nicer to the kid, since he's been through a lot. WHAT? I just enforced your rules upon him and you're upset about it?This isn't a huge inconvinience, but makes you want to save before every conversation, since you have no idea what will happen when you choose one of the dialog options.I would still recommend playing this game (at least the one time). It has a beautiful setting, some memorable characters, pretty funny dialog and wonderful music. If you just survive the combat and weird gameplay, there is a lot to like here.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												This game has interesting ideas that built the fundemental models the Witcher sequels use, however it ultimately falls short as a standalone title. The story is the main drive of the game yet it can become very uninteresting very quickly unless you pay attention to every little detail and constantly check your journal for background information on characters and quests. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it ends up making you lose motivation to continue if you don't absolutely pay attention to what each character interaction entails. Completing quests, on the other hand, essentially boils down to you running from one end of the mostly boring enviroments to the other with the occasional sprinkles of combat in between. Even when the game introduces detective elements to the quests, they still feel like a chore and yield no substantial outcomes or rewards for your efforts; most of the time, they lead you to track a second or third person.As for the combat, it feels very bland. The only thing making it different from a point-and-click mini-game is the alchemical preparations that can be carried out before each battle. But even that is something most people will choose to avoid since it is largely unnecessary at lower difficulty levels. My biggest complaint of all, however, is that at no point in the game do you feel like you have made significant progress as a player or as the character. There is no skill for you to master as a player as there is in other RPGs such as Dark Souls. And after 16 hours into this game, I also feel as though Geralt was the same as he was during his first fight (albeit with a few more spells). Apart from the initial sparks of interest in the story, this game offered little of its own to compel me to continue my adventure. So, unless your intention is to learn how the Witcher games evolved as a series, you will be just fine skipping this title and reading up the story online to play the sequels.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Let me just say, this was the best dollar I ever spent. This game goes on sale pretty frequently, and normally to about roughly $1. If that happens, pick it up immediately. 1$ for 30+ hours of ENJOYABLE gameplay can't be beaten. Yeah, sure, the Graphics and Combat are outdated and clunky. But overall, I was super impressed with this game. Like most people reading this, I wished to play the first two games before hopping into Wild Hunt. I figured this game would be torture, and at first wanted to speed through it as fast as possible. Boy, was I wrong to want that. The graphics are actually pretty decent for the time period. When not in a cutscene, I barely noticed low-res textures and the like. The combat, while being literally just clicking on an enemy to attack, turned out to be pretty exciting and engaging, despite its clunkiness. The game pulls you into a whole new world, like most good RPGs do. Your choices actually matter, there are lots of quests and things to do, and it has great lore and story. Not to mention a handful of witty one-liners from Geralt :P It is definitely a must play, especially or Witcher fans, and those who are broke, but still want to maximize *fun* gameplay :)And just a tip for beginners:POTIONS ARE YOUR FRIEND!!!! They make you ridiculously powerful if you get the right ingredients, and it's fun to experiment and try to find recipes for yourself.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												The Witcher is amazingly deep, rich with story, full of content, and extremely daunting for newcomers. Unlike The Witcher 2 combat is entirely skill based, which you will love or hate. I have to stress is that this IS NOT The Witcher 2, the gap in graphics, gameplay, storytelling, and especially voice acting will become very apparent too you.  This game requires patience, love, and time to get into but once you do get into it, you'll get hooked. PRO'S- tons of content- fantastic story/lore- the monsters!- mature and dark fantasy world- true choice and consequence- crafting (potions, oils, bombs)- classic skill based RPG mechanics- combat can be enjoyable...CON'S- ...but can get tedious after long hours of play.- voice acting- recycled character models (yes, even main ones!)- back tracking- little to no character customization ( you dont see new weapons/ armor for quite some time)OVERALLThis game is a must buy for people who wish to get more into the story/lore of The Witcher, or for those who crave a deep and complex RPG and feel up to some nostalgia.  oh, and heres a list of mods. they all add alot to the game, and i highly recommend you install them. all of these mods are lore friendly as well.-FCR ( Full Combat Rebalance ) *note, this mod changes combat drastically, personally i prefer vanilla as this can be buggy.-texturen-Scabbards-Rise of the white wolf *note, I feel this mod is a must! it adds alot to the game! install this one last!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												After playing The Witcher 2 and 3, I was pleasantly surprised by this game.  I heard before that it was a bad game, but I wanted to see for myself.  I suspect most players get put off by the confusing game mechanics, the combat system especially.  Once you play enough, you will get the hang of the game's systems.  I was slicing up Salamandra with ease by Chapter 2.  If you get bored of the slow detective-like story, don't worry because it picks up by Chapter 3.  You can beat the game easy by not doing any side quests, which is what I did.  The game has a dark and dingy atmosphere which can feel boring, but it's supposed to tie in with the atmosphere of the series.Some of the voice acting is pretty bad, and most of the characters faces look deformed.  Alvin and Dandelion are the worst.  The animations are pretty terrible aswell, like walking and Geralt's fighting.If you like the story of The Witcher 2 and 3, and have a lot of patience, I recommend giving The Witcher 1 a shot.  The scene with The Lady of The Lake and Eredin's spectre at the end are some of my favorite scenes in all The Witcher series.

												+ it's just a good 3D RPG game:* the quests are well thought out. they have some details, and characters connect with each other.* you can feel character behind characters (much better than the talking wikipedias in the skyrim, that's for sure)And you can get it on sale for a couple of bucks too.- non existent sex scenes - their execution is very symbolic in the game: The screen quickly fades out and you get a erotic card with that girl on it. Yay! ...  rather unsatisfying. (folks say The witcher 2 is better in this regard.)- some lack of the video settings. I would like to turn on V-sync - why no option for it?- bugs and glitches: at some points you will see some annoying things: white glowing on everyones faces / maybe stuttering cutsenes / ... many people experience different glitches - just go over to discussion section and see for yourself.- some "lazyness" on devs side:* confusedly/badly reused models - yes, there will allways be a limited set of models in a game, but as you start a game there will be some memoriable characters, but later as you progress you will encounter common characters that look exactly like them, it's like the devs said "f**k it, we are behind the schedule let's just use the model of that person."* minor inventory annoyances: like not being able to put stuff inside a chest/closet/box: you just read a book and want to put it from your inventory back to a shelf? - well you can't - you have to just drop it on the ground and walk away like a d0uchebag.side notes:when you are very drunk:it's faster to walk sideways.about game's CD-key:you can redeem a free copy of witcher 1 on gog.com:* Right click on The witcher 1 in your steam, and click "View CD-Key...". Copy it.* Log in to your gog.com account and go to linkhttps://www.gog.com/witcher/backupand paste your key there.* done. You redeemed your free, no DRM witcher 1 copy on gog.My point is: that's the only purpose of the CD-key. You do NOT need to activate the game with a CD-key as the steam will keep saying to you when you first start a game.

Posted: December 31, 2016
												It's okay. The story is so-so, the combat is rather clunky, controls are annoying and navigating through that Swamp is hell. The quests are confusing because you have so many of them, yet you can't complete any of them, because to complete one quest you need to complete another completely unrelated quest first. Another annoying thing with quests is that there is soooo much running back and forth. There is not much variation in the NPC's which makes the cities boring. But the characters that are important to the story are interesting, and there are a lot of big areas to explore, but other than that there's not much I like about this game. It can be entertaining at times, but sometimes it feels like a chore.The 2nd and 3rd game are better. It's not a bad game, but maybe not for everyone.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												The first of (what will soon be) an amazing trilogy, though it doesn't compare to the rest of the series no orignal title ever does.You are Geralt of Rivia, a trained monster hunter known as a witcher, you fight humans and monsters with your stell and silver swords (respectivly) you can use magic known as rune signs, and you know alchemy skills to craft various potions and bombs... and that's pretty much it. At the begining of the game you get amnesia, a cliche that's normally annoying and played out but it doesn't feel as annoying in this case because there's no secret your forgetting or underlying mystery that you keep getting reminded about but just can't remember.Asthetically, The Witcher looks pretty good and some of it's cutscenes are really cool but the character models aren't as spectacular. Musically it's a bit better but there's no stand out tracks, i just enjoyed listening to it's calm pieces as I scouted the land and it's envigorating battle music as I slashed through enemies.Combat can be very difficult in spots and you'll feel outnumbered (and sometims outmatched) but it's always satisfying to pull through.Overall i'd reccomend this game toanyone who enjoys a nice RPG with a lot of stuff to do, enemies to fight, and a game where there choices can help shape the world.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I wanted to play through Witcher 1 and 2 before moving on to 3. I know the storylines don't follow and its not necessary to do 1 and 2 but I wanted to get a feel for the characters and game universe.Pros:Good storylineInteresting charactersRP choices determining plot progressionCons:Getting stuck in same combat scenario for a long time (if you have no potions!)Getting stuck in mapsLimited special/progression in inventory (armor and weapons)I dont like referring to walkthroughs for gameplay or item collecting, but if you dont you can miss decent weapons and armor and make "bad" choices - not strictly RP I know but does impact gameplay negatively - slowing down your plot progression.I like the game but it is frustrating when you hit a combat dead end and have to fight same mobs 20+ times before surviving the encounter. This unfortunately breaks the RP immersion.My advice: make lots of health potions !, have a quick peek at any guides on getting best weapon and armor (try to avoid reading the spoilers), and keep saving before significant plot decisions and combat encounters - you will inevitably want to go back at least 2 or 3 saves at some time during the game.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I played The Witcher 2 first.  The Witcher 2 is a fantastic game, full of political intrigue, tight combat, and enough moral gray areas to satisfy the gothiest of goths or the fenciest of fence-sitters.  The setting was a fresh step away from the usual dragons and dungeons, brought to life by beautiful visuals of countrysides, crypts, and city-scapes.  And then I played The Witcher.Fair story and pretty awesome main character in Geralt, the White Wolf.  Upgrades in weapons feel heavy- your main weapons change once in each of the four chapters.  If you want a Diablo loot lottery (lootery?), keep looking.  I have gotten new armor once in 60 hours of play, and that was because I started with no armor.  This game makes you feel like you're working for your upgrades, and there's a lot to be said for that these days.  Geralt of Rivia is one of the best characters that I've come across in a lot of years of playing video games.  His voice acting leaves much to be desired, but his methods, motives, and skills are pretty incredible to play.  By the end of the game, just like with the equipment, Geralt feels like a cross between Wolverine, Scott Hamilton, and a long-time alcoholic.  Potions play a big part in game strategy, and Geralt learns to handle his liquor over the course of the game- turning him into a one-man army with just a few swigs.  His swordplay is pretty beautiful to watch by the end of the game, with many acrobatic twists and appropriately-heavy chops to keep you entertained while mindlessly clicking that mouse.  Which brings me to my next point...Unfortunately, this game falls down on three points- combat, travel, and questing.  Combat is a click-on-beat affair, which makes combat incredibly mind numbing.  I'm fighting a group? Let me switch to Group Combat Style and click.  Oh, most of the group is dead?  Let me switch to Heavy Style and click.  Lather, rinse, and repeat for 3 days worth of time.  There is no fast travel in this game (or I didn't find it), which is pretty awful considering Baldur's Gate and Diablo got this right in the 90's.   And because of the last fact, the questing turns this game into "5k Simulator 2010".  I never realized how much I don't like staring at the back of an albino's head for hours.  Anyways:Try this one out if...- you like real heavy choice in your games- you need an R-rated break from D&D- you ABSOLUTELY need to know the backstory for The Witcher: Assassin of Kings- you like to work for one of the best ending cutscenes around

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												You want adventure, eh? Well do I have the game for you! This is The Witcher, one of my all time favourite games. You might not like the game at first for the gameplay is quite odd, but believe me, I do NOT play games for the story. I'm an action guy but the slow pased combat of The Witcher is still quite enjoyable.This game is more than worth your money, If I was going to die in 12-24 hours you better bet that I'd be spending my time playing through this again. This is the adventure of a lifetime! The characters are so memorable (Kalkstein FTW =3) and the scenarios are so enduring you can't help but play this game for 10 hours at a time. The prologue, chapters 1-5 and the epiloge have so much variety in them, one moment you're solving a mystery and the next you're fighting a werewolf! The way you make decisions and how they effect the storys outcome is more than amazin. I felt genuine pressure when making my decisions the first time through.If you're looking for an amazing adventure, mystery or spiritual experience The Witcher is right for you! I'm not the kind of person who playes games more than once but The Witcher is an exception! You better pick up a copy before The Witcher 3 comes out so you know the full story before you see the endingI love this game :')

												Became a favourite immediately. I'm an avid RPG player, being the final fantasy series my preferred choice. This title changed so much of my perspective on the genre, coming from FF and Diablo, there's not much to say, just follow the story and level up your character. Love The Witcher!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												The first part of the Witcher Trilogy is one of the best RPGs released in 2007 according to many critics. I've only just played now 7 years later and it still was a great experience. It features a non-linear story with tons of side quests consisting of collect/kill quests for money and exp, aswell as intriguing quests where you have to find out who is behind some evil plot. You are often presented with a choice, which can be good or bad. Sometimes even though all evidence is against someone, it doesn't mean he is guilty. You can make a bad choice, and there's no turning back, the story goes on in different directions. Quests can fail as the story is separated in chapters and some quests can only be completed during a certain chapter and they depend on certain choices you make. In  general there's 3 paths good, bad and neutral which give this game a higher replay value.Now to the gameplay. Combat is simple and fast. You wear 2 swords, one for humans and one for monsters. Each sword has 3 stances, each more or less effective depending on a combat situation and enemy type. During a fight you perform timed combos using only your left click. Some will dislike this approach, but I didn't mind. You have also several spells like knockdown, fire, confusion, mind control and traps. Most of the time I've been using knockdown and fire as they seemed most effective.Music was great, fitting to the mood of the area. Voice acting was okay for the most part.During 50 hours of game time I've never encountered a serious bug, only some minor animation glitches.Overall, I would recommend this game to every RPG fan, especially those that are interested in Wither 2 and 3. This game was well worth 2€ I paid for it!Gameplay 6/10Story 8/10Graphics 6/10Polish 8/10Sound 8/10------------------------------------------Overall score 7/10 (Should I buy it? YES, its below 2€ on steam sale!)

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												I had heard from friends on occasion that The Witcher was a really fantastic game, and I cannot say that I was disappointed. While its graphics may not compete with more recent games, the rich story and world that the game brings life to is phenominal. For those who are unfamiliar with the books that this series is based upon, myself included, The Witcher is set in a very dark and grim world where monsters roam rampant and people live primarily in fear. The game provides you with unique decisions which can affect the story or in some cases your very character development. While some of the game mechanics are not the most exciting, they do their best to make them work. Combat works on a simple timed click system, which in itself is rather boring, but the moves that the valiant Geralt unleashes are quite dazzling and fun to watch. I also recommend looking into a mod or two to alter the very limited carrying capacity. The game limits item stacks to ten by default, which would result in an excess of returning to previous areas in order to maintain a stock of potions. On that note, both the alchemy and character development parts of the game are very unique and really well done. All in all, I think that this game is absolutely worth the time for a play through. Check it out, it is often on steam sale for under 2 dollars!

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This is is the second Witcher game I\'ve played after Witcher 3, and it\'s generally a good game on its own. As a first attempt by CD Projekt RED, it\'s very-well done. I\'ll admit, it was kind of hard to adjust to the hack-and-slash style of the gameplay, the rigid movement, and stuff. But, I can\'t nitpick it that hard because it was CD\'s first game. I\'ll admit. I almost quit the game twice while I was playing the beginning of the game, but once I got into the middle and end of the game, it got better and better once you start unraveling mysteries about the Salamandra. The story was also very good. The only complaint I would have against this game is that getting into the beginning of the game is kind of frustrating. Maybe it\'s because I played it on Hard, and plus, there\'s no complexity to the alchemy mechanics. On Hard, it says it requires alchemy, but all you need really is Swallow. You really don\'t need any other potion. But, overall, I recommend it to people who are fans of The Witcher series like I am and like good stories, but I wouldn\'t recommend it if you\'re not into rigid combat and hack-and-slash games.Rating: Recommended

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												This game is highly underrated. Even if the combat system is not the best, the immersive choice and delayed consequences system affect the story in a unique way. Sometimes you will be presented choices that will even impact your gameplay options and late game gear, which by the way is importable along with some decisions you make along the story. For a complete list of all the aspects that can be imported to The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings consult the link at the end of my own personal decisions.WARNING!!! SPOILERS AHEAD! YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!Personal list of decisions made, for my own personal reference:NOTE: Geralt is currently wearing the Neutral version of Raven's Armor and has the Mahakaman Rune Sihill as well as the Aerondight equipped.PROLOGUE• Chose to Save the Laboratory with TrissCHAPTER I• Safely Escorted Vesna• Helped Zoltan against the Racists• Let Haren Brogg's goods go to the Scoia'tael• Saved Kalkstein from the Salamandra Bandits on the bridge to Vizima• Chose the Lesser Evil and saved Abigail from the Reverend's MobCHAPTER II• Fought against the cockatrice alone.• Coleman died (Weapons the Scoia'tael took)• Killed the Cannibal in the Swamps• Successfully deduced that Raymond had been killed and Azar Javed had taken his place. As such, the autopsy was conveniently botched and thus afterwards pretended to kill Ramsmeat• Refused to lead both the Elves and the Order into battle in the SwampsCHAPTER III• Sent Alvin to Triss and gave her a Golden Ruby Ring• Saved Thaler from Count de Wett and the Order of the Flaming Rose• Spared Vincent the Werewolf and cured his lycanthropy disease• Spared Vetala during Six Feet Under (saved civilians)• Sided with the Order during the Robbery at Vivaldi’s BankCHAPTER IV• Reached a compromise between the Villagers and the Vodyanoi• Successfully set Alina to rest via Dandelion's Poem • Did not set Celina to rest via the Wreath of Immortelles• Killed Berengar • Remained Neutral and fled with Dandelion during the Order's attack on the elves in Murkey WatersCHAPTER V• Killed Princess Adda.• Killed Azar Javed with the help of Berengar's medallion EPILOGUE• Killed Yaevinn and Seigfried • Refused to let the King of the Wild Hunt claim the soul of Jacques de AldersbergMISCELLANEOUS• Romanced Triss [Gave her a Golden Ruby Ring and boned her twice]• Forged Raven's Neutral Armor• Collected every Trophy and received the Steel Sword 'Mahakaman Rune Sihill'• Collected every set of teeth for the dentist and received the Steel Sword 'Mahakaman Rune Sihill' (sold it as I already had one)• Won every fistfight.• Became a poker legend, however the sharper quest failed due to 1 failed game (needed 3 victories)• Did not complete all quests, failed some minor quests 2 or 3 quests, but finished at level 37 at medium - Seasoned Witcher.Import Information (SPOILERS!!!)[witcher.wikia.com]

												After completing the game and starting the second one, my advice is to skip the first. Assassins of kings is already looking much better than the first. My main issue, it's very time consuming, past the point of interest. You can even see that in the intro movie and the game intro, where it takes a little too long to get you in the action. Quests ask you to do a ton of walking, with nothing even resembling a fast travel system. You spend a long time listening to long conversations from poorly voice acted characters and walking through (for the most part) bleak and uninteresting settings. The combat system doesn't feel rewarding, as it is repetitive and gets dull quickly.I like the potion crafting system, even though it is unneeded for most fights. I also like the sex cards gimmick, even if it feels silly very often. (who has sex in the middle of a burning city?) They are fun to collect, even though they sometimes feel like a poorly made porn.Overall, my advice, just play the second game. It seems better in every way.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I decided to start The Witcher series just because I saw some critics praising it. As a 2007 game I was a bit skeptic about the garphics and gameplay, but I was pleasantly surprised.   The graphics, in my oppinion, are not very relevant for such games, as they focus on the story. Even so, the graphic aspect of the NPC's is very repetitive, all the elves and dwarves look the same except the colour of clothes. The men have maximum 5 different faces and the women 4. The exception are the important characters that have custom faces, which I liked.   In matters of gameplay, it took some time to get accustomed to the the combat system, as it was very different from all the games I played before, but now I find it rather intelligent and enjoyable.   The story was AMAZING! Very captivating and difficult to predict. It impressed me so much the difficulty and importance of making choices and taking decisions, a lot harder than in Dragon Age and Mass Effect series.   A 65h game that really deserves the money. Right now I'm already installing The Witcher 2 :)

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												This was an interesting one... I recommend The Witcher 1, for it's creative, interweaving combat, and it's deep story. But, only if you're going to play the other two. If you're going to play the other two, then I'd consider it almost necessary to play this one for its story.BAD - The graphics, animations, and general look feels dated. There are a couple parts where the game lags (down to 30fps), which a 2007 game should not be doing. However, most of the time it runs well above 100fps. The atmosphere is the only thing that can be complimented, but it's nowhere near perfect. The difference between forests, tropical islands, swamps, cities, and small villages is greatly felt.MEH - First off, there's a lot of content to be had here, I'm sure I missed a ton of it. Not to mention the effect your choices have on the story. That could be a good or bad thing, depending if you're a fan of the rest of the game or not. I probably won't replay it, personally, just because of a lack of time.MEH - The potion system is an unfamilar function to me, I wasn't a big fan of it. I found it neccessary to use some of the more exotic potions in the late game, but by then I was more used to it. It is unique, I'll give it that.GOOD - Yes, the combat is bad (at first). Through the prologue and first chapter, there's very little variety, and it's basically a pretty boring clicking rhythm game. However, once you start progressing past that, getting used to combining your spells, different swords (I used three end game), potions, and motion, I found the combat to be VERY enjoyable. Even if you still hate the combat, there are mods that change it entirely.GREAT - If you're going to play this game, this is what you're playing it for. If this is the only thing you're playing the game for, then I would personally play on easy and just do the story missions. You can import your saves into the Witcher 2, and it's obvious from the start how much your choices in The Witcher 1 mattered. Even your weapons and some other items are implemented into #2.VERDICT: Dated, and at times not very fun, it's worth pushing through to be introduced and know the story of the Geralt, as it immediately continues into The Witcher 2. Get it on sale.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Replayed the game a lot of times and now that I finished Witcher 3 too, I can finally honestly say, that this is the best game of the Witcher series. Ofc the graphics are what they are since the game is old, but if you can get over it, it´s perfect. There are some other shortcomings too, such as if you are fan of great combat systems, this game does not have it. However, there are things that Witcher 1 is superior to other medieval/fantasy games. For example atmosphere. The game describes the dark middle age just perfectly, goes deeply into human hatred and fear of unknown. Of all the games I´ve played, I like the monsters in this one the most. Behind almost all of them, there is a backstory of their creation, or rather how they were brought into the world. And since I do not want to spoil you out what you can read and get some goosebumps I´m just gonna cut it right here. With the great soundtrack on top of all this, both game´s atmosphere and goosebumps are gonna intensify :D Another great thing I´d like to point our is that the quest in the game are not all that easy. Since there is no marker to where should you find your quest object or NPC, you are gonna have to search for some of them pretty hard. Also the quests feel kinda logical and its not the usual stereotype of go there, fetch this, bring it there, kill him, oh that sh*** f***** up so you have to do 5 more things and stuff. At the end of this review I would like to thanks everyone for reading it. If you´ll buy this game I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did, and still do. Remember that you might have different opinion on some of these things and that´s completely fine. P.S.: There are some custom stories that you can play too, but most of them without voice actors.Here are some pros and cons:Pros:- atmosphere- great story- nice background- perfect soundtrack- good quest system- interesting mini game- sex cards :D Cons:- dull combat system- some of the spells are rather useless- cannot continue exploring after you finish the game- low variety of equipment

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I played The Witcher 2 first.  The Witcher 2 is a fantastic game, full of political intrigue, tight combat, and enough moral gray areas to satisfy the gothiest of goths or the fenciest of fence-sitters.  The setting was a fresh step away from the usual dragons and dungeons, brought to life by beautiful visuals of countrysides, crypts, and city-scapes.  And then I played The Witcher.Fair story and pretty awesome main character in Geralt, the White Wolf.  Upgrades in weapons feel heavy- your main weapons change once in each of the four chapters.  If you want a Diablo loot lottery (lootery?), keep looking.  I have gotten new armor once in 60 hours of play, and that was because I started with no armor.  This game makes you feel like you're working for your upgrades, and there's a lot to be said for that these days.  Geralt of Rivia is one of the best characters that I've come across in a lot of years of playing video games.  His voice acting leaves much to be desired, but his methods, motives, and skills are pretty incredible to play.  By the end of the game, just like with the equipment, Geralt feels like a cross between Wolverine, Scott Hamilton, and a long-time alcoholic.  Potions play a big part in game strategy, and Geralt learns to handle his liquor over the course of the game- turning him into a one-man army with just a few swigs.  His swordplay is pretty beautiful to watch by the end of the game, with many acrobatic twists and appropriately-heavy chops to keep you entertained while mindlessly clicking that mouse.  Which brings me to my next point...Unfortunately, this game falls down on three points- combat, travel, and questing.  Combat is a click-on-beat affair, which makes combat incredibly mind numbing.  I'm fighting a group? Let me switch to Group Combat Style and click.  Oh, most of the group is dead?  Let me switch to Heavy Style and click.  Lather, rinse, and repeat for 3 days worth of time.  There is no fast travel in this game (or I didn't find it), which is pretty awful considering Baldur's Gate and Diablo got this right in the 90's.   And because of the last fact, the questing turns this game into "5k Simulator 2010".  I never realized how much I don't like staring at the back of an albino's head for hours.  Anyways:Try this one out if...- you like real heavy choice in your games- you need an R-rated break from D&D- you ABSOLUTELY need to know the backstory for The Witcher: Assassin of Kings- you like to work for one of the best ending cutscenes around

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I'm going to start by saying one thing: this game has the slowest progression I've ever seen in any game; period. I have 31 hours into this game and I did not finish it. It takes that long. The reason why I'm making this review before I've finished is because my hard drive recently fried and according to Steam there is no cloud save and I do not plan on another 30+ hours just to see the end (as much as it pains me since I know the saves transfer over like Mass Effect). That's about the only negative thing I have to say about this game. The difference is really big between The Witcher and The Witcher 2 in basically every aspect. Combat is linear in this game in the sense that you can only focus on on enemy at a time. However, as a Witcher you are skilled in combat thus giving you the ability to do hard and strong, fast and group attacks. The graphics aren't bad but there's a clear difference like I said. The story, like I said in my first paragraph,  basically drones on. I am not saying that it is bad; this game is worth the buy for the story but you need a lot of patience. I really hope I don't sound like I'm saying 'meh' because that is not what I am trying to imply as confusing as it may be to you readers (sorry about that). So I'll narrow it down.The Witcher: Enhanced Edition Director's Cut is one of the most unique games on the market; and the series itself as a whole as well. You won't find another game like this one with its take on combat and lore; and while the story progresses slower than one would like it an enriching tale and does keep you hooked with side quests and getting to know the characters (some in different ways -cough-). Projekt Red made some honest mistakes with their first fan made series but not any that meant any irritation to the player. I didn't encounter any bugs other than the game freezing a couple of times. Make sure that if you do play you save regularly. And if anyone would like to tell me how it ends feel free unless I'm wrong and it'll still have my safe file. In that case, PLEASE let me know.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I had a good time with this game! It is rather clunky and awkward, but it's got a lot of charm to it. While the combat is nothing spectacular, the different combat styles and spells kept me focused and enjoying the fights. There are some cool boss fights here and there. I also think it's neat that you are required to study up on monsters and plants. Learning recipes and making potions is fun, even if I ended up rarely using them.I found the characters and dialogue to be entertaining. The game surprised me with how silly it really is, the best example being when you get drunk with Geralt's buddies. One obvious problem the game has is making you run across the map multiple times with no quick way to travel. There's a lot of walking, and there's no help with that except for some portals that are only in acts 2 and 3. Even with those portals, I feel like those acts in particular are a drag to go through. But even at its worst, I was still compelled to play the game all the way through.I was a little frustrated by how there is no quick heal, but I hesitate to call that a flaw. The game probably would be too easy otherwise, so I think it's fine. You have to find a campfire to rest or use a potion if you want to heal quickly. The game's soundtrack is excellent, and I enjoy the story. Also the sex.This game is rough around the edges, but I like it. It convinced me to play it and also the sequels.
